content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Fable Anniversary is a colorful Action RPG set in the pomporous fantasy world of Albion. The player takes control of the hero and progresses from childhood to adulthood, making critical choices that affect your story. Quests are a dime a dozen, and although there might be more loading screens than most would expect from an open world game, it does nothing to contain the exploration of the wondorous realm. Albion is a fantasy like none other, with humor and intense action waiting behind every door. The combat is fluent and enjoyable; Not easy but not difficult to grasp. If you've played the other Fable games, it plays just the same. Yet the thing that stands out the most for me is the players interaction with the rest of the world. The expressions are fun and make for a very interesting mechanic, and the whole alignment system (as in good/evil) is one of my personal favorite mechanics of the game. Seeing the halo hover over my pomporous hero's head is very satisfying to say the least, and really gives weight to the choices presented to the player. Acclaimed as the best in the series, it's easy to see why this game receives so much love. Most of everyone is fully aware that this is a remake, and the original is available on steam. So is it worth $30? To me, very much so. It is a vast improvement from the original in all the best ways, without straying from the original greatness of the earlier edition. I know that some people prefer the original version, and there's nothing wrong with that. But this game isn't for those people, it's for new players to enjoy the game with a new and modern life in it, and for the true hardcore fans who are excited to revisit this beloved world in a new way. I understand that a lot of people are having problems with framerate and texture (which i haven't experienced my whole time in the beta), but the developers have been and will remain active! They have been great at addressing everyone's problems and fixing them, and i'm sure they will continue to do so. As for me, I'll continue to support Lionhead in hopes that this is the beginning of something great. Fingers crossed for Fable Legends and Fable 2 Anniversary!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Just how I remember the fable games! I played all of them on console, fable 2 and 3 being my favourites. I pretty much forgot about this game after playing those, but it's all coming back to me and it is DEFINITELY worth playing if you're into genres such as this, or if you've played any other fable games. Even if you've already played this through on console, play it again! I love that it's been remastered, just like all fable games, the story is a bit repetitive but it's real easy to get in to, just don't skip the cut scenes or you won't know what the hell has happened. Also, there is a bit of an annoying 'issue' in the cut scenes, 2 black lines appear sort of like making the screen a cinematic view however it just looks dodgy, like some sort of glitch, but that's only during the cut scenes so it's not a big issue.Either way, I definitely recommend this game whether you've played it or not. The combat is pretty easy but super fun! The quests are sometimes story rich, and sometimes they're just comical (like searching for a man who's cheating on his wife, then snitching on him and watching her rip his head off.. not literally). You can get haircuts, get married, get tattoos, there's loads to do!The greatest thing about the fable games is the good deeds or bad deeds. You change the way people view you, they could be scared of you or dislike you because you chose to follow an evil path and perform bad deeds, or they could root for you and clap every time they see you because you're known as a hero and perform good deeds!So yeah, I recommend it, it's old, but it's gold! (I got it for £4.00 in the sale, bonus!!!)

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												A lot of people are salty about this release, I get it. The Lost Chapters (which will be TLC from now on, go ahead and take a moment to load up Waterfalls on youtube) kept the faithful graphics that give it more of an edge, a grittier organic feel and the price difference is almost absurd.But don't go chasing those waterfalls just yet. On a Chinese based website hosted on American based webspace ('g' two 'a' .com) this game is actually less than TLC, because of demand a lot of private sellers are able to sell this game for less than eight dollars, TLC is selling for just under nine.So about my experience; I grew up watching my friends play this game when I was young. When it was originally released I was 13 and I didn't own an xbox. Many sleep-overs were spent watching my friend's epic adventures through Albion, at the time the game was pretty groundbreaking.Now 12 years later I am finally experiencing the game from the pilot's seat, damn does it feel good.The graphics are great for its age, the worst part of the remake being the camera which didnt quite survive the tinkering process; it is a little wobbly but I got used to it after an hour. Like I said I never really played the Fable games for myself in the past so I do not need the older graphics for nostalgia reasons but it would have been nice to have the choice to toggle between old and new.So since the price between the games are so close on that Chinese site, I can only say that either one will satisfy you, just get the one that you feel makes the most sense to you and please stick to the rivers and the lakes that you're used to.R.I.P. Lisa 'Left Eye' Lopes

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Fable Anniversary is a fully remastered version of Fable: The Lost Chapters. It features a graphic overhaul, new save system and incorporates achievements. And well, that's it. And that right there is the problem. The reason everybody loved the first Fable was for it's slapstick humor and eccentric characters. But the game aged pretty badly. Sloppy animations, simplistic combat, stiff and eerie looking characters, finiky movement, oh and don't forget all the bugs..... So when Lionhead announced Fable Anniversary I was pretty stoked and could not wait to play a remastered and polished version of Fable.However, even though the visuals got an upgrade, characters, animations, movement, interaction, combat, etc. all remained the same. I've played through the entire game and nearly 100% completed it, because I do love the world of Albion, but in the end there's more to a game than nostalgic value. And this game delivers no more than that. I would only recommend getting the game if you are a fan of the original Fable: TLC.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												The menu is super clunky. Many people say the old menu was bad (I didn't find a big problem with it though, it was straight forward.) I actually had problems locating where things are. There's large tabs and several submenues. That being said, its still organized, its just ironically counter intuitive. So is the way you navigate.I mean, who uses pg up, down, home, end, delete, to navigate a menu? where's the mouse? It says "KEYBOARD AND MOUSE" and...IM NOT ALLOWED TO USE THE MOUSE to navigate the menu. Excuse me? Who managed the design overhaul for this game? Keep in mind, I own every fable game, and still replay fable: the lost chapters on PC to this day. since it came out. I love that game with all my heart, but the hero's face is disgusting. There's a few faces that look decent, like the guildmaster, and I like whisper's, but the hero's is awful. that and the mouse is overly senstive and I cant change that. It makes camera controls a bit awkward, but still manageable.Also, does anybody know how to change the hotkeys on the numpad? I had a very specific layout for them in the original, and I cant find a way to edit.Aside from all that, I find it interesting to see what's changed, and will continue playing. If you're new to Fable, I wouldn't recommend at all, but I would if you're a vet. I still want to support Peter Molyneux for his faithful devotion to the series, I just wish they'd try to mix innovation with practicality, as I think sometimes, they leave that later part out.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Even though I'm used to the Keyboard and Mouse from playing Fable: The Lost Chapters a hundred times over, I went straight to the controller because I wanted to see how that felt and I was plesantly surprised. I haven't tried Key+Mouse, and looking at the reviews here, I don't think I will, but if you're willing to play with a controller, you shouldn't have any problems.As for the game itself, I could tell you to save yourself some money and buy the original TLC, because it's the same game exactly, minus the graphic update which is nice, but not at all necessary to enjoy the awesome game it already was.I'm still gonna recommend it for one little detail, and that's the Heroic Mode. Shops will have a limited supply of Health and Mana Potions, although you can still find both as loot for defeating enemies or from Traveling Merchants at a slightly marked up price. Vendors will now purchase whatever you sell at 50% of what it costs, which means no more making a fortune by Buying/Reselling Emeralds in Oakvale, no more Resurrection Phials, more expensive and less effective Physical Shield and Enflame and all enemies will be buffed and give you 40% less experience.Heroic Mode feels a bit more like what the game should have been initially. Now, at the same time if you're like me, and you like to powergame, it'll just make it a bit grindier  but overall more challenging, which is nice.

												Ill keep my report short.  If you once owned Fable, and youd like to own it once more, this version of it is a nice makeover.  However, if you currently own Fable, it isnt worth a cent.  I bought this game on sale, and i still wish i hadnt bought it.  Shoulda listened to the reviews, but i was stubborn.Pros: The new look of the enviroments... thats about it... the trees are pretty...Cons: Character models are hideous.  Whoever put them together clearly did this as a rush job.           New menus are far more clunky.  Sorry i cant use a better word to describe.This is a game that was only put out as an "HD" anniversary edition as a means to make money.  I dont even blame the company for that.  I mean, thats what companys do.  I only mention this as a warning to all: There was no heart put into this.  None.   The only good thing they did was add the ability to modify the game.  Perhaps with that feature, someone will give this game a REAL makeover.Once again you have failed us.  I am the fool for trusting you, and this is my confession.

												I really do not know why people hate this game so much, it is exactly what it is advertised as without anything more or less. I have yet to crash and I have enjoyed every second of playing as much as I did when this game came out ten years ago.I have played Fable and Fable TLC countless times, the game is stellar and to see it remade with HD graphics brings me another layer of joy. Its like when you don't play a game for years and years and years and when you look back on playing it with rose colored glasses and then you see the HD remake and you think yourself, this is what I remember. They didn't cut anything but they didn't really add anything. I got the game on sale and it was well worth the 15 dollars that I spent on it. Fable will provide you hours and hours of entertainment and is way better than any of its sequels. Pick this game up and you will not regret it.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Do not buy the game. Just don't. Not for yourself, not for others. After much time and effort, I've only managed to be able to play this game for about 3 sessions so far. Every other time I try to launch or load the game I'll get hit with an infinite load screen, a freeze glitch, or there will be no sound and I'll have to close and restart it all from the beginning.. Obviously this isn't happening to everyone but it is to me, and probably to a few others too. Personally I just can't stand to deal with it anymore. I was really excited to finally get this game after finding it on steam and on sale for so cheap. I'd been wanting to replay Fable lately too, so I thought this was a golden opportunity to replay a great game with a few new things included. Even as cheap as it was though, it really wasn't worth it, and this is coming from a Fable fanboy. And though I call myself a fanboy I don't think I'm biased or unfair in my gripes with this "updated" version, it really does just feel like the changes made to this version are just worse than the way things were in the original. The unintuitive menu system that makes makes you constantly switch between WASD and arrow keys for no reason, the new opening menu which lags and doesn't load the proper save that you're trying to load (no matter which save I selected to try and load it always tries to load the same one). Also, am I the only one who thinks the characters were made so incredibly ugly in the visual updates? I mean really, they're  hideous. How is that an upgrade?...And then therey's the skippy framerate, even though I have over the recommended specs on all accounts and I've turned all of the settings to the lowest possible configuration. I don't know if my pc is to blame or if the game is, but something is just clearly messed up in this whole situation. The one good thing I have to say is that for the keyboard and mouse route, combat still holds up, but between the menus being abysmally annoying to go through, the game just isn't worth it. Even when it's on sale for super cheap. For the sake of being fair, I'll also mention the good things. The visuals were really nice. Character design aside, the environments and buildings were pretty sweet to look at, even with the messed up framerate. The DLC was really cool too. I'd always felt the game lacked a wider variety of armor and weapons. A lot of the dlc stuff feels fillerish and pointless, but quite a bit of it is cool too. If your game works properly then it's worth having. The most exciting thing to me though was the new difficulty level. It added a new level of excitement to the game that's been lacking for me after so many playthroughs. I died 3 times on my way to Oakvale! I would never come close to dying in the original mode. So yeah, it's neat to be kept on my toes again. Shame the game turned out to be a bust. With all of that stated for the record, Based on my experience, I can't recommend this game to anyone. Not even mega-level Fable fanboys and not even if the game is ever on sale for $2. If you do DL the game, I hope you have better luck than I did.UPDATE: After building a new, and much more powerful computer, the game is running fine for me. All the framerate and sound issues I mentioned above aren't happening anymore. I still choose not to recommend the game though because even my last pc was above the recommended specs and well above the minimum recommended specs. And I still stand behind the character design issues and the menus. Maybe the menus work better with a controller but for keyboard and mouse it's pretty lame. I guess if it's on sale for under $10, maybe you can take the risk and buy it though.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Fable is a great game. The combat is simple and fun, with a good variety of weapons and spells that you are fully encouraged to explore. There is a lot of great British humor, and a lot of charming character is put into the environment and the people and things that inhabit it. There is a cool simple morality system, wherein the world and the people in it react appropriately to your deeds and if you are a good guy/bad guy. There are also a lot of little extra role playing touches, like the ability to get married and have kids, that ultimately don't change the game much but it is really nice that they are there. So yeah, if you like RPGs, you should totally dig up a copy of Fable for Xbox (or maybe the GFWL version if you can find it) for a very fun and light Zelda-esq adventure experience. Unfortunately, this port does not do Fable justice. This port feels like a step backwards from the original Xbox version in almost every way. The first glaring issue is the menus. The menus are incredibly clunky and hard to navigate. Bafflingly, some of the menus seem to allow mouse navigation, and then other menus force you to use your keyboard to navigate them. As far as I can tell, there is no rhyme or reason as to which menus are mouse navigable and which are not. It is not uncommon to start off browsing through the first tier of a menu with your mouse, then when you get to the next tier you suddenly can't click anything and have to use incredibly clunky keyboard commands to continue through.The next issue I have with this mess would be the controls. To put it simply, this game controls like absolute poop if you use a keyboard and mouse. The mouse feels jittery and not accurate. As for the keyboard stuff well, any time a game makes you use the "Backspace" key as a common control, you know you are in trouble.Graphically, this game is a mixed bag. On the one hand, some of the lighting techniques seem to have been modernized, and there seems to have been some modeling work. On the other hand, the new higher poly models that they added to the game just don't look very good. This issue may be entirely subjective, but the new models just kind of look weird and lack the same interesting character that the original models had.As for the kind of graphical options tweaks, this game is your typical lazy PC port in that it offers you very little in terms of video options.To sum this up, this just feels like a cheap, not particularly good port. Combine that with the ludicrous price tag, and I'd say that you should never touch this game with a ten foot pole. This is a shame, because the core game of Fable is really, really good. Fable deserves better than this. Moreover, YOU deserve better than this. Don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												I've played Fable: The Lost Chapters for hours when I was younger, this remastered version has a few improvements. Positives Sound has been enhanced,  Cutscenes are ever so slightly clearer...just - you have to squint even with a side by side comparison. Marginally better textures for some items and areas, they still look considerably outdated.  Meshes for buildings and objects are quite a bit better. Controller Support!!Negatives A blurry filter over the whole game - FXAA?? The new lighting has completely changed the colour and look of the game. The vibrant fantasy colours are now gone. The new character models look like they're made of wax/plastic. Combined with the new weird shadows, they all look like their faces melted. The main character as a child actually looks like some kind of goblin. This is the most glaring and visually offensive problem for me. Not all of the keyboard and mouse controls can be rebound as in the original. The redesigned menus have no mouse support and take longer to navigate because of the way they're layed out. The game is a port of a port (TLC > X360 > PC) and is very poorly optimized. It does not run particularly well.At the end of the day, save £20 and get Fable: The Lost Chapters instead. It runs in 1080p, all the keys can be remapped to your comfort and you can force anisotropic filtering using your graphics card control panel to make the game look nicer apparently.

content:
Posted: April 17
This is the stuff memories are made of.For a long time, I decided against acquiring a remastered version of Fable. Having previously bought Fable: The Lost Chapters a year after its' release, I saw no real advantage in buying what was essentially the same product a second time. But the call of nostalgia eventually got the better of me. That being said, objectivity obliges, I'll try not to drift too much down memory lane.Fable is the incarnation of Molyneux's vision in so many ways, it would be tedious to enumerate those aspects. It suffices to say that the game follows a pattern which was already present in Black & White: that of the choice between good and evil. But instead of playing as a god, you are a simple child who will grow to become a hero after a fateful, traumatising event. What kind of hero you will become - a good magician, sneaky fighter, etc.- is entirely of your choosing.Even down to its' very name, the world of Albion is a fantasy-folkloric rendition of medieval Britain. And it particularly excels in that area. The variety of English (mostly Northern and West Country) accents, Monty Pythonesque dialogue, landscapes, myths (e.g. Huw's longsword, King Arthur anyone?), creatures, map (which oddly ressembles Wales and the Irish Sea) are always there to remind you of the inherent Britishness of the game. From the bandit-ridden forestlands to the Ale-brewing taverns, it succeeds in creating an aesthetically pleasing rpg and is more-than-atmospheric-enough to bring about a credible world of its' own. To put it differently, Albion sure looks like a beautiful place to live in.Also worth noting is the musical score, the opening theme was composed by the ever so talented Danny Elfman (you might also remember him as the leading member of Oingo Boingo, the author of the Simpsons theme, Tim Burton movie soundtracks along with countless other film scores). Russell Shaw took great care of the rest, and much to his merit, one cannot understate the monumental influence of music in this game. It is literally the heart and soul of Fable.This game easily ranks up amongst the best titles to have graced the Xbox console. So what of this new version?Given that it is mainly a faithful reproduction of what was made a decade ago. There is very little in there to criticise.One of the main criticism I can bring up against Fable is that it is two-sided. Playing neutral won't really satisfy you. This game badly wants you to vouch for one side over the other. Either become a total♥♥♥♥♥♥or an angelic figure. On the other hand, playing evil is great fun (even hilarious at times). This system offers double-replayability down to the smallest side quest.What of the DLCs? Unless you seriously intend on looking like a total reincarnation of Jack of Blades at the end of the game, most of them aren't really worth buying. Of all the weapons featured in the game, only one will give you a true upper hand over your enemies (Solus Greatsword for the win), the DLC ones are no game-changers.As for the graphics, it's a bit of a mixed bag in my opinion. Sure, the landscape looks splendid. But the characters look too plastic, especially when it comes to their face, it's almost like something straight out of Spitting Image. The original Xbox version had a charm of its own which this Anniversary edition can't surpass.All in all, these are minor flaws in contrast to the game as a whole. As someone who bears the unpopular opinion that Fable 2 was a downgrade and Fable 3 a slight improvement, I wish Lionhead studios had carried on the Fable franchise in the direction of the original game. Here's to hoping for a Fable IV reboot set in a prequel Old Kingdom world, much like I long for an Age of Empires IV (another franchise which Microsoft mindlessly destroyed).Highly recommended for first time players.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												I usually won't write a review for a game but for this one, I thought it was nesccary.Fable has always been a game that I've liked, It's a good series of a games, even if they're not the sprawling epics usually promised there usually always solid games.Fable Anniversary is no exception.First, Every action having consequences is a bit of an oversell. Every choice has immediete consequences, but  that doesn't mean every choice changes the world. in fact very few choices actually change the world around you. You'll get bounties for committing a crime, and people may react to your characters differently, but your actions don't change much how the story goes.An example of this is, in one quest you're given the choice of killing or sparing someone. If you kill them they're dead you never see them again in the game. If you let them live, you get a few moments of dialouge with them, than they leave Albion forever so you never see them again. The choice's don't have any real weight, except affecting your players look and how npcs react to you.The Combat is solid enough, although it kind of punishes you for not being a Jack of all trades. I would never suggest only doing Will or only doing Skill or only doing Power, All 3 are needed for combat (Although skill less so) You will likely be fighting with a mix of Power and Will. Skill is alright for bosses but the time you'll need to charge a bow makes it almost usesless against the regular mobs of enemies you'll face.The Social and Property side, If you're coming from Fable 2 or 3 you know how much the Social skills and Property are important. In this game not so much. You have about 1 house per town you can buy without killing the owners and the Social actions are not nesccary at all if you can get a certain level of atractiveness, Seriously I don't think I used a Social action once in the game but I had a full level of affinity with every elegible bachelor and bachelorrette.Game time, I currently have 14 hours, that's what it took to beat this game (Both Main game and Lost Chapters) while also doing Bronze quests and most of the silver quests except 3, The last 3 were basically quests I couldn't see a Good way of doing so I skipped them. It's short for an rpg but it's fun enough to make up for it.What does Anniversary add? Now I haven't bought any of the anniversary DLC so I don't know how good the weapons are it adds, but what I do know about are it's Steamworks compatibility and Graphic/Audio remaster.Steamworks: Definately in it's infancy, there are not a lot of mods and a lot of them are Heavy Weapons guy at the momement. If playing as heavy weapons guy with a Heavy Weapons hammer and Shrek wasps sounds good than this is the game for you.Graphic/Audio remaster: It's amazing, the whole thing looks like a brand new game, on my machine enemies with a bit more detail like the White Balverine or Twinblades, too a little longer to render but for the most part it was seamless.What would I suggest you pay for this game? 15-20 dollars. While the Remaster looks like a brand new game it's really the same Fable The Lost Chapters you can pick up for 10 here on steam. However I definately think it's worth an extra 5 or 10 dollars, but don't buy it for the full 35. However if it's on sale I'd say pick it up in a second. If you're a Veteran of the Series or a new player Fable Anniversary is a solid game that will give you at least 28 hours of enjoyment (14 for Good, 14 for Bad Charachter)

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Before starting this review, let's all bow our heads in mourning for Lionhead: they may not have been the perfect studio, but they had a lot of good ideas, and the next Fable game is going to be a fantasy based card game, because clearly we didn't have enough of those!  I played through all of the Fable games in their original incarnations (Yes, even the Kinect one, never have I waved my hands in such fury!), and I had heard that the 360 version of Anniversary was saddled with performance problems.  Fortunately the PC version seems to have resolved this and the gameplay has dated really well.  Obviously the combat doesn't really stack up to something like Witcher 3, but that isn't really the point, this is a quirky, quintessentially British fantasy game with a lot of heart, and many years after it's over the top prerelease promises its possible to see it as exactly that.  If you played it before then its a lovely trip down memory lane, and I you have only played the later installments then it's essential.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Alright, so let me say I may be a little biased, because Lionhead has bribed me with all the sun shaft effects. Ok, so basically, this game is a graphical enhancement to Fable: The Lost Chapters. And for all these other people reviewing, they are downvoting because they expected even more stuff to be in the game, which I find quite stupid because the whole point of re-making games like this is so that people who haven't played it yet can experiance it where it looks even better, or for nastolgia's sake. Alright, so here is the basic run down of good and bad:GOOD:- All the models, animations (Some of these are still the origional), textures, and light FX have been redone- The game looks really pretty on the max settings, and some of the movement is even smoother than before- Combat is still massively fun- Stays true to the origional's everything, but they did add some outfits though- The game supports modding, and even gives a free DLC to get the SDK- They are releasing some new content packs to add more to the gameBAD:- When you save, it only saves from your last checkpoint, sometimes you have to redo a thing or two (not very game breaking though)- The eye's pupils are too big on some characters, making the game look a little awkward- Textures can sometimes be a little lower resolution than would be expected- Texture poping sometimes happens (Unreal Engine's fault, not the devs)Overall, I would have to recommend this game. All the people asking for this need to stop complaining about the little things, all of them will either be fixed by lionhead or by modders. I don't know about you guys, but I am having a great time. So overall, about an 8.7/10EDIT; They added keyboard and mouse support in menus. It could have been better, but its on par so I dont really view it as a bad thing

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Most people I know got their introduction to the series with 2008's Fable II on the Xbox Tree-Sickidy. From what I remember, it's not a bad game, but it was a bit of a step down from the original. And the third and final entry was even worse. I believe Fable / Anniversary is the only truly great game in the series. Truly a one-hit wonder. Why? I guess it just has a charm that it's sequels did not possess (as much), from the characters to the world to the soundtrack. And the sequels were also too simplified, especially the last one, from the breadcrumb trails to the combat. Still, it's a shame Lionhead shut down recently, so there doesn't look to be a chance of a redemption for the series. Even the cancelled Fable Legends didn't look all that promising in my opinion.At least before Lionhead went out with a whimper, Anniversary was released, a remastered version of the original game. Being an Xbox hipster when all the other kids had PS2s, I played it back in 2005, not long after it's release. I remember actually not being too keen when I first started, what with starting as a kid and having to earn money to buy your sister a present. I thought, wow, how lacklustre is this... And the world and goofy-looking characters with thick-accents I found somewhat freaky.I didn't play it for long, and lent it to my brother to play at the hospital where he was staying with hella-bad tonsilitis. He played a ton of it and convinced me it was a great game, so I tried it again, and got very much into it, eventually falling in love with it. And I fell in love with it all over again with Anniversary.The world is a medieval interpretation of Britain, of course with the addition of magic and the threat of dark forces and whatnot. So yeah, sounds pretty darn familiar. But this exceeds with the way all that is portrayed. With colourful charm and humour, the choice between a good and bad alignment, either which alters you physically and changes the perception of those around you, and easy accessibility (but not too simple as it's sequels, as I said).You start as a little boy, scatting about your nice little town trying to get money to buy your sister a birthday present. And the choices start here. Do you earn that money with good deeds (i.e watch a bloke's barrels for him while goes off for a♥♥♥♥♥♥ or earn it with bad deeds? (agree to watch those barrels but then smash them and earn the approval of a little shitbag trying to peer pressure you). You get many of those choices throughout, some harder to make than others.Bandits attack your village, and♥♥♥♥♥♥goes sideways. You are rescued by a member of the Heroes Guild, where you begin training as said Hero, and grow up there, eventually leaving as an adult. As it goes in video games, whatever alignment you choose, you still end up saving the world from the big bad guy.In games with moral alignments, I tend to stay on the good side, because that's just me. And I did when I played the original. But this time round I became as evil as possible, doing bad deeds, assisting bandits, betraying my family and murdering innocents. Either side of the moral spectrum grants you exclusive items and weapons. I was so evil I grew horns, had red eyes and skin like a zombie. I looked awesome. On the higher end of the light side you have nice skin, a halo above your head, and all the people love you. And if someone loves you that much (you can further earn their affections with gifts and flirtatious gestures), you can ask them to marry you; man or woman. Pretty impossible to earn trust and affection if you're evil though. Everyone just screams and runs away. Just like me in real life ohhhhhh!All in all do I recommend this? You bet your big♥♥♥♥♥I do. The thing to take into consideration though, is that while this is an RPG, it's not entirely open-world. It consists of many individual chunks of areas, many with very narrow paths. And there isn't a colossal amount of things to do, once you've unlocked and collected everything. So those who are more used to the gargantuan games of today (i.e Skyrim, The Witcher 3) with literally hundreds of hours of content, stunning graphics and modern mechanics, might not be so impressed. But there is certainly enough to keep you going for a good 25+ hours or so. Especially now as it has achievements, and some rather amusing ones at that, like getting a headshot with a crossbow while dressed as a woman, farting while dressed as an assassin, and choosing whether to explore every single region or just get fat (they unlock the same achievement).A personal niggle from me? It's possible to miss one of the silver keys out of the thirty you can collect. If you leave it too long before starting the fishing competition, the NPC you talk to can disappear forever. As an achievement geek this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. You have to get all thirty keys in one playthrough for an achievement, and I have twenty-nine... So to get it again I'll have to start again and get the thirty all over again...Still, I gotta give it full marks for everything else.10/10

number of helpful: 21 of 38 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												EDIT: It's worth noting that Lionhead have been good enough to update the game and have fixed many of the common gripes. This is good as it indicates that Lionhead are putting their money where their mouth is.However I still, honestly, believe that the incredible cost of this - around 3.5x more than the Fable: the Lost Chapters - makes this not worth it. At the end of the day it is, by and large, a "HD" redux of the original that doesn't look "HD" - Fable 3 looks notably better in everyway except the faces (which are done very well). With the mod support it has, maybe in time this will become a game that is worth the money it's asking for, however at the moment it is staggeringly overpriced.If you don't have the game, the cost of the other one is better. If you do have the game, the graphics are not actually that much better (or, really, that good to begin with - they use a DirectX package from 2010, and honestly, it looks like the game would fit that age quite well).[note: I use a 360 controller for many games anyway (the Fable series, in particular, does not need a mouse+key), so the pretty bad port mechanics aren't all that for me.]The big selling point of this game is the graphics and, based on the iffy model and texture quality, I highly doubt they're going to get noticeably better. In Oakvale there are areas that, graphically, look lifted from the base game.It looks like there will be mods (and if there can be mods there will be mods), but it also looks like there's some D1DLC.This is not worth $USD35; skip it and be happy.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												I had fond memories of this game and was very much looking forward to its PC release. The graphics are improved, and the game itself seems well preserved but.... yet another console port where keyboard and mouse support is terrible. Unlike its much older non-anniversary sibling, the menu is navigated by the insert, delete, home, end, "A" and "B" keys. Your mouse does nothing in the menu.The controller issues coming out from these console ports (looking at you Dark Souls 2), that are never likely to be fixed or optimized are very disappointing- especially in this case- a re-release with worse controls than a decade old predecessor. If keyboard controls are what you prefer and their poor implementation is a pet peeve for you, I would advise against this purchase- stick to the older version (still available on Steam)- and yes you will want frequent access to the menu so it is a bit of a game breaker (when i scroll through armor it all gets unequiupped).Edit: (22/8/2014) Since I wrote this review the game has been patched twice with small but significant improvements. If the developers continue to patch and update the game it will likely become the gem we were all hoping for. Might be a good X-mas purchase.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I enjoyed Fable: Lost Chapters when it was first released years ago; and it did not age well.This update to the aging game was a welcome sight, so I purchased the game when it was on a flash sale, for a third of its normal price.The graphical update is fairly well done, and keeps to the cartoonish look of the original, it looks like they tried to fix some of the issues with the original game as well.That's where the good parts of the game come to an end though.It's a good thing that you can now save anywhere, as you'll see your desktop more often than you'd like. The game crashes during entirely mundane activities (walking, etc.) for no apparent reason.The controller support was a nice touch, and they tried to make it more user friendly (failing mind you, as it feels as though the 'improved' controls are somehow worse than the original). However the game is sluggish and unresponsive. I find myself being struck where I wouldn't be, had I been playing the original.Taking everything in consideration, I can't recommend this game at it's normal price. Pick it up on the cheap, during a flash sale, or holiday sale; otherwise, look for something more worthwhile.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Quick fixes in this review so read carefully if you want a great play experience.Alright, so I've read all the other reviews and I agree with most of them; however, there are some easy fixes to most of the problems.  Yes, there is a stuttering issue that is incredibly annoying.  It is rough being able to run Crysis 3 on ultra and not being able to run Fable on anything.  To fix this - cntrl alt delete and set fable's affinity to cpu 0 only.  The game was originally designed during a time when almost everything only ever used 1 core.  This does fix the issue and it runs perfect after.  I have a gtx 780...it is not nvidia that is the issue.  Nvidia runs fine with this program.  The FPS problem people are complaining about are because they have both integrated and dedicated graphics.  If you have an AMD APU or 4th gen intel the integrated graphics should be fine and you won't even notice (I have a 4th gen intel and just leave it running off that).  If you are still having issues though,  "just go to Nvidia control panel and select the Manage 3D Settings tab. After that “select Program Settings” and find Fable Anniversary and switch the game to your Nvidia graphics card". quoted from segmentnext.com because I'm lazy.The game is best ran with a controller.  I have a cheap logitech i use for my emulated stuff and it works fine.  If you are going to use the keyboard, it isn't too bad but it isn't anything like the original.  I think people don't like change and just love complaining.  It is what it is.  Another complaint I heard plenty of was the lack of "video" options.  There are some assumtions made by the developers, if you have a computer today it will be able to play everything from 2009 on max.  They have some distance and shadow options for slower computers.  Fine assumption for a port, I'm not complaining - graphics are amazing compared to the original.Overall - great port/remake.  Lots of new stuff to play with, higher difficulty option, amazing graphics that will stun you.  If you have the original, do a comparison just for the wow factor.  I'll give it a solid 8/10.  I'd give it a 9/10 to have my mouse back and a 10/10 if you didn't release it before fixing the bugs.  Although I'm sure they'll get fixed in the near future, I hate paying to beta test.  Recommended to all fans regardlless.  Enjoy the nolstagia.Update - Through the nvidia control panel I increased all the settings to max (had to add the program because it wasn't there originally), enable the option to allow/optimize multiple CPUs and this helped a lot.  I'm now running perfectly with all 8 cores firing.  There is no delay when skipping dialog now and everything is much smoother.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												This game is quite dissappointing.Fable is a classic RPG probably every gamer is familiar with, and it deserves a proper reconstruction, but this is not it. Fable was ahead of its time and as you might expect lacks a number of modern design principles we all know today, but which did not exist back then. There have been a few new features added (mostly just some spells and new armors/weapons), as well as some things taken away, including some plot elements. Beside that, this game is the old Fable + hi comp art + poorly executed KB/mouse control. They haven't done any bug/flaw fixing so your imerssion is just as regularly interrupted by mistakes in the game as it was in Fable for XBOX. The control and combat system is also quite awful. However, they've made the combat easier than ever because the enemies seem tremendously easier to kill and deal far less damage to the player's character. It is pretty much impossible to die, yet they throw extra lives at you like they are going out of style. Frankly they've made what was a fairly entertaining combat system into something unenjoyable and unchallenging. Special points like renown and alignment accumulate much faster than they used to, so they max out shortly after starting the game. So, if you're really not interested in a good, fun game to get into, and you just want to relax and goof off for a while with something graphically-rich, this may be a good option for you. Otherwise, go play the original Fable on XBOX, it is far more satisfying.

content:

												     This game lives up to the original and is so nostalgic for me, its a bonus I only played the core game and not the lost chapters edition so the added/new quests are a treat.      Runs great, however on its highest settings it even has my gtx 980 at 100% usage at 120 fps, but the visuals are very impressive for a remaster.      The game itself can seem short lived even though its probably 30+ hours of grinding to get through the story, but that time goes quickly due to it being so fun. I have yet to try heroic difficulty but a higher setting is something the game has always needed.      Compared to other RPG's this game seems alot more present than say Oblivion or Skyrim, which in their case give you TOO much to do, so it feels overwhelming.      But this seems to be a game that is timeless for me, I always have to make myself quit to save some for later, where most other games eventually you get bored and need a break.     My only issue is playing with a controller it sometimes randomly vibrates. I can ignore it and you have the option to turn it off but I see how it could annoy some people, and to me this is on of those games best enjoyed with a controller.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Fable Anniversary is a prime example of how NOT to handle a re-mastered game. I love the Fable series to death. TLC remains my favorite RPG to date. Some compatibility issues prevent me from playing the original Fable TLC on my PC, so I purchased FA in order to still play it. While the general gameplay is exactly the same, they destroyed everything else. First of all, this was supposed to IMPROVE the graphics: not just add more polygons and change the lighting. The textures are horrible, the models are even worse, and the lighting makes me want to carve out my own eyes. Everything is incredibly dull and grey - the opposite of the original, bright and colorful Fable. What's worse than the graphics is the menu system. At first there was no mouse support for any of the menus. NO MOUSE SUPPORT ON A PC GAME. Okay, it's not THAT big of a deal, right? We can still use the arrow keys and "enter", right? Nope. You use Insert and Delete to navigate. Explain this sh*t to me. They have since updated the game, and we can now use a mouse in the menus. However, they are still the clunkiest, unnecessarily difficult menus I have ever used. This is the worst part of the game being ported from Xbox. All in all, this game is the worst console port I have ever played. It's literally a port of a port, and it shows. I'll still play it because it's Fable, but as usual I'm quite irritated with Micro$oft and Lionhead Studios. If you're going to continue milking this franchise, how about you give us something we want: like FABLE F*CKING 2 FOR PC.

The morality logic is still messed up in the intro, I got positive karma(and a thank you from the barrel guy) for breaking the barrels. For comparison, the in-development alpha games(ie kenshi) I bought in steam are more complete than this, and some are new developers. The launch day of watchdogs ran flawlessly compared to this remake, and it's graphics are leaps and bounds more complicated. I've been a PC gamer since the 90s, I understand launch day is going to have bugs. But this is the worse I've seen, maybe ever. If you want to play this game, save some money and get the lost chapters.

content:
Posted: March 5
												Only 1.4 hours with this version, but nearly 60 on the one I owned on my old computer (may it rest in pieces), so I can say now what I thought about the game then:The tl;dr version is simply: funny little game with a lot of wasted potential.Much longer version: I bought the lost chapters edition some years ago, played through it a few times as both good and evil characters, and mainly enjoyed my time. However, the game always seemed to be missing something, and with this new version, I realized what it was. Unlike many of the other RPGs I've played over the years, Fable never gave me this sense of nostalgia or longing to play it ever again once I deleted it off my older computer and put the box on the shelf.Fast forward to now, and the feeling remains the same. Sure, it's still a funny little game with some great moments to it, but I don't feel the same sense of wanting to play for hours at a time that I have with others in the genre. I've likely gotten spoiled with more modern games, but that's not just it. Fable always seems to hit a point where it is just on the edge of being a truly great game, but then falls short in far too many areas.My biggest gripe is with the alleged improvement in graphics. My computer is not a monster rig, but it plays most games well at high specs. With Fable Anniversary, I've had to mess with far too many things to get it to run properly in the manner in which it is supposed to be played. I can run it, but not at ultra-high specs, and that's just stupid for a game that's now eleven years old.The second gripe is with the combat, which was always my problem with the original version. The lock-on is terrible, especially when there are several enemies on the field of battle, which can lead to quick deaths if not properly managed in the first place. With the bad camera slinging around like a loose sail on a schooner during a hurricane, boss battles involving fast enemies can be nearly impossible to finish without dying numerous times, even on easier difficulties. The biggest problem, though, is when the battle is over...every time a dead enemy drops an orb, there's a really good chance that it will end up in a spot where you can't get to it (say, in a non-accessible water source), so you lose that power-up that round, even with the button that allows you to essentially vacu-suck them towards you.Finally, I just wish what had been improved had extended to more than just the graphics. Some new music would have been nice (all of it gets so bedamned redundant after the six thousandth repeat that I have to turn it off eventually), some re-voicing of the more squeaky little brats would have done my ears a favor, and some of the quests were just so dumb that I'd play them evil just to amuse myself.Fable was, for many, a failure because it never delivered on the developers' promises. I wouldn't have gone that far, but there was too much wasted potential for me to able to recommend it to any but those who enjoyed the game initially. New players will likely hate Fable, with all its improved graphics, and with good reason. It just doesn't stack up to more modern RPGs, from any country.

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Bad Port, Terrible Controls, Same Old GameFable: The Lost Chapters was a wonderful game, but if you've already played it, you've already played this. This is nothing more than a high res texture/shader pack for Fable: TLC. This is not a full scale remake, leaving audio, animations and engine untouched. The character have been given higher detailed and higher resolution models, but they are stuck on the same old skeletons and use the same old animations. The worst offender are characters' eyes, which like the original game, still do not move. It looked weird 10 years ago, and it looks even weirder now. With the more realistic looking characters, with the old robotic movements, dead unmoving eyes, it really does give you the feeling of being trapped in some sort of fun house animatronic hell. The faces of the characters also feels like a downgrade from TLC, while they are higher resolution, most of the characters have rather ugly faces, and look a lot more generic than in TLC, losing a lot of their cartoonish look which gave them life in the first place.It's also a bad port directly from Xbox, with absolutely no attempt at making PC controls. This game is practically unplayable with a mouse and keyboard, even if that's how you typically played Fable: TLC in the past. In-game controls can be remapped (only once in game, NOT in the main menu) but all UI controls are ripped straight from xbox, meaning you have to type "A" "B" "X" "Y" on your keyboard in order to interact with the menus, and there is no option within the game to remap these. Other control flaws exist such as needing to press "Insert" and "Delete" to go to different pages in your inventory/journal.As for the environments and lighting changes, all is not well either. While a lot of the houses and scenery do look better with more detail than in TLC, the lighting kills the experience in a lot of places. They have in places put in some new real time lighting effects, but these are very localised. They look good if you are directly in that spot (in front of a fireplace for example) but look really out of place if you are viewing them from afar in an overall scene. You end up having a scene that is primarily ambient lighting, with a few spots of real time lighting that completely look out of place with the environment. You will end up with scenes like the Oakvale raid at the beginning of the game, where the scene is tinted heavily red, but the shadows and real time light sorces remain unshaded. It's hard to explain, but it ends up just looking very WRONG, like a badly photoshopped image.If this was a fan made free overhaul mod for the original game, or a forum collaboration (which is what it feels like) I would really be on board with all this, as a work in progress. But this is not fan made, this game had a team behind it and a budget. It is not free, it costs more than a lot of better games on steam at full price. And it is certainly not a work in progress, this is as good as it gets. And it's certainly far from good.

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Lengthy review ahead; skip to bottom for TL;DR version.The review:* General stuff: Alright, so in a PC port, they excluded a few rather *key* items. Obviously, the first major item on this list is mouse support in menus. However, you still CAN navigate the menus using the keyboard's arrow keys + 'A'/'B' keys for selection/back button. Although it's rather annoying, it IS there... so, there's that.* Options: The other thing that got to me before I even got into game was the (lack of?) options for graphics. You can set a few basic options from low, medium, or high. Basically, there's really no graphical options for the game. That being said, for a port from a game that was based on Xbox 360 graphics, I really cannot complain. Is it better than the original? Of course. Is it modern PC graphics? No, not by a long shot. But hey, it's a port. It's not like they went out and hired an entire staff of PC programmers for this single game (I wish, though).* Bugs/glitches: Well, again, for a port it's kind of 'to-be-expected'. Honestly, I'm kind of surprised about how many people are talking about this specifically. Does Darksouls get a bad rating because it natively cannot render 1080p, or display text/textures in HD? No. Everyone goes and downloads DSFix and then stops complaining. I really feel like this is something that people spend too much time on. I found that if I let the game load (e.g. I sat there for a few minutes), it would load the entire level and I'd continue without any disturbance of FPS issues. Later in the game this became extremely uncommon and within 4 hours of playing, I stopped experiencing this issue altogether. Other than a few brief run-ins with a laggy screen, I didn't experience any downsides of 'programming' on their behalf. (Note: I do have a gaming PC, I don't know if that makes a difference when experiencing these issues...)* Overview: Overall, it still feels like the same Fable I played years ago. The dialouge is the same (whether you decide that's good/bad is up to you, I didn't even care that it wasn't HD... you really can't tell, stop ♥♥♥♥♥ing), so the story still really hits home. Everything you used to do? You can still do it. With the exception of some really broken exploits, of course. I was still easily able to navigate the game in my old manner; I had a Master Katana within the first hour (first few quests), and by the middle of the game (before Arena), I was donating hundreds-of-thousands- to the Temple of Avo for all the glory they could bestow onto me. Buy/Sell schemes still work on merchants, the house buying/selling still works, etc... it's pretty much all there. I didn't ever try the time-stop glitch, but only because I didn't need it due to buying/selling Emeralds in Oakvale (honestly why would you need to stop time when you can buy anything?).* Combat: Alright, so I've been playing the whole game (yes, I completed Fable + TLC content) with a F310 Logitech controller. Honestly, combat is a little awkward, at first; having to hold 2 buttons (L2 trigger for lockon; R1 bumper for blocking) + pushing 'X' to attack, + rolling the thumbsticks for directional/camera changes is a BIT much, but after all, it's Fable... You can stop pretending you have to block attacks after you purchase Plate armor and upgrade your Health/Toughness. It becomes less hectic and becomes kind of mundane, but that's how the original one was as well (about to attempt Heric Mode), so again, I cannot complain. Magic use is a bit frustating too, as by default you can only have ONE magic spell readily castable. The way you cycle through them is R2 trigger + 'B', which becomes slow if you have a lot of spells and sometimes, you over-rotate spells and have to re-cycle through them just for the one you wanted... sometimes, in combat. Not fun.* Other Thoughts: I pre-ordered this game, so I was given Scythe's Pack for free. The items it added are interesting and, to say the least, are fun to mess around with. They are not game-breaking and give no edge over someone who does not purchase the pack. Again, I played this game with a F310 Logitech controller and found it rather easy to control after a while of getting used to the controls. I played my first play-through on Normal mode and plan to play again on Heroic and go for 100%.TL;DR version:* I do recommend this game, but remember, it is a port and is not designed for the PC. Please, do not hold it to the same expectations as a newly released PC game. Also, if you happen to encounter some of *many* bugs/glitches, instead of complaining and whining, maybe contact Lionhead support and let them know? Help them fix the problem so we can all enjoy the game. Use a controller for the gameplay, it'll make your life easier. Enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Fable Anniversary is the exact same game as Fable: The Lost Chapters (a great game) with somewhat improved graphics. Well, almost exactly the same... Technically they changed the menu layouts. Unfortunately, not for the better.    It's pretty clear that this wasn't intended to be released for the PC originally. This new version is NOT mouse friendly. Unless you use a controller you'll have to rely heavily on the keyboard for most things, which I personally find frustrating; when there are a lot of things that would be much simpler if I could use a mouse. This isn't the only issue with the Anniversary version of Fable either.    The picture looks blurry and washed out on the PC. There is a fix that resolves this issue completely, but it involves some very minor editing of a couple game files. It's fairly simple, but shouldn't be necessary.    As stated though; textures, faces, and such are improved noticeably. A couple of the faces (like the hero as a kid and Maze's) look a bit odd to me though. The only reason to get version is if you really want a the modestly improved graphics and the added outfits & weapons in the DLC. Just be prepared to deal with the mouseless menus and to fix those files I mentioned to clear the picture.

I've almost completed the game with every side quest done, and I haven't found any of the issues people are talking about:- Gamebreaking bugs. Not seen any at all. The camera controls are almost exactly as it was in the original Fable, which I played extensively as a child and had no complaints with. Maybe new people to the game aren't so happy with this? But it seems absolutely fine and easily playable. I was using an Xbox controller to play, and it works seemlesly.Not worth the full price, but it was on sale for £5 and so I definitely recommend it if you can grab it on a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Played Fable on Xbox originally. Played through the pc Version whith lost chapters included, Played fable 2 and 3 on xbox 360, and now the remastered version of fable also including the lost chapters and completely redone graphically. The game is still great. I have played through 2 times on Anniversary and collected everything possible so its sad to say there is no longer anything to accomplish after the time i have put in. If you originally enjoyed fable on xbox and more specifically you played the pc version this one controls much the same. A little wonky with the mouse but you can get used to it easily in an hour or so. The character model for the main heros face looks kind of weird in the remastered version. The new additions to fable anniversary are Hero mode and the dlc. Hero mode is fable hard mode. There are more enemies they seem to be more agressive and harder to kill. This is also particularely noted with the bosses. That being said you can do whatever you want in fable so you can get quite good weapons and armour right from the start depending on your strategy. Also noted in hero mode there are no resurection phial which means instead you will be given 1 health potion where a phial would be. The shopkeepers also hold very little health and mana potions and mana is consumed alot faster when using magic abilities. Having played alot of fable in the past the hard mode was not really much more hard and it just meant that it took a bit longer to accomplish objectives . Unless you really like fable this is where i would recommend this game. Also unless you are really into cosplay in fable i would not recommend the dlc as the weapons and armour are not adding much to your experience.

content:

												The original Fable holds a place in my heart, and the idea of a HD remaster of this game should have been a pleasant, nostalgic experience. However, due to clunky programming, thrown together UI, frequent clipping issues and overall lazy efforts on behalf of the developement team, this game is only a glimps of what it could have been. The core game is still in tact, and just as enjoyable (and recommended) but the original has had a lot more love put into it and is more deserving of your money.Fable remains a very enjoyable experience, and worthy of multiple playthroughs. Either version is worth picking up, as the remasters pros are equalled by it's cons. Pick this up if you're a hardcore fan or if it's on sale, otherwise the original remains cheaper and more authentic.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Ok, so they have released a patch to fix some of the issues. The UI is still broken however. You still can't navigate though the menus with a mouse, nor can you reassign the (stupid) menu keys.  You can map more of the keys (note thats STILL "more" not "all"). While trying to reassign the keys to something a little more sane I discovered you can't map anything to ctrl or alt, and that left shift and right shift are treated as the same key.  also the ' key is forbidden for keyboard mapping.  No idea why, it just "is". Oh, and "accept" and "back" are still hardcoded to "A" and "B".  Nice first try, now how about giving us a patch that actually FIXES the issues we're all complaining about.-- ORIGINAL REVIEW STARTS HERE --I wanted to like this game, I really did. I even played it past the intro level (which has an annoying about of cutscenes) in the hope I'd get used to the UI and controls. But this has to be the worst port I have ever had the misfortune to pre-purchace.  The User Interface is horrible, the "new" graphics are nothing much (and some of the "new" faces are appalingly ugly).  This is a quick and dirty port of a console version rather than a PC version.  How quick and dirty?  The "A" and "B" buttons from the joystick have been assigned to the "A" and "B" keys on the keyboard so they didn't have to change anything else.  Half the keys (and as far as I can tell, all the mouse commands) cannot be redefined, some of the special moves (flaunt, first person perspective when using a bow) either don't work at all, or work so sporadically as to be unusable. Quest markers for secondary missions are either missing or randomly vanish (and so do some guard quest NPC's, don't tell someone to wait then go kill bandits, you'll come back to find they have vanished and the quest is now unplayable).If there was a reasonable way to hand this back for a refund I'd be at the head of the queue.  Until they release a patch for at least the UI and quests, I'd advise leaving this alone and trying the older "fable lost levels" instead.  It's cheaper, and apparantly has a UI that actually works.

												This game seems to be getting a lot of bad reviews, but my experience has been nothing but positive. I haven't encountered a single bug, glitch or crash, if the game had problems they've apparently worked them. I've already got over 50 hours into it and I'm already looking forward to a second playthrough. As I said, I never played the original so I can’t say how much difference there is, but if you haven’t played it than it’s definitely worth the money in my opinion.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												In short: This is a great game. Any bugs or glitches that were there, are no longer there so don't worry about that when purchasing this game. It has a great storyline, one of the best combat systems, a huge arsenal of weaponry/spells, and a great system for customizing your character.Storymode: The storymode in the game is one of my all time favorites in rpg's. Getting scarred as a child, then living a life where you thirst for revenge. And like every story, when seeking revenge, betrayal is not far behind.Combat Style: I've played a lot of rpg's and this is a combat style that I wish more fantacy rpg's will focus on. You can easily organize your massive library of spells to work with your combat when needed. Unlikeother games I found this one a lot easier to defend myself against enimies, yet still gave me a challenge if I wasn't paying enough attention.Character Customization: As you play the game you begin to aquire more clothing/armour, as well find some tattoo parlours/hairsalons. With clothing you can mix and match or easily set it to the presets. Each set of clothing not only helps you with your armour, but with how you look to other npc's, Rather you're trying to attract a babe, or scare a gaurd the Algorythm in doing so is very simple to understand. When it comes down to tattoo/hairstylists, there are several locations in doing so. Each location has different styles, and certain artists don't have a stationary building so you are able to go on a random walk in the woods and end up getting a haircut and a new tattoo along the way. Bugs and Glitches: I didn't buy the game when it first came out so my following statement is how the game is currently. Mind you I 100% the game so I was still able to experience everything, and I'm not reviewing this whilst I'm in the middle of the game. The only bugs that I did get are the following: Getting stuck between two objects, when this happened I simply tp'd out and continued on (This happened only once through my entire play through). Near the end of the game I tried to kill an enemy with my sword and when doing so my game crashed, I resolved this problem by killing him with my bow instead. After doing so I had 0 problems with that quest and at no other point did I have that problem. After I 100% the acievments I was awarded the achivment via game but I wasn't via steam. Which is frustraiting but nothing to cry over. In simple terms the game has very minimal bugs, all of which were easily resolved.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												I loved Fable TLC and have played it at least 4 times over the years.  When I heard about Fable Anniversary and saw some of the preview pics I made a point to pre-order.  That was a mistake.The graphics are largely better than Fable TLC, but still underwhelming.  On close up the hero's hair looks bad, and Whisper's looks even worse.  There's odd lighting around the hair and face of the models.  The hero's eyes look dead - totally a 2 dimensional surface.  You can see this in TotalBiscut's review at about the 11:25 mark.  The eyes in TLC by comparison look much better (which you can also see in his video).  There is a bit of a blur over everything and some of the ambient occlusion looks pretty bad.  There's already user-made .ini tweaks on the Steam forums to deal with some of these issues and using them does provide some improvement.The real problem is the horrible controls.  There is no mouse control for the game menus and the keyboard controls are nonsensical.  They literally mapped the A, B, and Y keys of the Xbox 360 controller to the A, B, and Y keys of the keyboard to manipulate many of the menu functions in the game.  I've never seen the B key used to manipulate menus in a game before.  It's not a great innovation.The inventory screen is completely changed from TLC's for the worse.  To do anything inventory related in this version you start with the Insert and Home keys to navigate tabs, then use the Delete and End keys to navigate sub-tabs, then switch to the arrow keys to navigate lists and sub-lists, then the A key wear, equip, or bind something, then B to exit out.  Sometimes Esc will get you back directly to the game, sometimes not.  It's really clunky.  The layout itself has a ton of wasted screen space on colors, tabs, and subtabs with only a small amount of screen real estate devoted to actually display the items you are carrying.There is no mouse sensitivity adjustment.  When I first started playing in Oakvale just turning the camera was strikingly jarring.  I don't know why, I just finished Skyrim a few weeks ago and had no issue with swinging the camera around in that game, but here in Fable Anniversary I found it terribly jarring visually.  I thought maybe turning down the mouse sensitivity would help...but there's no way to do that.  Maybe this is just a personal thing that I'll get used to.The oddness of combining orb gathering and spell use on the left shift still persists and is just as troublesome as it was in the original.  Blocking and dodging are on the middle mouse button.  Maybe that was fine 9 years ago when I played with a gaming mouse that actually had a middle mouse button, but today I have a scroll wheel there and that scroll wheel button is a terrible way to control such critical functions like block and dodge.  It's not as sensitive and fairly uncomfortable.There is some key remapping available once you have loaded a game, but critical keys (like the A and B use to navigate the menus, attack, block, dodge, etc.) cannot be remapped.  I wish I could remap dodge and block to some of the other mouse buttons on my Death Adder 2013, but that's not possible.  Exiting game is probably the worst I've seen in any PC game in years.  You hit Esc, then A to select save game, arrow keys to choose a save slot, A to save, B to go back to the menu, hit the arrow down key 4 or 5 times to select Quit, A to quit, wait for a loading screen to the main menu, hit the arrow down key 7 or 8 times to select exit to Windows, hit A to exit. Every.Single.Time.You.Quit.The.Game.  In 2014 it should be substantially easier to save and quit a computer game.Some of these control issues can be mitigated by using an Xbox 360 controller.  I happen to have one and tried it but I thought the quick menu to access the many expressions and inventory items to be atrocious.  There is no key remapping for either of the 2 controller layout options.To sum up: I'm disappointed.  I expected better graphics.  For regular (non menu) gameplay the keyboard/mouse controls aren't too bad or too changed from the original but they certainly weren't updated or improved.  The inventory menu layout is overly complicated and the menu controls are abysmal.  It all works, mind you.  It's all functional.  But it's not very well done and absolutely mars a really great game.As for stability, I've only played a little over 2 hours and haven't had any stuttering or other visual issues being reported on Steam forums.  No crashes either.  I have an i7-3770, 8 GB RAM, and an Nvidia GTX 770.I wish I had waited for this come on sale on Thanksgiving or maybe Christmas. I still love Fable and still think it's a great game, but Fable Anniversary did not live up to expectations.  There's a really great game underneath the clunky interface and inventory menu system.  It's a shame that Fable Anniversary didn't really polish up Fable TLC and really make the game shine.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Fable: The Lost Chapers, was one of my favourite games as a child. When I heard about Fable Anniversary, I bought it withotut expecting much; I thought it would just be a HD remaster. Maybe fix some of the glitches. What I got was:+ Improved shading.+ Improved sound qualityImproved texture resolution and models, though the faces are all hideous.- Interface that's about as user-friendly as forks being jammed under your toenails.- No mouse control in menus.- HORRIBLY clunky camera that seems to have trouble going around corners without jumping around.- Sound cutting off and crackling whenever it feels your headset and/or ears aren't being tortured enough.- Random Crashes- Combined key commands that shouldn't have been combined- such as dodge/rolling- Not being able to edit all of the controls without digging around in the filesFable Anniversary is not worth the $35 price tag. The original Fable:TLC is superior in every way, unless you put graphics over gameplay. The graphical improvments are not enough to make up for the technical trainwreck that is Fable Anniversary. This is a shoddy port that simply feels unfinished. Alot of work has to be put into it before I would consider it supeior to the classic in any way.

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												My sympathies to anyone that shelled out the £27 for this game expecting a quality remake. Let this be a lesson to us all.This remake has been designed for a console and not PCs and the shoddy porting does not justify the price tag. Porting a console game for PCs and not redesigning the control interface to take advantage of the versitility of keyboards is just outright lazy. The developers should be ashamed.The simplified interface is a big problem. My impression is they designed it to be attractive instead of functional. Menus do not support mice and are awkward to navigate.Another couple of flaws with this game are hard-coded keybinds and non-reprogrammable key functions. First off they are scattered all over the keyboard [Menu navigation keys especially]. Secondly if you are using directional keys you will find that a lot of the neighboring keys cannot be rebound. Unless you are born with a third, usuable arm it is difficult to use the controls effectively.Lastly, for a game that is focused around cosmetic improvements it does not offer much fine-tuning for the graphics. It offers very few options [Which is a huge problem for lower-end computers, since minimal settings are still overstrained by the games poor optimization]. The only way to modify specific graphical features is to root around the files and modify configs. Players should NEVER have to do this.I have no found no notable qualities that makes this game superior to the original Fable.P.S - You can take your enforced Depth of Field and Bloom and shove it up your asses. If I wanted those on all the time I would just save my GPU the trouble and smear grease on my screen. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Fable is one of my favorite game series of all time. If you liked the original, picking up the remaster is a no-brainer. It's funny how little it seems upgraded until you fire up the old version and are reminded how old it actually is. The graphics are actually MUCH better now, not just in terms of poly count and textures, but also in the lighting and post processing. Fable probably won't play well on a keyboard and mouse. I have always just used a controller on my PC to play it. The 360 version works great. I love that they also ported over the control scheme from Fable 2 and 3 so you select either that or the classic Fable controller setup. Now, Lionhead: WHERE IS FABLE 2 FOR THE PC?!?!

number of helpful: 25 of 49 people (51%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												This remake is a bit of a disappointment. The graphics, like lighting, models, and textures, look better. However, they have made the interface worse! It is not a PC interface, by any stretch of the imagination; the menus are built with controllers in mind. You even use the A key to select menu options, and PAGE UP/PAGE DOWN and HOME/END to navigate through the menus. Ridiculous!I have myself noticed a bit of dodgy mouse control when moving the camera. It lags a bit, and it seems to be certain predetermined positions the camera "nodges into" when you stop the movement. Not very smooth at all.The rest of the game is just as the original Fable: The Lost Chapters, but the better graphics does not really make up for the worse interface.The game does however perform very good. I get almost constant 144+ FPS on my GTX 670.

number of helpful: 28 of 55 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I never had the opportunity to play the original, but heard so much praise for the series over the years that when I saw this I jumped at the chance, and I'm glad I did! It's certainly a little dated and clunky in places, but that's to be expected from a game originally from 2004.The graphics look great, and from what I've seen of the original, are a huge improvement. It runs at a steady 60-120fps and fully supports 1080p-4K. I've been running it on a 1920x1080 screen, but downsampling from 4K using GeForce DSR, so it looks very nice.I've been playing with a 360 controller and it works perfectly. Havn't tried M+KB much, but they seem to be well supported.I havn't finished the game yet, but I've enjoyed every moment of it so far; a well-rounded RPG that gives you quite a lot of freedom in how you tackle quests. Coupled with the traditional British Lionhead humour and passion, good & evil choices, and addictive gameplay, it's a lot of fun!
