content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												I played this on Xbox when it first came out and absolutley loved it (I never could get into Fable 2 or Fable 3, though my kids played them a lot). I thought I would purchase this for myself and have a go at it to see if I could rekindle the old adoration. Nope, it's just not there. Despite the facelift, this game hasn't aged well. If you have never played it then perhaps you will enjoy it, but the game simply can't live up to the memories for me. The graphics are dated, I am having all kinds of problems aiming with the left stick with the bow (Too used to right thumbstick now), and dungeons that repopulate with the same monsters once you have cleared them, had me uninstalling after a few hours. There are better dungeon romps out there and for me, this one is better left in the past.It does have it's charm, and maybe for some younger gamers, it might still have enough oomph to draw you in. It's not a terrible game by any means. Give it a go if you have never played it, and judge for yourself.6.5/10

												It seems like a lot of people who have reviewed this game poorly either played the game before the implementation of the newest patches or were expecting the game to be on the visual level of fable III. content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												I feel a little bad giving this a thumbs-down, because I don't strongly dislike it... but I probably wouldn't give it above about a 7.5/10, and to me, that deserves a thumbs down. I never played the original Fable games myself, but I remember seeing friends play them and they looked like they'd be a lot of fun, so when this went on sale a few weeks ago, I thought, "Hey, I should check this out!"In some ways, I'm glad I did. I got 25 solid hours out of it, for $8.74—which is not great, but is also not bad. But then I hit a wall. I'm the kind of person who has to get all the achievements in every game I play. I played WoW for, like, three or four months (most of it during Mists of Pandaria) and got about 85% of the achievements that the entire game had to offer, to give you an idea of how I play games. And for most of the game, Fable was working just fine.But once I beat the game on the standard difficulty, I ran into some problems. There were a couple missing achievements (like beating Whisper without getting hurt) that I hadn't even noticed in time to get them on my original playthrough, so I figured I could just go through on Heroic and take care of those. I got that one, but found around the same time that hitting three enemies with a single flourish is essentially impossible to do on purpose, and I hadn't had it happen on accident throughout my entire Normal run. Likewise, there was the achievement for getting all the hero dolls that seems like it's going to be nearly impossible to do, without just sinking hours and hours into it in hopes of getting lucky. That's not how achievements should work, I'd say.And then there's Heroic difficulty. It started out just fine. I got through the training, ventured out to Bowerstone, did the first few quests, and then tried to make my way through Greatwood Lake. First I ran into an Earth Troll. "Uh oh," I thought. "This could be pretty difficult to beat on Heroic." But with some careful dodging, I took it down—only to run into three bandits who had such an incredibly high amount of health that I couldn't even take *one* down with ALL of my MP into lightning AND all the crossbow firing I could get out before they caught up to me and killed me.Now, I don't think I'm bad at this game. I made it through Normal without EVER dying. But I tried this same spot of Heroic three or four times and had the same result each time, despite gaining some experience from each of the failed attempts before dying, and then using it to boost some of my stats. I would have had to spend an inordinate amount of time grinding experience to just get past three random bandits in Greatwood Lake, much less that first Balverine you come across in the swamp area. This seems like poor scaling to me, and essentially made me quit the game.It wasn't the only thing that pushed me in that direction, though. I thought the Good/Evil system was pretty good for a while. I went through all of Normal trying to make the most Good decisions possible, because I'm a good little boy. Then I found out that Good players just don't get as many options or as much good stuff as Evil players. It's quite limited, and I object to that design as well.All in all, this game does have quite a few things going for it, and it has an overall enjoyable game style. That's why I'd give it about a 7.5/10. But no higher.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												Not as good as Fable 1 & 2, but still a good game. I'm just gonna list the cons,1. The difficulty, dont play on the easy mode, you are practically immortal(with potions ofc). I didnt die once in a full playthrough. I never failed a mission once either.2. Optimization/Graphics, well its HD, it does look good. But, some animations lag. My system should be able to run 4 instances of this game at the same time. Dont get me wrong, its not a constant lag or anything, just some animations do lag, so I guess it isnt completly optimized.3. The interaction with NPCs, for example, if you want to have sex with your SO you'll have to court him/her alot. Then get married. Then court them again alot more before you can have sex. I dont really play games like Fable for the static 15 second moaning and a black screen, but still. And particulary Lady Grey, you have to court here like a million times. Literally.4. The short gameplay, mainquests took about 6 hours for me. In 13 hours I completed all sidequests aswell, including the 2 godly weapons you get from the 'good' and the 'bad' worshippers. I didnt get all Demon Doors and Silverkey-chests though, so I guess you can add 1-2 more hours if you include those.5. The money-making method, for obvious reasons, I'm not gonna say it here and spoil your potential gameplay, but did they really think this through, spend 1 "skillpoint" and be able to resell everything right after you bought it to gain gold? Thats uncool. But then again, you dont have to use it.6. Lack of buildings that you can buy. Also, you cant decorate your houses manually.7. Gear, the lack of diversity is absolutely ridiculous. The best weapons and armors is available for you after 10 minutes of gameplay. It doesnt matter that the town you start in has supereasy surroundings and the last places you visit has semi-powerfull enemies, they sell the same gear, for the same prices. Some items cant be bought, but only found through secret quests, which is a good thing.8. The controls, dont play this with your keyboard+mouse. This game, as all Fable-games, is designed to play with a controller.9. The story, its just dumb and dull. I'll shorten it alot so I dont spoil it. Someone kills your family. You get training to become super OP. Your joruney to seek out revenge on your familys assassins begins. No more, no less.I bought the game on Steam summersale 2016 for €5(+ €4 more for the DLCs). If Fable Anniversary was my first Fable game, I would give a bad rating, because Fable Anniversary isnt any more than a mediocre game to be honest. But as I've played the other games and really loved them, I'm able to see behind the flaws. Im glad I bought it at a saleprice. If you're a fan of RPGs, its a must-buy, but dont expect alot of it. If RPGs isnt your niche, dont get it.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												This game doesn't hold up very well.  I loved it when the original came out, but playing it now I realize how pathetically basic it actually is.  I got a laugh out of one of the achievements called "Definitely Not on Rails".  It's as if the devs were responding to very rational criticism about how linear the game is by throwing in that passive-aggressive jab.  There are tons of awful game mechanics that haven't changed a bit since the original.  In fact, nothing has changed outside of the HD textures from what I can tell.  The map and fast travel system are awful.  It's amazing with so few choices how easy it is to get lost.  The Quest Area system seems super bugged to me.  You can't leave a quest area without reloading a previous saved game.  Anyway, you get the gist.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												This game fails on so many levels and I could not honestly recommend that any serious PC gamers buy this game until it has some serious patches and enhancements made to it.Firstly, IT IS THE MOST BLATANTLY OBVIOUS CONSOLE PORT I'VE EVER SEEN.> The Main Menu does not have mouse support.> Key rebindings can only be accessed in-game, and not through the main menu.> Key rebindings are extremely limited, with hard-locked keys for certain things, and dual functionality keys.> The key rebindings were far more extensive, customisable and USEFUL in Fable: The Lost Chapters.> The in-game Inventory/Quest/etc. menu also lacks mouse support, and is terribly designed for a PC game - with poor use of real-estate, bad structure, etc.Secondly, THIS BARELY EVEN QUALIFIES AS A REMAKE.> It is a HD remaster at best.> Some graphics options that were available in Fable: The Lost Chapters are mysteriously missing in Fable Anniversary, namely Anti-aliasing (I believe Fable Anniversary is hard-locked to some sort of FXAA  - which results in the game looking like a blurry, murky mess).> The only real improvements that I can make out are texture improvements, some mesh improvements (though I was expecting a little better, especially for characters faces), and some nice shadows/post-processing effects.> Due to the lack of a decent and accessible anti-aliasing, I actually find Fable: The Lost Chapters more aesthetically pleasing, because the image is sharper and not as murky or blurred.> On my 16:10 (Native Resolution 1440x900) monitor regular gameplay (not just cutscenes) also has thick black lines at the top and bottom of the screen. I am uncertain as to whether or not this is intentional, and whether or not 16:9 monitors get this as well.All in all, this is a terrible PC port. It needs a decent bit of work before I could honestly recommend it.Totalbiscuit (the YouTube Channel host) also did a good video outlining some flaws of the game and comparing it to Fable: The Lost Chapters.P.S: If you are an Australian citizen like I am, and you are unhappy with this purchase, I believe you can ask for a refund if you have played less than 14 hours of the game. Under Australian law the vendor is REQUIRED to provide you with as refund if the product is not deemed 'Fit for Purpose', which I would argue it is not, as it does not fulfil it's purpose of being a fully functional PC game.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												I'm not going to write a conventional review on this game but I will leave my thoughts after playing it for about an hour.WARNING: This will be a rant in most places, but I will do my best.What I liked:- The Nostalgia: This is the reason I bought the game, and in most places, it delivered, at least aesthetically.- The Graphics: This is a bit of a double-edged sword... They look impressive enough (certainly an upgrade) but there are issues.What I disliked:- The Voice Acting: This is only a small point I suppose, but something miffed me about it... Much of this has remained from the original game, which is fine, absolutely fine, but the very first opening cutscene seems to have been re-recorded or remastered or they've done something to it, and it sounds terrible. The actor does not sound enthusiastic about this heroic tale that is about to unfold, and not only that, the sound quality is awful. Not sure if it's a problem on my end but it wasn't terrific, and for an opening cutscene I would expect something to excite me about indulging in my nostalgia and playing one of my favourite childhood games again, but in HD - the concept grabbed me and I threw my wallet at them, I really wish I hadn't now and spent it on something else, and I will explain why in the next point.- The Menu, Inventory, etc......... : I have no idea who designed this menu, but I do not think they were human. It is just so fiddly, so much so that it irritates me too much to even want to play the game. You can assign things, sure, but doing that takes some real jiggery-pokery, a little too much if you ask me. It's like trying to crack the da vinci code, when all I want is to eat an apple pie from my potions and produce tab. It has NO MOUSE OPTIMISATION. This is the big one everyone is talking about and I feel it needs to be heard. The original game had perfectly fine mouse optimisation. To call the game a HD remake and not have mouse optimisation is absolutely mind blowing to me. I know HD more so focuses on the graphics, but if its a testament to the original, I would expect everything to be in place that was originally, such as being able to use your mouse to select things in a menu... When I loaded the game up I was all excited to get stuck in, but my heart sank when I tried to use my mouse and realised I could not. That was the point where I realised that this would be a bad port, and it was from the very start.- The Options Menu: You are able to keybind some things... When you actually get into the game, mind you. But not the attack function, block function or anything important... The controls are fine for me, as I said previously. I can get on with them fine, it's a perfect setup for me. But for other people that's probably not the case, it's definitely something that should be there, why? Because Fable: The Lost Chapters had it. You could keybind anything.It's a terrible port at the moment. I really hope that a patch is released to make things easier for people who want to enjoy it on their PCs with a keyboard and mouse. I enjoyed Fable: The Lost Chapters perfectly fine on my PC, in fact I have done at least 4 seperate playthroughs of the game because I enjoyed it that much. This was one of my main childhood games. I feel as if its ruined, all because of this console focus they have gone with. "Play it with a controller" some people are saying - no. Why should I? If you're going to release a PC port of a game, do it right. I play on a PC. If I wanted to play it on a console I'd buy the console version of the game. I don't. The Graphics: As mentioned before, there are issues. Nothing major, the graphics do look okay to me. They didn't exactly blow me away, but they are certainly an upgrade, which I appreciate. I am not technically minded about this kind of thing, so forgive me for my simplistic manner of explaining it. There appears to be blur on some of the models. Yup. It's like blurry textures, and eventually they fade back to being detailed again. Its weird. It's only a small thing, it doesn't bother me that much, but the fact that they can't even get the graphics 100% right and they're calling this HD makes me laugh. Oh yeah, and the graphics options do not give you much freedom to do anything either.At this point I am terribly disappointed and would not recommend to any like-minded PC gamers like myself. If you can enjoy the game with a console controller, fine. You will probably have a blast, but that menu is enough for me to put this game down until it gets fixed, if it gets fixed.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												The game looks okay graphicly (and the game play is the same so far as I can tell) , but the port Is awful! You have to use the arrow keys to navigate the main/ options menus and the "A/B" keys to select things. This shows almost 0 effort to accommodate for PC users at all and tells me that they were too lazy to change the controller schemes over. This IS PC we have mice, let us use them or at least bind "okay" to enter! It does, however have rebindable keys (only one set though) but this will not recognise any extra keys you may have on you mouse or keyboard unlike the old port (also in steam) were you were free to use any extra buttons.on top of this for some unknown reason I was unable to bind to "TAB" ( I only tried the auto targeting[default "Space"] so it may work elsewhere however it seems "TAB" is defaulted to chat which I find disorientating ) it did seem to register the button but just flashed red instead of using it. As for the new graphics, they are fairly good but seem washed out and not as bright as they should. (after some fiddling I found that you can correct this by reducing the gamma) That being said, I do have issue with the character models, they look like there from TF2 (very cartoony) and it ruined the feel of the game for me. To me the game was like Skyrim is now. It was not dark per-say, more rustic and I feel that this is lost in the remake, however this is a personal gripe and not a big issue. As for performance, I run a moderate rig (SSD hard drive and a GTX 660 on a 27 inch 1080p acer monitor) and cranked right up to max I get minor lag (25-34 FPS according to audacity) so I feel the optimisation of the game is good if not great.  All in all I think that it is amazing to think that the OLD port is better than the new one in many ways, the graphics do stand up today too if a bit low res, in my opinion. Its sad to see games like this are still coming out from MAJOR companies In this day and age and they will keep happening if we just ignore poorly designed game ports like this.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												One step forward, 10 steps back pretty much sums up this retexture.Unfortunately this is a rather poor Xbox One port, that removes all of the good aspects of the original Lost Chapters PC version. Mouse functionality is no longer available in menus, instead navigation is controlled though the Home, End, Insert & Delete keys. You then make a selection using the "A" (!?) key.Whilst basic key rebinding is available, the main abilities are locked and cannot be reasssigned - block and dodge are both set to the mouse wheel which makes combat really fiddly for mouse and keyboard. The control scheme was clearly designed for use with an Xbox  controller.  The game seems to use built in FXAA that cannot be toggled off, which gives the game a blurry, unfocused look hiding a large amount of the  higher resolution textures.Until large improvements are patched into this game, save your money and play the arguably much better original that was actually designed to be played on the PC.

												I want to, oh how do I want to, but I can't write a positive review for this. It runs fine, the graphics are nice, but here's the thing...You don't play a game for graphics, I don't care who you are but if you give a positive review for this game, I'm calling bs. I'll give a few pros and cons that I have encountered in playing this.Pros:Graphics are better than the origional/Lost chapters.DLC stuff (Trust me I'm scraping the bottom of the barrel with these pros for this game)Personal Pro: You can dress up as a guard and beat up people with a Lute, I love that.Personal Pro: It stays true to the story/doesn't add extra bs to an already told story that isn't needed.Now for the Cons:Buggy menus, I cannot tell you how many people I've talked to where its impossible to buy certian items cause, when I press down on my keyboard, it would instantly snap back up. I am forever Chicken Chaser with a normal haircut and normal beard cause of this. Hopefully this will be fixed one day but as for now, not happy. One other thing I nearly forgot, you have to have at least one item in one of the equipment tab if you accedently buy too much and you want to sell a few back. Sell all your sellable items in one of the tabs and you won't be able to get back into it without exiting the traider's menu and retalking to them, which if it was any proof in the origional Fable or The Lost Chapters, they usually decided to talk your ears off before you could talk to them agian, leaving you to simply wave till they shut up.The animations are daited and it shows. Sure, The mouths move more naturally but holy ♥♥♥♥ you have one of those demon children stare at you or one of those really stiff guards talk to you its almost like your in a world filled with robots.Buggy Combat, I found this out fighting wisper and the wasp queen. I would hit wisper several times then suddenly she decided she didn't want to be hurt anymore, actually blocking some strong attacks till I eased up on her and decided to put away then requip my sword, giving her a free hit on me in the process. The wasp queen was a diffrent story, after hitting her several times with my Crossbow, suddenly she was invinceible to it and I couldn't use it anymore, even after unequipping and requpping the crossbow, thank god they start you out with lighting as a spell, though I nearly died to her cause of this. Agian, may be fixed, but I never once got hit in the origional fable unless I made the mistake of trying to block a power shot, or my mana shield went down. Not. Happy.Now I understand that's four pros and Three cons, but keep in mind that two of those Pros are personal and those cons are pretty damn big. Let me put it how I explained to my friends about the Fable franchise.Fable, the origional fable, was a nice girl, and when she told me about The Lost Chapters, she was very "adult" when she talked about it, we still call eachother sometimes, but we've moved on.Fable two was the kind of party girl, the perfect girlfriend who had everything almost completely perfect, even with how she ended. we still hang out on weekends and she still knows I LOVE the blunderbuss/Greataxe combo and her jokes never fall flat for me.Fable three is the girl that forced me to play by her rules with her guns and weapons, a cruel woman who would usually tell me I have to be evil to get the most out of my weapons. I told her no, we don't talk anymore.I have never met Fable Journey, so I will not say anything about her till I have.Fable Anniversary is a tart that trys to act like Fable, saying that she's better looking. Sure, she's better looking, but she acts way too much like Fable that, honestly, it makes me sad that I decided to actually buy her things thinking that she would also act better when its quite clear she doesn't. I'm not planning on talking to Anniversary and I'm going to talk with Fable.TL;DR I am an idiot and I do not like this game, buy the origional fable, fall in love with Fable two, but don't buy three or Anniversary. If you really wanna try it, get it as a gift, you'll feel less like you waisted your money if you do.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												I was never much of a fan of the sequals, however the first Fable and its expansion will always be one of my favorite games, one that i'll never get bored of. When I heard that there was a game that was exactly the same but with a graphics/physics update I thought great! Pre-ordered it without a second though. I've been quite disapointed with it though. Considering the graphics are the ONLY update to the game, which is priced at a hefty £26.99 I was expecting amazing graphics, although the graphics are better than its predesessor, they are by no means impressive. Rocky terrain is still completely smooth, and the game for some reason is quite blurry. Not even close to being worth £26.99. The game is also an obvious console port. You have to use the keyboard to navigate the menu's which can be quite frustrating and you are unable to bind the keys to the mouse, for the price tag its unacceptable and just lazy. I've already had an unrecoverable crash.If you are a die hard Fable fan im sure you will buy this anyway. If you havnt played before, I suggest waiting until the game is at a more reasonable price. In conclusion this is a slight graphics update, with a lazy console port feel and leaves the impression that the developers just wanted to make a bit of easy money from a known title.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												While Fable is a wondeful game, the PC port falls short in a lot of ways. If you're looking to own the game to play it normally, or just bought it to have in your collection like me, i'd highly recommend it. However with that being said, it's version of "Modding" is in fact hardly modding at all. You can supposedly change the art and animation. I say supposedly because the feature to start the game in the editor for me is missing an executable file. The main problems with this game are the counter-intuitive UI and the embelishment that this is going to be modable. Don't get me wrong, wonderful game, fable was my first RPG, and I own this game for multiple consoles. I'm certain the modding community will be able to crack this one wide open, but don't hold your breath for it being any time soon.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												I played and beat the original and then TLC's when they came out so I wasn't really planning on getting this itteration of it until I saw the addition of heroic difficulty. What a bad choice it turned out to be. The first half of the game I found myself questioning if I had really picked "heroic" in the beginning. The only way I knew for sure before I beat it, was the enemies did infact have obsidian & master weapons. That was it, just a visual indication. It's been a long time since I had last played TLC's but I didnt notice a lack of potions, experience, money or even an increase in enemy damage like they said. Im an average gamer when it comes to skill at best and I died a total of 3 times. With a difficulty labeled "Heroic" and described as "(it) will test the mettle of even the most hardcore Fable fan.", you would think it would present some kind of... challenge? Heroic mode was a joke.Other than that, the graphical upgrade was nice for the game imo, aside from the characters faces. And the menus were not intuitive at all. I found myself fumbling through them more than I would have liked. I can't really comment on the keyboard controls as I used a PS3 controller, but aparently those were chosen by throwing darts at keys.Bottom line, I'd stick with the lost chapters or wait for this to go on sale down the road. I personally can't justify spending $35 for this knowing what I know now. In fact I spent only $21 and still regret it. The only thing that might make it worth the current price is if the integrate steamworks support. It's been mentioned but no official word as of yet.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Fable Anniversary offer no noticable improvements over the flawed but charming original. Furthermore, wonky camera, unless alternate views (first person bow mode, WTF where they thinking!?) and totally disfunctional Z-lock style target make arcade style combat, formally Fable's greatest asset into a frustrating mess. The "HD Graphics" offer little noticible improvement over the original, and absolutely no improve over the sequals. And through all of this, the pointless utterly superficial "morality" system remains pointless and utterly superficial. And the barely there story line remains barely there. Countless titles have been released since Fable which actually suceed in doing what Fable tried and failed to do upon release. This remake was the perfact oppurtunity but completely missed oppurtunity to step it up. Instead, what we got was a too little, too late re-release of a 10 year old broken game.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												I'm a huge Fable fan, it was the game that really got me into RPGs and made me fall in love with the genre. I was so excited for the reboot after playing all the different versions dozens of times. The game looks okay...but the characters faces all look very waxy. The menu system doesn't support a mouse. Then you get into the complicated menu system where you must use Ins, Delete, Home and End to navagate through the different categories of items.I got the game for 44% off and the pre-order DLC so I'm not to upset with my purchase, I'm hoping they'll fix it as time goes on. To anyone curious about this game, if you haven't played Fable: The Lost Chapters I highly reccomend that more, but you're a long time Fable fan like myself I would suggest this game during a sale event.TL:DR - Game looks good, better in my opinion (Other then weird character faces), but the menu system will drive you crazy.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												This game fails on so many levels and I could not honestly recommend that any serious PC gamers buy this game until it has some serious patches and enhancements made to it.Firstly, IT IS THE MOST BLATANTLY OBVIOUS CONSOLE PORT I'VE EVER SEEN.> The Main Menu does not have mouse support.> Key rebindings can only be accessed in-game, and not through the main menu.> Key rebindings are extremely limited, with hard-locked keys for certain things, and dual functionality keys.> The key rebindings were far more extensive, customisable and USEFUL in Fable: The Lost Chapters.> The in-game Inventory/Quest/etc. menu also lacks mouse support, and is terribly designed for a PC game - with poor use of real-estate, bad structure, etc.Secondly, THIS BARELY EVEN QUALIFIES AS A REMAKE.> It is a HD remaster at best.> Some graphics options that were available in Fable: The Lost Chapters are mysteriously missing in Fable Anniversary, namely Anti-aliasing (I believe Fable Anniversary is hard-locked to some sort of FXAA  - which results in the game looking like a blurry, murky mess).> The only real improvements that I can make out are texture improvements, some mesh improvements (though I was expecting a little better, especially for characters faces), and some nice shadows/post-processing effects.> Due to the lack of a decent and accessible anti-aliasing, I actually find Fable: The Lost Chapters more aesthetically pleasing, because the image is sharper and not as murky or blurred.> On my 16:10 (Native Resolution 1440x900) monitor regular gameplay (not just cutscenes) also has thick black lines at the top and bottom of the screen. I am uncertain as to whether or not this is intentional, and whether or not 16:9 monitors get this as well.All in all, this is a terrible PC port. It needs a decent bit of work before I could honestly recommend it.Totalbiscuit (the YouTube Channel host) also did a good video outlining some flaws of the game and comparing it to Fable: The Lost Chapters.P.S: If you are an Australian citizen like I am, and you are unhappy with this purchase, I believe you can ask for a refund if you have played less than 14 hours of the game. Under Australian law the vendor is REQUIRED to provide you with as refund if the product is not deemed 'Fit for Purpose', which I would argue it is not, as it does not fulfil it's purpose of being a fully functional PC game.

Like I played Fable a couple months ago and for a console port that game was good. but the Fable anniversary the port is so bad controls are so buggy. to use the menu you need to use A and B key on your keyboard you cant even use your mouse. Trying to change your armour is a pay in the♥♥♥♥♥you have to use HOME and END keys. when really you could of just clicked on the stuff you wanted to use. I also read on the forums they chose not to add mouse  support because they had to choose between modding and mouse support. Im no game expert but seriously??? come on this game is ment to work on pc and the whole thing about pc is to use a MOUSE!So really I would say buy the game when there are mods and the community has fixed the game.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Player character (Hero) is foul as spreadable sin on ugly bread. Not just "oh, he's a bit on the unattractive side" ugly, but "Proof that exorcists should be mandatorily present during child births" ugly. Deal breaker ugly, especially for an RPG like Fable, a quintessential messiah complex simulator.Don't buy until it's either fixed, or some kind soul makes a mod to alleviate this visual train wreck from our sight.Side note:-Broken keyboard+mouse support-*WAY* too expensive for what's on offer, not even courteous enough to include the extra content which they've hidden behind a DLC pay-wall, as if you're not already paying a premium for a retextured 10 year old game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I've been a fan of the Fable series ever since I first played the original, but I can honestly say I'd much rather be playing the Lost Chapters over this "Anniversary" edition. While the overhauled graphics are nice, that's really all it has going for it and personally I think it killed a lot of the charm that the original had. What other improvements the game claims to have like the UI looks pretty good but feels very clunky and unoptimized. The save system is a complete mess and if you're not using a controller it just feels like you're playing a lousy port.Overall, I'd say it's definitely not worth the price difference compared to Lost Chapters but the game itself is still a classic and I highly recommend it. If you really have to have the Anniversary edition I suggest holding off til it's got a good sale going.

number of helpful: 19 of 38 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												This game is great! At the current price, yes, it is pretty expensive. I bought it at a discount for preorder, and I am not disappointed in my purchase. There are caveats to complete enjoyment like I have encountered.1, I play this game with a controller (mouse is not supported in the menu)2. I downscale the game for better visuals (the game is slightly blurry due to DoF)3. I anticipate modding making the game even better. (this is the real game changer)4. I try to get my combat multiplier even higher!!! (if you don't try then the game can get really repetitive fast)I feel this game holds onto something that has been lost in modern games, the idea of evolving characters and enimies seems to be non-existent in todays games. This game was a real treat!

number of helpful: 25 of 50 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This is exactly what i have been waiting for, I loved the first fable and the original gameplay but each sequel "dumbed" the game down more, which was not a bad thing because the control scheme got much more better but you could not control all the aspects of the game because they were trying to make it simpler. But i already played fable once and I felt that buying The lost chapters did not really warrant me buying a new copy of the game. Then Lionhead announced this game, and I was almost going to pass it up, until I looked into it further. Some people don't seem to appreciate the effort lionhead put into this, they COMPLETELY remade the whole game in a new engine. They had to port all the old textures and remake them into higher definitions which is pretty much saying they made new textures just the same style as the original game. It is not as buggy as the old one is on newer systems as well and thats a plus.TL;DR It is a complete overhaul of a remake, they left no stone unturned. If you liked the original game and never bought the lost chapters you should buy this. If you have the lost chapters, consider if all the bells and whistles are worth the money first.P.S. I also suggest you get a xbox controller to play this game with. It really makes this game shine and works flawlessly.

												It looks flashy and it runs alright but you can't use a mouse and keyboard in the menus. You have to use arrow keys and literally press the 'A' and 'B' keys to go forward and back... Not Enter and Esc or '>' and '<' but the ♥♥♥♥ing letters A and B... Also to navigate the inventory you need to use 'Insert' and 'Home' to scroll left and right and 'Delete' and 'End' to do the same on the lower level...They chose 'mod support' (texture and animation editing only) over being able to use a mouse on a ♥♥♥♥ing PC port!

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												If you loved the original Fable then get this game for the nastalgia factor, the only issue that I have to report about the game is the frame rate dropping almost every 10 to 30 seconds. For the most part the game is everything we loved about the original except it would seem that the creators did a shoddy job on optimizing the graphics for the PC before they released it. I would recommend waiting for a week or two as I'm guessing this problem will be fixed by then, otherwise you'll just be wasting your money on a game with broken graphics.10/10 for the game as a whole.0/10 for the current playability with the graphics at this time.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												You know, I'm not usually one for reviews, but I felt I really needed to say this. Did you like Fable?Like me, did you miss the fantastical land of Albion, the first adventures of our hero, balrog hunting, lightning throwing, and Whisper♥♥♥♥♥kicking? Did you miss being called Chicken Chaser?Well if you did, then you would think to buy this game, yes? Ho ho hold your horses, friend.First off, I am shocked that after.. Lord, how many years to get this right, they still ♥♥♥♥ed it up? So, the graphics are so god-awful they make the first game look fantastic by comparsion. All the people look like their skin is melting right off their faces and look like cosmic horrors when they speak, like everyone is covered in melted plastic and♥♥♥♥♥♥ The land looks more lazilly put together too. Again, looks worse then the decade old original.As for mechnaics? Remember all those bugs that tucked you to bed each night? Those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are still around after 10 years! Fighting? Still as clunky as you remmeber. Magic? As unbearable to control. And you know how in Fable three they made it where when you upgrade you Str as a woman, you didn't become Shiela, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Nordic Mountain?! Well, I guess they felt that was too big a change fromt he original. Hope you like ♥♥♥♥♥♥ looks! No new voice acting, same annoying lines, everything you hated about the original, minus the creativity, spark of life, and amazing wonderment that made this title stuck out.All in all, looking for a nostaligic tromp though Albion? Go buy the original. It looks better and at least has a modding community.

content:

												Im seeing a lot of negative reviews for this game, however i certainly enjoyed the play through. I've played this game 3 or 4 times when i came out and i was not dis-satisfied in anyway with this purchase. True there was one bug that caused me to have to load to a previous save, but in the 20 hours or so it took me to beat the game i found it to be pretty minor. Dont buy this game if you are expecting drastic changes from the original, i was glad that they kept the core game the same as the original because it was enjoybale on all levels. If you want this game to be a little more challenging then i would play without the revive vials but i just played it for the enjoyment and died maybe once when i was stoned a ♥♥♥♥. Anyways i would reccomend this game especially if you have yet to play any of the fable games, this is by far the best out of the series.

content:

												I bought this game as a fan. I have already played it a million times. So, I know I really like it.  I like how my character looks amazing as he progresses.  I also like that this game is about choices and how the world reacts to those choices.  That's what made this game so innovative in it's day.  I really loved this game in it's day. I played it so much I killed my first xbox.  But, as amazing as this game is, I still had my issues with it.  For a game about choices and change. The first one did not give me a choice to be a female. Here I am in playing this amazing game, in this amazing world, kicking butt as the male I have always dreamed to be. Uh no! lol. Sorry, but I want to kick butt as a female thank you.  I wanted to look good in that shiny armor as female. Then the 2nd one came out. I have the choice to be a female.  But, now the armor sucks cause the the story goes into the future a bit! Still I played because I enjoyed kicking butt and I really enjoyed the rest of the game.  I did like the steam punk twist to things. I really enjoy that. I still would recommend this game. Because for gaming sake, it is still a fun game to play.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Absolutely terrible.  Not only were the graphics nearly identical in all the environments I have so far experienced, but the small changes they made to important characters were awful.  Maze's hair/tattoos/face is broken, and all spell graphics are either the same or for some reason downgraded in quality.  My hero is uglier than sin, regardless of what type of tattoos, facial hair, or scars I try to apply to him.The audio is, as far as I can tell, the same.  I have noticed that the natural pauses in conversation that I remember being present in the first game were either shortened or deleted in this game.  The worst part is probably the menu and lack of hero save.  The menu is terrible, clearly ported directly from console, as it does not support the mouse and you must use the 'insert, home, delete, and end' buttons to navigate.  In addition, you cannot re-bind any skills on your mouse  (since as far as the menu is concerned, it does not exist.  Last but not least, there is no hero save.  That means if you're like me and work hard to get very powerful early in the storyline, you'll be age 65 when you meet your *maybe 20's* older sister.  And you'll be old enough to be your own grandfather when you meet your mother.  Awful. 1/10, would not waste time with.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
FABLE ANNIVERSARY: DO YOU WANT IT!?Have you been looking at the new Fable Anniversary relaease, wondering if you should pull the trigger and add that pup to your library? I asked myself the same question almost two months ago when I decided to shoot for the stars with Fable Anniversary. Here I have for you a few words of caution and/or encouragement. My first exposure to the Fable franchise was a few months after the release of the original on the XBOX, I was blown away and drawn back, simultaneously, to the alluring pull of this new, ambitious and anglo-centric adventure. This was like re-living the debut of Ocarina of Time! Fable, however, was of an entirely different realm. Putting much of the focus into the adverse gameplay style and the design of this beautiful reimagining of the British Isles, Fable left a little to be desired of the story. This was remedied with the addition of The Lost Chapters which made the game almost perfect, aside from a few problems that still exist in the new Anniversary version. Foremost, the game is supposed to be about making choices and becoming your own hero; the game is constantly trying to force you into being the well rounded and skilled player that the game needs you to be which makes certain boss fights or other missions difficult or undoable if your hero build isn't right. For example: Fighting Jack of Blades the first time the game wants you to use a bow. I dont want to use bows with my spellwarrior. I WANNA USE MY MELEE AND SPELLS!!! (fighting the Kracken will also take two hours if you try and use a sword and a lightning spell). This is a major problem with the Anniversary version because it still exists in every facet of playing this game making all of your decisions practically pointless and almost all the time reversable (i.e. you can go from good to evil with relative ease). It was ignorable the first time because all of this was so fresh and never really done like this before. After a decade of making games based on free will and adventure, you should be able to recognise the little problems that make your whole morality matrix and character role development feel a little redundant and pre determined. (i.e in Fable you always end up with A or B, never is a C or D involved) Fable was and is a game which does not require much time to complete the core of it but potentially doubles it's playability when you add in the side missions and all the other quirks of Albion. This was done extremely well especially with the addition of The Lost Chapters. I hoped and expected that with the new release we might get another 9 hours out of this game, but here we find much more to be desired. Moving on to the NEW issues with Fable Anniversarry, we take a look at what Anniversary does to leave the gamer longing for more, which isn't always a good thing in necessity. No new missions. If you remembered how to play the last game through, you know this one. Some might see this as a good thing, I figure my expectations were too high. But when I learned not even a single new side mission or interactable character was added to the Anniversary version, I was quite dissappointed. So what did they do? Is anything in this new-old game different or improved? Not really, its still the same semi-goofy adventure. Its the same. The game is the same. It is the same. IT'S THE SAME!!! However you do get a new and slightly longer Heroic mode: There are no ressurection phials and some healing abilities are somewhat gimped. Slightly prolonged eh? HOW IS POSSIBRU IF NO CONTENTS R NU!?!? Well if you never died before whilst playing Fable (this is not uncommon) you probably will die and if you haven't played a Fable game in a couple years like me and decide to jump right in, you may die a lot. All of this dying and reloading is what gives you those extra hours, especially if you're trying to be a good guy (the hardest kinda guy to be). The game is not necessarily more difficult, it just takes longer and sort of forces you to try and gain more experience to level up as you bump along those good ol' core quests. The difficulty in the boss fights comes from getting too bored to actually follow the attack sequences in order to hit the boss amid the 15 minutes of minion fighting/dodging before the 5 seconds you actually get to hit the boss with (assuming you have the right spell, weapon, blood type, zodiac sign, character alignment, age etc.) Here is the attack sequence for every major boss in the game *SPOILER ALERT*: DODGE, KILL MINIONS, DODGE, KILL MINIONS, DODGE, HIT THE BOSS (with the one and only attack), FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, RELOAD, DODGE, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, FIGHT MINIONS, RELOAD, BEGIN ARHYTHMICALLY POUNDING KEYS/BUTTONS *with specifically designated spells/weapons for that boss* PROFIT!? It isn't even subtle the way the game trys to force you into being what it needs you to be rather than what you want to play with. If you have the same sense of conquest and need of self reassurance that I had when I started off, I would reccomend doing the heroic mode first to get it out of the way in order to enjoy the far and few between favorable little pieces that have been reworked in Anniversary. The controls cannot be criticized too heavily as Lionhead was sort of venturing into new territory with operating systems being different these days on the PC, as well as two different controller formats, a total of three control types to be programmed and supported. I'm no expert but that probably sounds easier in type than it is in reality. I use a 360 controller, which can be tricky but you will get used to it and once you do it's almost like the good old days. So, have I gotten older, more mature or more jaded in the decade between the original and the anniversary. Yes I'd guess so. SO TO ANYONE NEW TO THE FABLE FRANCHISE, MEANING YOU'VE NEVER PLAYED FABLE BEFORE; THIS GAME IS FOR YOU! BUY IT TO SUPPORT LIONHEAD AND FUTURE VENTURES![/b] Words of warning; if you're a fan like me, you will most likely find more to complain about. But I'm no Negative Nancy. The second you step into Albion it is beautiful. The updated graphics are what I wanted, not too pristine but volumes more detail than the original. The integrity of the art is indeed intact. The new outfits, weapons and armor are also a great leg up in the game because you finally get more sets that can be more specific, even more condusive to building the kind of character you want to play...Assuming it still fits the Lionhead template. There is no damage done to the story, interactions with characters or any of the little running jokes and insider quirks we all adore hidden about the game. Would I have been willing to relenquish some of the humor or parts of the story in order to make way for new grounds in exploration of the map or exploration of different characters and I dunno, maybe a new mission or two? Definitely. Perhaps the most important and beneficial aspect that Lionhead added to the release of Anniversary was the ability for the community to create their own mods to the Fable program. I am very excited to see what the more skilled enthusiasts will creeate. Keep in mind this is all being written around/about the game that I wanted. Something slightly newer, something a little more in depth, something with a twist and above all something with a little more to explore. Some might say that what I wanted was a new game. In some ways, some people are right. But if you want something a little redundant, a little repetative, a little fickle, a little quirky and/or a little nostalgic, maybe even a little new; Look no further than Fable Anniversary...or this review Remember friends, keep your expectations and your promises low, but over-deliver with every opportunity.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												This remaster is very well done and while it does have some issues, is still very enjoyable. Fable: TLC is my favorite game of all time and this version is a welcome addition to my collection and one that I will be spending a lot of time with. I have had no problems running this game, no crashes, no stutters, no blur problems that others have had and I don't really have the best setup.Now there are two issues that I have with this game, but they do not make the game unplayable. The first issue is that there is only partial Mouse Support. You cannot use the mouse at all in the menus and the developers chose some convoluted keys to navigate the menus that are difficult to use, especially on a laptop. The keys that you use to navigate are "A", "B", "INSERT", "DELETE", "HOME", and "END". I have to press and hold the "FN" key just to use three of them. There is also no way to rebind these keys. Hopefully there will be a patch or a mod in the future to add mouse support to the menu.The second issue is the targeting or locking on system. It doesn't always work and sometimes the system chooses the furthest enemy or, even worse, a friendly target. Again, this does not make the game unplayable, but it is annoying.8/10 overall a great gameOS: Windows 8.1, 64 bitCPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-3610QM CPU @ 2.30GHz GPU: NVIDIA GeForce GT 640M LE

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												First couple of hours---------------------Nice, generic, light hearted and simple RPG. Maybe too simple.The whole style seems a little bit childish to me as if it's aimed at young teenagers or even younger, yet there's murder.The UI and Keyboard setup is non standard and awkward.As of now I can't recommend this at £27.It reminds me of Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning, but not nearly as good.I'm fully expecting to have better impressions a few hours from now as it generally has good reviews.After 9 hours------------------------I'm getting slightly used to the UI and Controls but they are still very clunky. It's obvious that the UI is a port from consoles and a very bad one at that.Getting frustrated with the way some quests are laid outShop NPCs frequently seem to disappear at random times to nowhere when it's daylight.Not enough portals in map locationsAfter 15 hours---------------------A lot of the game is just fillers, like the boxing ring thing and the bardEnvironments seem very small and almost fake.. no compelling reason to exploreI'm quite bored now and want the game to just endAfter 20 hours--------------------Finished the main questline and I'm very bored. Skipping past all dialogs and just wanting the game to end.Conclusion----------------Game is far too short, too childish, gets boring quickly and didn't live up to the hype or anywhere near it.Only worth £10 not £27 so can't recommend at that price (I got it in a sale)

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Yikes! This game is unfinished and nearly unplayable. Apart from the poor menu system, and the general difficulty is reassigning keys, the framerate is poor, doesn't look HD, and the camera jerks all over the place if using a mouse. Anyone who has motion sickness, you may actually vomit. It is obviously made for using an Xbox controller, but this is a PC game. Why a controller? Why not have mouse function in menus for an RPG game that's all about customisation? I hope a quality patch fixes these issues, the game seems like a rushed port and many will be feeling the burn from forking out good money for a barely functioning game. In the end, I'm sure if Lionhead came out and said 'we need on more month to make it perfect' I'm sure everyone would understand. To release it as it currently is, well that's just unprofessional and a stab in the heart of the diehard fans who were hanging out for this game. WIll cross my fingers for a patch, as I know there's no chance of a refund. What a shame...

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Fable: The Lost Chapters was my first Fable game and the only one that really sticks out of all the others, but this Anniversary is a joke. Lionhead Studios/Microsoft didn't bother to add new voiceovers or overall sounds. The gameplay is just the same clunky like in Fable:TLC, nothing has been touched there, except for the controller option. And probably the worst, NO NEW QUEST? NOTHING AT ALL?! I was hoping for a sandbox mode with new quest and maybe activities once I completed the game. but there's nothing!  Just your daily Fable life with your imaginary wife and sometimes helping out a wandering trader. The guildmaster also became silent and no one has something to say that I saved their life from Dragon Jack.Improved graphics doesn't make an Anniversary game Lionhead Studios/Microsoft, especially if they aren't that good. And how can it even be that an Anniversary release has less options than the 10 year older original game?This said, I had my share fun with the game. The nostalgia was big walking through Albion. I still don't suggest anyone to buy this version of the game. Go get yourself Fable: TLC which is just the same and cheaper! Atleast I bought this game via a thirdpartysite.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Fable was one of the original games that allowed you to decide who you wanted to be. It was a very popular game for that reason. Fable 1, TLC and Anniversary will always be better than Fable 2 and Fable 3. Not that I didn't enjoy those games either. It's nearly impossible to see sequels or anything further, best the first and original game. With a large community that has loved and cherished this game through the years; there can be a LOT of mods and new content on the approach. Not sure what happened with the Custom Tattoo feature that was previously in The Lost Chapters.I'm sure that most of you, if not all, have beaten the story line at least once. The story line was superb and I will pretty much leave it at that. You must see the story for yourself, since there are multiple ways of gameplay.The new updated graphics are very appealing. Runs a lot smoother than TLC and deifnitely the original. They had fixed some glitches from the previous versions and they have also developed new ones that are currently being addressed. I've been enjoying this game like I have when I first got it. It has a lot of replay value. If you are new to RPGS, I would definitely recommend this game to you for a starter.5/5

If you missed out on the first fable then buy this version and not the original, controller support on its own makes this worth buying over the original release. 												updates 3-4:while they finally enabled the mouse for all menu's the menu system is still jacked up big time.they fixed some of the graphic issues with clothing and clipping with skin/underwear or whatever the base textures are.- still need to work on combining all menu's so that keyboard and mouse changes can be made from main menu, instead of being forced to do it while playing the game.- still need to upgrade skeletons for male characters, specially PC; which currently looks like a walking toothpick, and mesh morphing.- still need to work on invisible items that are still somehow selectable... (at least one glitch like this with the haircut shop in bowerstone).- still need to work on updating intro videos or get rid of them, both logo and intro to main menu are still pixelated bigtime, still no excuse for this lack of work, its just pathetic.- still need to work on invisible walls that dont match the terrain.- need to work on how stat/equpiment/etc. menu's are laid out and work.- still need to work on GUI sizes, should all be included with the hotbar 'options' which really isnt a option right now.- still need to fix blue plastic look for player character.- still need to fix animations (would be less of an issue if skeleton on PC was made more masculine instead of stickman).- still need to fix quest text, given quest text is non-informative... unless you remember exactly what you were doing when you start the game and load/continue a save, the quest text is so vague as to be completely useless... it needs to be fixed or removed entirely.- random item pickup respawns for house objects that are actually searchable, also you would think that you would be able to use those objects (shelves and cubaords/etc.) in your own house, to store stuff or to search for what might have been there previously.- better modding support for textures/animations/skeletons/etc. so people dont have (forced?) to use texmod to play/use mods at all.- some textures and item placements need to be updated (delivery boxes, garden walls, 'retaining' walls).still major work needs to be done on this game before it is worth spending ANY money on for PC... the original port is still 100 times better than anniversary.the modding DLC that is 'free' still has nothing in it to download... even if we wanted to mod the game we currently cannot because there are no tools available via the free DLC download, there isnt even a place setup to add override or mods for the game to use (plus no options in-game yet to load override or mods for the game at all)MS/LionHead have a TON and a half issues to fix still, specially for those of us who where hoping to mod the game.final thought:even with the (3rd?) update, it is not yet worth actually buying still.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												I loved Fable on XBOX and each of the sequels - that's what it's incredibly upsetting that Fable Anniversary is so choppy that it's nearly unplayable. I'm playing on an HP Pavillion Laptop with an AMD A10 2.10 GHz processor and 8 GB of RAM - which should be able to handle the game. Instead I'm spending my first few hours playing around with settings to try to get my character to not pause for a frame between every step he takes. The cut scenes look terrible too - the sun rising took a quick break halfway up due to this choppiness - and the character interactions look worse than on the original XBOX version. I'm going to keep looking online for ways to improve the performance but 1 hour into the game it's pretty clear that Lionhead didn't put much effort into this. Thanks for the huge dissapointment :(Update - I ended up playing through the main story and mostly ingnoring the bugginess. The choppiness gets better after the Hero Guild Graduation - but not completely. I used the Slow Time spell to make the lagginess seem less out of place, and tended to skip all the cutscenes. I did put in a lot of hours, and did enjoy myself, but if I had a choice to go back and buy this again I wouldn't. I'd take a train out to my mother's house in the subburbs and plug in my old XBOX and play the original instead.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Hey guys,I've been playing this game for a while. In my own opinion, it is one of the great games, as I never got to play the original Fable:TLC as a kid. Objectively, the gameplay is the same as original, as I have watched the TLC's videos on youtube. It doesn't deviate in anyway. Pros:- Same gameplay controls as original (From what I've seen in youtube for TLC)- Their UI is different to the original (In my opinion, that's pleasin' to my eyes compared to the original)- Their graphics differ greatly, as they use Unreal Engine. Anniversary has more colours, shadows and details- It is moddable- It does have ALL TLC's DLCS included in it.- They did add new equipment to this game such as  Snowspire Guard Outfit and the Jackarse- It has the new difficulty that makes this game a bit challengingCon:- For anyone that have played TLC, they won't see any differences in it.- No mouse support in the menu and inventory. TL;DR - Worth getting it if you want to relive nostalgia in a new skin, or you never had a chance to play the original Fable in my opinion. You may not find it any different to original Fable, just loaded with a bit of new equipment, that's all.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												DO NOT BUY FROM STEAM. BUY ANYWHERE ELSE!!!!!!The Fable series is excellent. Definitely my favourite RPG game of all time. I was introduced to the game in reverse order, this being the last one I've played. All of the games are well worth the money. I was ecstatic to see Fable Anniversary on sale and I jumped on the opportunity to buy it. Waste. Of. Money. I shouldve just bought the CD. Now, on to why YOU SHOULD NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME FROM STEAM.Steam does not offer suport on this game, obviously. There are some game crashing bugs that ruin the entire game, even if you try to work around them. The spells Multistrike and Berserk DO NOT WORK. Instead, they immediately crash the game, losing any progress you had made since the last checkpoint. I have researched bug fixes and have found absolutely none and Steam doesn't seem to care that they're selling a broken game. This has been an issue since 2014 as far as I can tell, YET STEAM DOES NOTHING TO FIX. I have validated my game caches, and messed with every setting under the sun to try to figure out the cause. Nothing works. If you buy, NEVER PURCHASE MULTISTRIKE or BESERK. You cannot avoid them once purchased; they're an easy accidental button press away from losing all your progress. THIS GAME IS WORTH 5 STARS.      FIX IT, STEAM.   IT'S BEEN YEARS SO THERE IS 0 EXCUSE TO STILL BE SELLING A GAME WITH HUGE BUGS LIKE THIS. I'll reccomend this game on steam when it stops crashes for stupid things.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Fable Anniversary is exactly what you should expect from an HD remake: the original game with modern graphics and improvements to the gameplay. The models and textures are updated, gamepad, widescreen, and windowed modes are now supported natively (as opposed to 3rd party workarounds), modding tools have been added (hopefully to be expanded upon at some point in the future), and a new difficulty has been added to the game for an added challenge.Speaking from my personal experience with the game, I never had any issues as far as crashes or drops in framerate. The game ran smoothly from start to finish, and I was able to beat the whole of the game without much trouble. The biggest issue I had was with the in-game menus. Fable Anniversary is a fairly straight forward console port from the Xbox 360 version of the game, just with the resolution and graphics options unlocked. Normally, this isn't an issue, but since the 360 is not controlled with a mouse, you need to navigate menus with buttons. Besides this one annoying quirk, it's the same as playing Fable: TLC.If you already have Fable: TLC for PC or Xbox Original and feel fine with shelling out some extra dosh for HD graphics, then Anniversary is perfect for you (at the time of writing, Anniversary is on sale for $12). But if you're new to the series or this version of the game isn't on sale, I would recommend buying Fable: TLC over this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												(Note: While I can't say I recommend this game just because of the nature of this review, please don't let me stop you from at least trying it if you want it. Fable is a great game, and if remasters are your thing then it's worth buying. But this is a serious problem that has not been addressed despite the fact that I'm far from the only one who's experienced it, so I have to give a negative review.)The game has serious issues.Whenever I walk around, the camera is constantly stuttering and jerking every. single. half-second. It's absolutely unplayable. My computer can clearly handle the game, that much I can tell. All while the lag is going on, the background stuff (flowers waving in the breeze, fire, idle animations, etc) are going at full speed. My processor is more than enough to handle this game, it just... doesn't work.And I've tried everything from screwing with ini files to lowering graphics to as little as possible to making the game use only one core, but it's unfixable. Some people have reported that this stops after Oakvale, but it doesn't, and I couldn't stand playing anymore to see if it stopped after the Heroes Guild.Even in the in-game cutscenes, I hear the audio play at normal time as the characters stutter on, while the voices play at the correct time, so you have things like hearing the sound of the villager getting shot and 10 seconds later you hear "Got one!" and it's complete silence for the rest of the cutscene except when the characters are speaking. It's bewildering.The main thing that's crazy about this is how my computer meets and even exceeds the recommended requirements (I've seen reports with people as high as i5 processors encountering this problem), and the game itself seems to run just fine. This isn't even like normal lag or processor overload. It almost seems like the game is doing it intentionally, because everything else in the game except for me isn't lagging! So buy this game if you'd like it, but be prepared to get a refund (and a punch in the nostalgia) if it doesn't work.As for the game itself, I'd be pretty happy with it if it wasn't for this game-ruining bug. Yeah, it's just Fable with better graphics and a nicer lighting system. There's also Heroic (hard) Mode, which is definitely worth a play, and the aging is slowed so you're not 40 years old by the time you beat the bloody Wasp Queen. It's a minor quirk that always bugged me, so heyo. Oh, and you can save anywhere. Other than that, there are no differences. I got it on sale so I can't complain.If that's your thing, don't let me stop you. But if you also encounter this problem, you might just want to get a refund and buy the original Lost Chapters instead.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												For those of you who may have played Fable II and Fable III and liked those, but never got to experience this original game, I would highly recommend this game. I will say that $35 is a bit steep for a graphical overhaul, as most of the mechanics (as far as I can tell) haven't been altered. For first timers it might be worth it, but if it goes on sale for 25% or more I would definitely recommend picking it up.For those that have played/own the original version, the $35 price tag is way overpriced. I would recommend waiting for at least a 50% off sale before picking this up.Bottom line... I picked this game up after get one of the mass distributed coupons for 60% off and I jumped on the offer, and I say it was well worth it. The graphics are beautiful to look at. Nothing revolutionary or next gen, but a great enough improvement over the original that makes playing through it again a whole new experience.As for the few things I dont like...- If playing with a controller... Even though I have been using 360 controllers since '06 I still find myself attempting to hit those Black/White buttons to use my bow and sword, but those are now assigned to the LB and RB. There is an option for a more Fable II and III control scheme, where X is melee, and Y is the bow. I like that control setup more, overall, but it messes with my instinct to push Y to block like the original controls do.-The faces are the one thing that seem to have suffered in the overhaul. The Hero's, Maze, and the Guildmasters faces all look wrong, compared to what I expected from the original game. But it is easily able to be overlooked and ignored.The things I have mixed feelings on...- The new menu interface... It is very different from the original. If this is your first time playing the game, dont worry. The menu setup is still logical, just different. lol It definitely looks nicer, I am just still adjusting to using the LB/RB and LT/RT to navigate rather than just having a list you scroll through with the thumbstick.- The difficulty... I recall that during my first one or two playthroughs of the game on Xbox, I used many Ressurection Phials. And then I got to the point where I could sell all but one or two, as I very rarely needed them. The Anniversary edition has two difficulties (the original just had one IIRC), the classic difficulty, and a harder one. I seriously debated playing the harder one right off the bat, as I remember that I had stopped playing the original in part because it felt too easy. But now... maybe the default is harder, or more likely I just lost my "edge" in the game from not playing it for a long time. I have only played about 4 hours I think at the time of writing this, and I have already used 4 or 5 Phials. lolThe things I like...- The graphics, obviously. I like seeing the detail on my gear now, and the world seems more vibrant. I have enjoyed just running around and looking at things.- Even though it seems I would have been committing suicide, I am glad that there is a harder difficulty for when I am ready to attempt that.- It is the same game I fell in love with so many years ago. Yes, including bugs lol. They had debated redoing the entire game, but I am glad they didnt. It would have been nice to see the bugs fixed, but there arent even enough to be concerned about really. This game gives me a rather large sense of visually updated nostalgia. Aside from the Halo games on Xbox, this game was my next favorite.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Fable was a game backed by huge promises and a lot of hype. Although it didn't live up to every claim that Lionhead Studios made, it did manage to deliver a great action RPG, with a lot of character and humour. Fable Anniversary on Xbox 360 gave me so many problems, that it left a sour taste in my mouth, and I flat out put that console back in the closet. I found it on here for sale the other day, and I am glad I gave this one a second shot. I got to relive all the epic moments and see all the sights Albion has to offer, but this time with a fresh coat of paint and a few slight changes to bring this game up to par. Aside from a few problems here and there (nothing game breaking) and some freaky looking character models, Fable Anniversary was 20 hours well spent, and I actually look forward to my next adventure in this wonderful game!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Where to begin,Let me start off by saying the original Fable game was one of my first Microsoft gaming experiences (Got it with the Crystal EDition Xbox with Fable and Crimson Skies). Since then however many years ago, Ive owned 6 copies of this game whether it be the original, lost chapters, or anniversary. It was on sale on the summer sale and for the low price tag, I had to try the PC port.Im a huge fan of the game, and the series, however this PC port is less than what is desired. Lets start off with the basic skeleton of the game, the graphics.GraphicsThis Anniversary edition is pretty much Lost Chapters remastered, with a very linear reskin for graphics. The graphics have improved by a little bit yes, but some animations are still quite static and robotic. For a game they are asking $40 full price I guess there isnt too much space to complain about, but when you look at other aanniversary games (Halo 2 Anniversary as an example) that offer full redone and appropriate next gen reskin, its hard to pass this as acceptable. For owners of Lost chapters, its not worth spending that kind of money for minor graphical enhancements. The thing with graphics that drive me nuts with this game is the color palette and shadowing. Original fans like myself will notice this when you first start off, as the green and red outlines around foes/allies are a murky and dull shade, where these colors should be vibrant and identifiable such as the original. Id give the graphics 3/5.SoundFor me this games sound component has always been stellar. The composed music in this game is well written and very recognizable. The music composure fits the game well, and changes appropriately without being abrupt as situations in the game change. Whether its browsing throughout the guild, to entering the woods and entering into a combat scenario. As far as sound effects go there is quite abit of repitition, but its to be expected in an older title, and its only going to bug you if you focus on it. Voice acting is another strong point of this game as some of the main characters (minus your hero obviously!) have very interesting voices, and some of the scripting the speak is quite funny and entertaining. Overall, with the music being a strong point for me and the mix of it all into one works well, id give the sound 4.25/5, especially considering the age of the game (unsure if sound was remastered for the anniversary edition, will have to look)StoryAnother great part of this game. Original fans will feel quite at home and know what they are getting into. New fans will have a great story mode to get into and see how it all intertwines. From the original Oakvale raid, to the battle with Jack of blades, its quite a nice vengeance based story mode that will keep you interested. The transition from the original game to the added extention of Lost Chapters has always been odd for me. You can definitly tell where the original game ended, and where they slapped on the added part of TLC. However, the variety in missions and rewards make this well worth looking into. 4/5 ControlsHere is the major flaw with this PC port. The controls are awful. Controlling the camera with the mouse while trying to balance out everything else out on the keyboard is less than desired. In High tempo, higher ranked combat it is quite difficult to go from say a range attack, to melee, to will in a smooth way. I find myself getting lost on the keyboard trying to remember all the silly Hotkeys (Clicking in the mouse wheel to block?!). I havent looked to see if I can change these or not, but even fresh off the install, better controls should be offered as you seem to be all over the keyboard to map simple combos and interactions. Again im very new to the PC port, so I dont consider this part of the review to be fair. Im going to look into other control options, and test out the full control compatibility and update this. But as of now, 2/5 for controlsGameplayBeing a fan of this game I knew what I was getting into. There are gold quests which are your main storyline quests, while silver are selective. Theres a great balance between these quests and none of the main quests seem repititous in anyway. They are all interconnected and feel smooth, while the silver quests seem to be less polished. Whether its combat in the Arena Quest, or racing in your underwear in the prison, I think most gamers will be quite happy with the versatility offered in this game. Its nowhere near as in depth as other RPGs as Skyrim or WoW, but for a casual common gamer such as myself that doesnt want to put 500hrs into the game, its great for pickup and play. The combat mechanics are simple, yet effective. You have a decent selection of basic weapons (Swords, Hammers, Scythes, Bows, Crossbows, etc) which are then placed into damage categories based on level (Obsidian, Master etc). Not to mention the Legendary weapons you can find in game through chests, quests, and other means. Like previously stated, the only amjor hinderance with the combat in this game is abmysal controls.Gameplay 4.25/5Overall, would I recommend this game? For the $9 I paid for it, definitly. For users looking to get into it I cannot recommend it at $40. Owners of Lost Chapters especially, save your time and money,ID RATE THIS PORT 3.5/5Its a great game for a great series, and those who didnt experience it on both xboxs like I did, I would recommned picking up this port and checking out this great story and game. For myself, I can look  past the flaws as im a huge fan of the game, and hopefully you will do the same and experience the core of Fable and where its popularity came from.*Thanks for reading my first review, I will update as I continue on with the game as obviously I dont have much time played right now.
