number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												For those of you who may have played Fable II and Fable III and liked those, but never got to experience this original game, I would highly recommend this game. I will say that $35 is a bit steep for a graphical overhaul, as most of the mechanics (as far as I can tell) haven't been altered. For first timers it might be worth it, but if it goes on sale for 25% or more I would definitely recommend picking it up.For those that have played/own the original version, the $35 price tag is way overpriced. I would recommend waiting for at least a 50% off sale before picking this up.Bottom line... I picked this game up after get one of the mass distributed coupons for 60% off and I jumped on the offer, and I say it was well worth it. The graphics are beautiful to look at. Nothing revolutionary or next gen, but a great enough improvement over the original that makes playing through it again a whole new experience.As for the few things I dont like...- If playing with a controller... Even though I have been using 360 controllers since '06 I still find myself attempting to hit those Black/White buttons to use my bow and sword, but those are now assigned to the LB and RB. There is an option for a more Fable II and III control scheme, where X is melee, and Y is the bow. I like that control setup more, overall, but it messes with my instinct to push Y to block like the original controls do.-The faces are the one thing that seem to have suffered in the overhaul. The Hero's, Maze, and the Guildmasters faces all look wrong, compared to what I expected from the original game. But it is easily able to be overlooked and ignored.The things I have mixed feelings on...- The new menu interface... It is very different from the original. If this is your first time playing the game, dont worry. The menu setup is still logical, just different. lol It definitely looks nicer, I am just still adjusting to using the LB/RB and LT/RT to navigate rather than just having a list you scroll through with the thumbstick.- The difficulty... I recall that during my first one or two playthroughs of the game on Xbox, I used many Ressurection Phials. And then I got to the point where I could sell all but one or two, as I very rarely needed them. The Anniversary edition has two difficulties (the original just had one IIRC), the classic difficulty, and a harder one. I seriously debated playing the harder one right off the bat, as I remember that I had stopped playing the original in part because it felt too easy. But now... maybe the default is harder, or more likely I just lost my "edge" in the game from not playing it for a long time. I have only played about 4 hours I think at the time of writing this, and I have already used 4 or 5 Phials. lolThe things I like...- The graphics, obviously. I like seeing the detail on my gear now, and the world seems more vibrant. I have enjoyed just running around and looking at things.- Even though it seems I would have been committing suicide, I am glad that there is a harder difficulty for when I am ready to attempt that.- It is the same game I fell in love with so many years ago. Yes, including bugs lol. They had debated redoing the entire game, but I am glad they didnt. It would have been nice to see the bugs fixed, but there arent even enough to be concerned about really. This game gives me a rather large sense of visually updated nostalgia. Aside from the Halo games on Xbox, this game was my next favorite.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Edit:I am leaving my initial review because I think it's important to know how companies release games as well as what the end product turns out to be. The game is great now aside from the menues still being terrible with a key set. The graphics are smoother, the eyes aren't taking you out of the game because they are so poorly done (decent now) and although esc doesn't back you out of menues, "backspace" does and that in it's self is nicer than having to use the letters on the key set. Now, I would say to go a head and play this game, and I'm changing my thumbs down to a up.(This edit was done when I saw the update installing.)Edit: Seems they may have fixed everything I didn't like... Will have to test soon and re-write the review. See patch notes here: "New Version Available – 835543Community Announcements - OmanFixes include but not limited to: Expanded Keyboard and Mouse remapping optionsFixed a script issue with digging glyphs in NecropolisHard Mode – Removed ability to farm gold by selling houses with trophiesFixed highlight effect on textures with Alpha (trolls for example)Updated eye textures and placementFixed Moustache colour morphing Added error message for running out of Video MemoryFixed flickering sky at 3am Fixed hero morphs in the stats screenFixed new profile reverting back to previous profile on front endAdded borders to cover UI clipping on non 16:9 screensAdded Enter and Backspace as the main UI buttonsFixed a crash in the modded version with the skill upgradesDisplay the GPU Adapter at the bottom of the screen when on credits option - use this to verify which GPU your PC is using."Original review below:I was really looking forward to this... Then I launched it.As soon as I launched this game and got to the menue I thought to myself "This has to be the worst port I've ever seen"Navigation of the menue is not possible with the mouse, you can not move up and down in it with the W or S keys, you can't select a choice with a click of the mouse or a strike of the enter key, esc doesn't back you out. The "A" key selects, the "B" key backs up, and you must use the arrows to navigate the menue... I shut the game off in discust after I maxed all the graphics settings.Launched the game a few days later with a controller attached. OK fine, if I have to use one in game I guess I can get past the total lack of propper key set support... Now that I'm in the game my dissapointment grows further. The original animations were fun and cheaky at the low rest and dated textures, having the exact same with new textures... Just feels cheap. It can look better, with propper screen shots, and there are deffinitely added foliage, increased resolutions, and so on and so forth but... The dancing shadows from the original are amplified in this version, and you get "pop in" loading. I know what you are thinking, my computer must be slow or dated. I can play Witcher 2 maxed with uber sampling and not have an issue, so it's not the machines capability although who knows if it is a compatability issue. Next up, the EYES. I should have said this first but if you played it I wanted you to wait a bit to know I agree heh. The eyes are so bad they take you out of the rest of the game. They make the people look like creepy dead little dolls from a horror flick. They never are looking at the person they are talking to but they do move around and seem to stare off in a direction that might contain the city where the person is that they are talking to, but never actually at them.... This is so bad that all I can do is laugh, laugh at it's complete and utter discrace it has brought to the first game and laugh at the fact I spent money on it...They updated it so the crows in the start don't give you experience, but didn't bother to update it so you could save at any time and shut the game off and not lose your place...I may keep playing it, I'm not sure... If you want to try Fable, I sugest "The lost chapters" it was a fun and fantastic game. This one? Unless you want to laugh at it the way you would a movie from the 80's that's completely serious but you just can't help laugh at how bad it is, then don't bother.

												Very pricey for a simple retexturing, but for me, it was worth it. Fable was my favorite Xbox game of all time, and being able to replay the entire thing in HD with a controller was like a dream come true. I do own the old PC version of TLC, but having full controller support just made me feel like I was sitting down at my Xbox again and reliving one of the greatest video game experiences I ever had. My only regret is that I rememebered the entire game, so there were no surprises.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												As a fan of the original Fable and Fable 2, I felt compelled to dip my toe into this fantasy world once again and revisit the series, and I'm glad I did. The setting is beautiful, humourous and exciting, the gameplay ranging from complex to simple depending on how you want to play and is a good fit for all types of players and the controls, whilst a little awkward at first, fits well by the time you have finished the earlier quests.If you enjoyed Fable on the xbox, I'd say you will enjoy your second time around, and if you are new to Fable, you could do much, MUCH worse than this adventurous RPG. A must buy. You SHOULD buy. Or are you just going to stand there like a lemon?

												I never played Fable on the Xbox when it came out, but I had heard good things about it so when it was on sale durning the winter sale, I decided to pick it up.  I am sure glad I did!  It has a great story, the combat is fluid and easy to control and the inventory system is very good, although I will there was a little easier to tell what you have equiped. I highly recommend this game if you have not played Fable before, if you have I have heard not much has changed so it might be a waste of money unless you a die hard Fable fan. Bottom line: Get it if you have never played Fable before.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												This is a remaster of a 12 year old game whose core gameplay is good enough to stand against the giants available for purchase today in the genre - the definitive version of Fable/Fable: TLC. I spent countless hours playing Fable for the Xbox growing up, and when I saw Anniversary up on the winter sale this past December I jumped at the opportunity to experience the version of the game I never had when I was younger (I never played through TLC).What a great experience! I've loved every single minute of my playthrough thus far, and will probably do a second one shortly after!Controller support is great (I use a Steam Controller when playing), but I'm sure the KB+M controls work fine as well. The old hero save glitches are gone which could be a boon or a negative depending on who you speak to. The graphical updates are noticable but still retain the charm that the original Fable had.If you played this game when it was originally released and you were a fan - GET THIS! Get it on sale, get it full price, whatever you may do - just buy it. If you have the patience to wait, pick it up on sale (it goes on sale frequently) and get the best value for your dollar. You will not regret it.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												(F.Y.I. I played more then 8h it just didnt count them no idea why)THis is an awsome game for everyone who likes RPG and fantasy. It does not matter if you have played RPG's for years or this is the first one the game teaches you everything and is easy to understand. This Game is full of Action, Adventure and fun, i have not had a game like this in a long time. IT IS AMAZING!!! Very interesting story fun gameplay and the game lets you choose between good and bad all the time you can either save some farmers or help rob them, you can Guard a diplomat or kill him it is totaly up to you but remember "FOR EVERY CHOICE, A CONSEQUENCE" now the graphics are not the best but still pretty good. How old should one be? Absolutely no problem at the age of 12+ at least 11 would be good since there is a lot of violence and a tiny bit of blood.All in all this is a must have for every adventure RPG fan, has a lot of action and an awsome story

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Fable was a game backed by huge promises and a lot of hype. Although it didn't live up to every claim that Lionhead Studios made, it did manage to deliver a great action RPG, with a lot of character and humour. Fable Anniversary on Xbox 360 gave me so many problems, that it left a sour taste in my mouth, and I flat out put that console back in the closet. I found it on here for sale the other day, and I am glad I gave this one a second shot. I got to relive all the epic moments and see all the sights Albion has to offer, but this time with a fresh coat of paint and a few slight changes to bring this game up to par. Aside from a few problems here and there (nothing game breaking) and some freaky looking character models, Fable Anniversary was 20 hours well spent, and I actually look forward to my next adventure in this wonderful game!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												This is more a remaster than a remake of Fable. Nonetheless, this is probably one of the greatest RPG's ever to have existed so it makes sense to remaster it to preserve it for upcoming generations. What is Fable? Fable is a game about the life of your in-game character. You will follow him from childhood to his elder years (age is simulated through playtime rather than story). Your decisions shape your character's appearance, reputation and social standing. The way people react to you differs depending on your in-game actions. Did you raid a farm in order to gain some gold, or did you defend it from bandits? Fable is a game filled with lore and really gives you a good sense of growth. You will feel yourself and your character improve with gameplay. Fighting often with swords makes your character's muscles grow. Eating too much food will make him fat. Using a lot of magic will create rune lines on his skin. Doing good deeds will make your skin lighter and your eyes glow blue. Doing evil deeds will make your skin darker and your eyes glow red. Whatever your decisions, you can bet that the game will reflect it.I will not spoil anything, but this is one of the greatest RPG stories because of how varied it is. It really feels like you've lived a lifetime by the end of the game; the game feels that lengthy.The combat is enjoyable as it is a hack n' slash game. This version gives you a 'heroic' mode which really ups the challenge. More tactics is required in heroic mode as you need to plan before heading into battle, "which enemies do I kill first, what spells should I use, how should I initially attack". One false move and you will die (and die for good as you will need to restart from a checkpoint).If you've already played the game and are purchasing this for the upgraded graphics, then you're reading the right review. The graphics are a great improvement. However, I feel like the game 'feels' different with the new graphics. It feels more like 'clay' rather than the old World of Warcrafty graphics. Hard to describe unless you've played it yourself. In terms of gameplay, NOTHING was changed. Everything is the same; the bugs, the sounds, the interface. They have 'improved' the HUD (which isn't necessarily an improvement, just a reskin). All in all, it's a solid remaster but not worth the $40.00 price tag. Wait for a sale; $20 and below and this remaster is definately worth it.This remaster gets an 8/10. It lost 2 points due to no improvements/innovation.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Fable 1 is like dollar store candy- cheap and unsophisticated, but still tasty none-the-less in a junky kind of way. It helps that it doesn't take itself seriously in the least. Anniversary, then, is like the candy makers going over the recipe again, fiddling with the sugar quantity, maybe sourcing a slightly better supplier of chocolate liquer, upgrading their factory machinery, and investing in a more professional-looking packaging. Its still junky dollar-store candy, but now its the BEST junky dollar-store candy. Patching has done much to resolve stability issues, and my gripes are few, mostly in relation to non-functionality of Boast UI and the continued annoyance of trying to buy property in Bowerstone South.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I couldn't wait to play this game when I heard they were going to remaster it. Fans have been asking them to do an HD remake for years. The gameplay is exactly how it was on the original game (animations and all) and the only thing changed are the graphics. A lot of the reviews are negative for this reason but the majority of the people who were asking for the remake to happen did not and still don't want the original gameplay changed. Yes, there have been some features in Fable 2 and 3 that would have been nice to have on the remake (better animations once again), but a lot of fans, myself included, wanted to play this game exactly as it was. We just wanted to see this great RPG in full HD glory and updated so it ran better, so if you were a fan of the original but wanted improvements on top of the HD remaster, this probably isn't the game for you to buy, but if you, like me, just wanted to see this game in stunning HD quality, this is a great game to buy. The only con I have is the new inventory menu. It takes some getting used to and I'd have prefered the original one, but oh well.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												As a huge fan of the original Fable, I just had to pick this remaster up and I'm truthfully glad I did. It is still basically the same game, but with a major graphical overhaul and built on a new game engine (Unreal). I'd say the graphics look 20x better than the original did despite some naysayers who say otherwise. The only problem I noticed visually is often times textures will take a while to load when talking to NPC's and their faces will look a little muddy for about a minute until the texture loads, but other than that it looks great and way better than the original. The character faces are what shine the most and have been improved dramatically, but overall the textures and colors are far higher resolution and more rich in color. Another plus is the addition of achievements and full gamepad support (I mean afterall, this is 2015, every PC gamer should own a gamepad). Aside from the obvious, this also has some cool DLC (I haven't bought yet, but I've seen it), mostly just new clothing and armor like being able to wear Jack of Blades' or Thunder's outfit, etc.Aside from the obvious, it is still the same classic Fable fans will know and love but optimized for people who have the latest computer hardware and Windows 8/10. However, the price is a little steep. I would wait for a sale before purchasing as the normal price they're asking for is a little too much even for a remake as worthy of a purchase as this. I think $15 to $20 is fair, but anything more than that is a little overboard honestly.Do I recommend buying it? Of course. Even coming from someone that played the original countless times this game doesn't ever get old.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												The original game with some graphical textures is arguably a much better game overall. The lack of menu and key binding options, the lack of hotkey porting especially (there's no F key bindings I have found), makes this game not only lazy but extremely frustrating to play.Don't buy this if you are thinking about it. If you haven't seen already, you can't actually use your mouse in the menus. WHY? I assume it would have taken 2 or 3 hours at the very worst to put the capability back in, or copy and adapt the code from *any* other game from the studio.Edit: 2 months of fixes later and it has become quite a good game, happy to recommend it now.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Updated 10.11.14So we finally got mouse support, reason to check all patches and take another look at controls, keys and graphics.The game improved, navigating the menu with the mouse is behaving strange, but thats not unusual for console ports, and at least we can do that now.So that works argueable well, in comparision with the 4-key system from before its a 400% improvement. The menu was the main reason i didnt play Anniversary so far, it just made the task of doing anything in the menu unbearable. Thats fixed now. It could be better, but its ok.Contols and fighting system are still like the original, i like that. Yet we werent able to fe. use special mouse buttons or rebind individual actions. All this is possible by now.Graphics had to live through some changes and are now less blurry and sharper overall. Nice to actually see the better graphics now ;)For a review of the game itself (story, world gameplay) check my Fable - The Lost Chapters review, the games are 99% identical and control the same way (aside from menu as discussed before).  I'll just say that the old version was/is one of my most favorite games of all time.http://steamcommunity.com/id/st0l3nid/recommended/204030Fable Anniversary finally got the curve, there is still some room for improvement, but we can finally enjoy with mouse and keyboard and nice graphics. I change my vot from no to yes therefore.'nuff said.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Absolutely just. . . .the exact sound I made when we saw the hero's face was "gyuh!?",. . . This is a good with the same kind of horrendous aesthetic choices. Characters and objects (training dummy e.g.) don't fit with the environment, the low camera with the new visuals make the buildings look like some weird low-budget 3D movie set, and the Fire bridge that looks epic even today is just..underwhelming, clashing, and not at all nice to look at. They done %$@#$ed it up. That clay-ish colour palette, that doesn't help. Fable is meant to be bright and vibrant and  .. . well . . .cartoony. The more realistic colouring and texturing looks really, really wrong on the basic designs of everything else. That said, game runs better than TLC, windowed mode works properly, and finally get a controller on PC. Plus, if nothing else, the hard mode -does- remove both the trade and the sell house with trophy money cheats. There's still stuff you can do, but the worst offenders have been dealt with, and the only real limitation the limited funds put upon you is how many potions you can burn thru. EDIT:The above has been edited as well, so update is a better term, but anyway . .. .The patches do make hard mode more interesting, the worst offenses as a port (keybindings) have been addressed, and just all in all, they're doing a lot to improve things. I still HATE the new aesthetic, but I'll have to begrudgingly offer up a recommend now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												NEW REVIEW: So they fixed all the bugs and issues, the new graphics are alright (nothing special, especially for a PC game). Gameplay's always fun (since it's fable). Of course, usually a remake is the original but reimagined, where you'd expect an entirely new game based off the original, though really it's still the same exact game, I think most of the animations are the same, weapons are mostly the same with a few exceptions. I honestly expected an expanded story, maybe more adult with the Fable Fan Community now all grown up, no longer in their teens or childhood. Honestly I wouldn't really "recommend" this game, though it's an improvement from TLC, it's nothing new or different. If you already have TLC I wouldn't say this is worth 60 dollars, though it won't freeze and crash like TLC did often.OLD REVIEW: This is subject to change, since this is only the first day, but essentially it's the same exact game as TLC, only with a new GUI that doesn't allow you to use your mouse in menus, and a screwed up combat system. If you want to learn more I have a nice big rant in the forums. I just hope Lionhead fixes this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												UPDATE: As of 21/12/2014, the game is playable, even enjoyable. Most major problems and concerns have been ironed out and the addition of mouse controls in most menus (but oddly enough not all) has made this an actual PC port worth considering. With this in mind, I'm changing my review to a recommended. I will not remove the original criticism, though, as I feel the "release broken port, then fix all the faults afterwards" trend has got to stop, and we as the consumers have to tell the developers and publishers that this practice is not okay. TL;DR: The current state of the game is acceptable. What we got at launch, was not.ORIGINAL CRITICISM:If you thought the original port was bad, boy are you in for a treat. This game features endlessly loading textures, with the graphical fidelity of a game from 2006. The menus seem like they've been made by aliens with no idea of how humans use their hands, and the most annoying controls are not rebindable. I think this is a crying shame, as I loved the original as a teenager, but as an adult PC gamer, I'm insulted by the lack of effort made on lionhead's part, to make this remake playable on PC. The least they could bloody do is make the mouse cursor available in the game. I'M PLAYING ON A PC, WHY CAN'T I USE MY MAIN INPUT TOOL FOR NAVIGATING YOUR MENUS?That rant aside, just buy the lost chapters instead. It is at least playable, something that this remake is not.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												The probem with these hd remakes, is they never seem to capture the exact feel of the original game. Fable has a weird sheen over it now, but is quite lifeless compared to my nostalgia. If the cheap original has controller support, play that instead. (If you need controller support anyways) Sure it's fun for my faux OCD to collect achievements for a game that I beat 4 times 10 years ago, but its not as fun as I remember. I am spoiled by modern rpgs that do so much right, whereas Fable always faltered then, and still does now. If you loved the original (or even liked) don't bother with this version. It's not worth it. If you have never experienced Fable, jump right in. I'm sure its quite enjoyable, if a bit embarassing and antiquated. 6/10

												All the negative reviews on this game seem to be about a lack of added content... I didn't see anywhere in the description that they did anything to the game aside from bump up the graphics and add the hero mode. That being said, this is a great game, matches the first one (and TLC) perfectly. Being able to play a game i grew up with and the added bonus of the much higher graphic quality was very enjoyable. The people complaining about the lack of added content are all morons that can't be bothered to read a description before hitting "buy".TL;DR? Game is same as the one we loved with better graphics and a harder mode.... just like advertised...

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Fable: Anniversary is the bare minimum for what constitutes as an HD remaster. Sharper textures, better lighting and higher quality sound. The game feels and plays like the original game with the usual loading screens in between sections that you often see in games released back in the day. It's still the same old Fable at its core, but for some reason the developers made some pretty major changes to the artstyle which make the characters look a bit off. If you've never played Fable before then this is the game for you. If you, like me, have played the original Fable then this is just an okay remaster that does nothing better than the original. Hell, it does some things worse.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
  // RATIONALE FOR PURCHASE AND WHERE I'M COMING FROM //:   I played the original Fable to death on the original xbox.I played Fable: The Lost Chapters to death on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ old lappy from 2000 in my adolescence.I picked this up for the summer sale price of $8 USD.Didn't see this product at launch and it may have been quite buggy. Stayed away for a while as I felt my copy of TLC is all I needed, but the sale price seemed worth it at the time as replaying TLC with the dated visuals wasn't as appealing with this existing.   // EXPERIENCE //:  Nothing more than a HD remake of the TLC game in the Unreal Engine, but thats not bad by any means, just worth noting. Visuals are ok, but the animations for the most part have seem to have been reused, with only facial animations having a minor overhaul. The other animations sometimes clip through some armour sets and it detracts from what they are trying to achieve.Having played it recently, the game is reasonably stable, with a few very, very minor bugs. It plays very similar, if not identically to TLC.It mostly lives up to expectations and its quite enjoyable, but doesn't provide any new content above what was included in TLC. Some find that infuriating, I don't personally. However, I would welcome new content in the same vein as the original titles.   // BOTTOM LINE VERDICT //:   The remake is  worth a sale price value (e.g $8 USD)  ,   NOT    its current full asking price.If you've played TLC through and through, then the value of buying this is just updated visuals and I recommend  buying it at a low sale price if you really want it.If you haven't played TLC or Any Fable games, this remake will do the series as much justice as TLC, so the value to a consumer in this category is vast in comparison, however I still only recommend purchasing at sale price as I feel purely updated visuals isn't enough to merit the full price.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Fable is what I would call a fantasy classic: You, the protagonist, suffer hardship at a young age, and then learn the skills required to be a Hero (quite literally) and save the world. I have always loved the combat system of Fable and Fable: The Lost Chapters. It feels smooth, and is easy to master. Enemies are always going to be challenging and willing to punish you if you let your guard down. The Fable Series has long been one of my favorite, and I love this remake.However, there are a few flaws to this. Firstly (and the biggest problem) is the menu. Occasionally the menu will glitch out and either randomly start scrolling through whatever screen you are on, or it will try to prevent you from scrolling through it, constantly dragging your selector (is that even the term?) back to the top of the menu. The second flaw to Fable: Anniversary is the colors. The origional Fable and Fable: The Lost Chapters were these brightly colored places that captured your imagination. Now, the world feels dull and somewhat bland. However, the balance of the coloring it still good, and you won't be bored looking at the world after an hour.That all being said, I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to everyone, both those who have played the series since the first installments, and new players who found a sale going on.

												I played Fable on the Xbox when it came out. Playing this is quite a trip of nostalgia; so if you're like me and you enjoyed playing the original, this might be worth your time. If you've never played Fable, I wouldn't recommend picking it up now. The game's difficulty curve is laughably broken (even on the supposed "heroic" or hard mode), the mechanics feel double their age, and the story is nonsensical. It's fascinating to see how drastically RPG (and game design in general) has changed in the last decade-- so perhaps it's worth playing to quench some sort of historical curiousity. Even then, there are probably better games to play if that's your goal.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Fable is a decent enough game. Anyone who was playing on an Xbox in the very early 2000's knows how strangely disappointing this game was, due to good ol' Peter Molyneux and the Hype Train Express that he rides all over the place, but at the end of the day the game isn't necessarily bad. It is an enjoyable and simplistic RPG with a lot of great ideas that never really seem to be fully explored. It's the lack of exploration into these ideas that makes Fable strange, as there are truly a lot of really cool things in the game. It just feels a tad lackluster.Nonetheless, this is a great 15-20 hour RPG, worth playing at least once in my book. It's not very complicated, the combat is satisfying, and there are enough sidequests and hidden things to find to satiate most appetites. It is not an incredible or deep experience, but merely a game that is good-enough-to-pass-for-fun. There is an alignment system, you can give yourself tattoos or haircuts, you can run around on a murderous rampage if you feel the need, and you can walk around a town dancing and farting to please the locals. Go and get drunk in a bar, eat some apples, and beat up an innocent guy in town. Woo!For what it is worth, I've managed to beat the game three times, twice on the original Xbox and once just now on the PC. I've always enjoyed it, even if the game seems to come to an end a bit early.The PC port, as far as I could tell, was just fine. I liked being able to use a controller for this game, as I feel like it controls better on one. I didn't have any crashes or bugs, and it even alt-tabbed without a hitch. My six year old computer kept 60fps on all high details, as well. If you're looking for an interesting RPG to play through in 20 hours or less, Fable Anniversary would be a good choice.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Fable Anniversary is a great game with much better graphics than the original Fable, But you should also give this game a try if you are new the series. + You can make your own choices in being Good or Bad and the best part is that the sotry adapts with your choices wich makes the game have a great replayablity, because you want to try all the chioces. I have tried all choices in the game and with every choice you make there is always a something new to find out. This is what got me hooked on the game at the start.+ Story is great and the lore in the world of Ablion is good.+ The voice actors and the dialoge are great, This makes it really worth doing all the Quests because you want to know more about them or the story.+ The large variety of creatures in the world Albion are great with special abilities and combat styles to beat them, Though it gets a bit repeditive at the end when you have seen them all.+ The scaling of the combat and your Hero is great, if you want to rush trought the game it is gonna be hard, but if you take your time and learn more about the game.+ The are alot of extra Quests apart from the story that are great and will make you explore the things are Areas in the world witch you haven't seen yet.+ Boss fights in this game a great are unforgettable, and hard enough so that you need to have a stragery to beat them, if you don't know any OP combos that could make so the the fights really short.+ Nostagia, If you you have played this game before and wants to relive some of your emotions from the past. Just do it, the game won't dissapoint you.-+ The combat it self are Good but lacks more depths. It does have great variety but you will probably just stick the a few combos that are OP, But you could always roleplay and be and Archer, Warrior or magician if that is what you want.- Controlls from mouse and keyboard as default are awfull. I recomend using a controller or rebind the key so you feel comfortable. The Magic Scroll trought spells system is just a joke for the mouse, DON'T use it, assign the spells and skills you use the most to your hotbar or you will get frustrated.- The new graphics are poorly optimized but have been getting MUCH better with the updates to the game. If you have played alot of the original the you will be dissapointed by how ugly some of the heroes look compared to what I remember from the original. Jack of blades face and your face when you are a little boy.- Menu and inventory layout it BAD, It takes way to long to get used to find things in the inventory. Which might make some people not use it and when you have you will miss some of the quests because you will need to use thing from your inventory to figure out how to solve the quest.So, Is this game worth 32€?Almost, It is just like the the original game but with better graphics and I would say that the gameplay is a bit outdated.But when it gets to sale for 20€ or less this game is worth your money. ^^

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Back when Fable first released, I was young and owned nearly the entire series of nintendo consoles. But I remember wishing for the first time that I had an X-Box just so that I could play Fable instead of The Legend of Zelda. Eventually, I did get to play it, and now Fable Anniversary brings it all back with the kind of polish that makes the game stand-up to your memories. Will you be a shining beacon of hope to the people of Albion? Or will the bottomless depths of your darkness sew dread in their hearts? Containing all the content of the "Lost Chapters" edition, remastered HD visuals, and a new "Heroic" difficulty setting for verterans; Fable Anniversary is the perfect reason to either return to land of Albion, or explore it for your first time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												Fable is what I would call a fantasy classic: You, the protagonist, suffer hardship at a young age, and then learn the skills required to be a Hero (quite literally) and save the world. I have always loved the combat system of Fable and Fable: The Lost Chapters. It feels smooth, and is easy to master. Enemies are always going to be challenging and willing to punish you if you let your guard down. The Fable Series has long been one of my favorite, and I love this remake.However, there are a few flaws to this. Firstly (and the biggest problem) is the menu. Occasionally the menu will glitch out and either randomly start scrolling through whatever screen you are on, or it will try to prevent you from scrolling through it, constantly dragging your selector (is that even the term?) back to the top of the menu. The second flaw to Fable: Anniversary is the colors. The origional Fable and Fable: The Lost Chapters were these brightly colored places that captured your imagination. Now, the world feels dull and somewhat bland. However, the balance of the coloring it still good, and you won't be bored looking at the world after an hour.That all being said, I would wholeheartedly recommend this game to everyone, both those who have played the series since the first installments, and new players who found a sale going on.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Pros:-Solid remake of the original with updated graphics-Fun, whimsical atmosphere-Variety of weapons and armor sets to suit your character-Great amount of content-Fantastic story-Morality system that reflects your choices well-Modding supportCons:-No additional content in the remake-DLCs are overpriced and only offer armor and weapons-Very occasional graphics issues (her eyeball was clipping through the side of her head!)-Same old camera angle/clunky control frustrations-Fable: The Lost Chapters is available for $9.99 and is the exact same game, minus the graphics upgrade and mod supportOverall: This is the original Fable game.  If you haven't played it, it's fantastic, and worth the price.  Whimsical humor and deep gameplay make it a fun RPG.  Choices matter and change the way the world reacts to you.  There are several approaches to combat.  The voice acting is good.  The controls get a bit clunky no matter what version you have, but it's a small flaw in a large gem.  If you can get it on sale, great, or you can pay the cheaper price for the older version as it is the same game.Bottom Line: At full price, you should probably get Fable: The Lost Chapters, but this is still worth it even paying full price, as it stands on its own.  Get it on sale for the mod support and updated graphics, and support these types of projects!

												I thoroughly enjoyed Fable when it first debuted on the original Xbox. Gameplay feels somewhat outdated although it still fits with the game. If you missed it then, now is a great time to try it out. If you had already played it and can still remember the game you may want to skip as nothing else has really changed. content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												I was about 3 hours into the game as a first time Fable player. I wanted to see what the fuss was about, so I got the Anniversary Edition on Steam. Escorted some merchants, killed a cave troll and got rid of a red barrier blocking the way forward. Went to a previous map (the camp) to pick up the merchants. For some reason the red barrier was back, but the troll is still dead so there's no way to progress. The merchants even have a dialogue about that "rumbling noise" from a non-existent troll. I'm not about to waste my time back-tracking and re-doing a quest for a game that has had over a decade to have its bugs fixed. Wasted money, and lots of frustration trying this and that and checking Google for help. Fable may have been a cool franchise, and I wouldn't have minded giving it a shot, but I'm not about to wrestle with significant bugs from decades past.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												This is a great game to just relax to, I've seen people complaining about certain spells making it easy for the harder modes, if you don't want easy mode don't use those abilities simple, those abilities only really exist for those who really can't take the hits, and who are having problems finishing the game. If you are finding it to easy still all you have to do is just unequip your best gear. The game plays great with simple dynamics, which are easy to learn and pretty simple to master. Players used to Dark Souls and watching for certain animations, will find that for the most part you can still do that if you watch the enemies carefully (enemies will sometimes swarm you, and unlike some games won't take turns on you) You can always try and take out the ranged/summoners first, while dealing with some not all of the adds which they create.I enjoy playing this game, it's great for those who tend to get upset and angry and break stuff, this is one game where you probably won't really do that. Just your standard adventure button masher. Fun for the whole family.

												Despite having no new content I found myself enjoying the brilliance of the old fable again. This fable is the best in my honest opinion and it will take much to waver that opinion. The better graphics and controller support are fantastic, seeing how I played this gem on my old xbox growing up. Although the new reskins are quite bad on the main characters. Weird mishapen people giving off way more eye contact than nesscary. The absoulute best one I found was on Thunder, a large black hero. He, no joke, looks like a balck guy in blackface. Briar rose, a sexy nerd like hero in the original, killed my boner faster than the speed of light in the remastered. All-in-all, if you LOVE fable or somehow missed playing the original give this game a try, but only on sale. $35 is an outrageous price for a 10 yo game. I purchased this on the winter steam sale. number of helpful: 25 of 52 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												I have played and modded the original Fable, and I have to say that I love this HD remake. And now, that Lionhead allows us to mod the game with the Modding DLC, it's great! My review point to point:- Graphics. It's an HD remake of the original Fable, the graphics are really good, love that "Depth of Field" we have, the lighting, great too. You just have to see the images of the game :P Textures are great, maybe with mods they can even get better, same with the models. Some models have changed, and they got better! The animations, same animations as the original Fable, so... nostalgia :') Great effects too.- Gameplay. It's like the original Fable. I don't really like the movement of the camera, but it's still good.- Sound. Like I said with the animations, nostalgia when hearing the Fable music. The game has also the previous voice actors than in original Fable, and there is some characters that have a great voice acting! Also, the sound with the effects, really good.- DLCs, okay, some of them cost money and only add armours and weapons (which look great!), but for me, the good point is the Modding DLC. I remember modding the original Fable, and get desesperated because the tools (made from the Fable modding community) crashed, or the game crashed and you had to reinstall the game or restore it with a backup... Now that we have these tools, we can mod the game. Still waiting for a Steam Workshop for Fable though :)I think I haven't forget anything :S.In conclusion, Fable Anniversary is a really good game, that have great graphics for the game it is and respects the original Fable things. Great game!

content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												Fable was always a treasured memory for me. So when I heard tell of a remake in the works I quickly pre-ordered with all the DLC (like the massive nostalgia-sucker I am).If you're expecting all-new quests and gameplay mechanics, look elsewhere. This is a faithful remake with beautifully tacky voice acting and broken economies aplenty. You can do all the things you used to do, fight all the battles you used to fight and listen to people call you chickenchaser in just the same tone they used to ("do you chase chickens?"), but now it's actually making use of the full-HD monitor you have sitting on your desk. This was simply a nostalgia trip for me, and that was all I ever expected.The heroic mode is hard, and that's what was always missing from the original TLC. Real challenge has been added and that is welcome. The new costumes and weapons are fun, tiered well and implemented just fine.Now the bad:Most noticible for me were the incredibly jerky animations of the chests opening (of all things) and the entirely unintuitive menu system. The old menus were quick to navigate, efficient and fit the character of the game nicely. The newest ones are clunky, space-wasting and actually hard to navigate (even with the added mouse support!). I dreaded upgrading my character for fear of navigating the quagmire of poor design decisions and rudimentary grasps of UI design.Overall this was fun to play, particularly through rose-tinted glasses. And despite the menu issues, it still feels untimately like Fable. Maybe not worth £27+DLC, but certainly a good one to get on sale!

number of helpful: 15 of 32 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												This is a fantastic remake of a classic game, worthy of anyone's Steam library!Having only played the original Fable incredibly briefly at a friend's when it was first released, I would still consider myself new to the Fable series.  It has always been one of those games that I've meant to play, but when I first heard about the HD remake, it seemed like the perfect time to actually do so.  First off, the game looks lovely - you only have to compare the visuals from the 2004 release to those in Fable Anniversary to see just how much of an improvement this release offers.  It really brings the game to a standard where you can play it today and it doesn't feel dated, and all without losing the original charm and style of the 2004 game.As a new player, I've been really enjoying Fable Anniversary - the game feels open enough to give a sense of exploration (the side quests, mini games etc.) but has an interesting and engaging primary quest that keeps you moving forward.  RPG levelling is there and, whilst it might not be as complex as some RPG games these days, I like that I don't have to spend hours in the menus worrying about to which of the tens of attributes I should be allocating my experience!  It's a great adventure game, and one that you can just pick up and enjoy when the mood takes you.  For those who loved the original, I think you'll enjoy rediscovering a game that you played perhaps ten years ago in beautiful HD (or 4K if you're lucky enough to be an early adopter!).  Get it!

number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Few hours in, and looking at reviews here it looks like I'm the only one who wasn't severely disappointed.  Yeah, that first trailer with a bunch of people typing chat messages to one another did little to sell this one.  Yeah, the graphics are a lot less improved than I had believed.  Yeah, I preordered this largely because I thought I was getting some one-time shot at bonus content that you couldn't buy as a $5 DLC.  Okay, a little let-down, but it's not a terrible remake so far.  Some of the characters faces have gotten uglier than the first Fable tho.  Was that intentional?  I really expected Briar Rose to be more, um, appealing, given her self-absorbed attitude, and Mace to look less like he's lost some fights with his food processor.Thus far I have played this with a controller, and have had no crashes, no issues, no glitching.  Not even the ability to buy a crapton of apples and buy/sell them for infinity money and archery exp.  Well, I guess they did fix some things, even if they kept some dumb game mechanics like having to murder people to buy their houses.  "Sorry I had to immolate you with magical fire so I could buy your house, but Bowerstone doesn't allow weapons, y'know...  Hey, I'll use your future rent monies to buy lots of tofu and it'll all be okay!"  Actually, now that I've played a bit more, it turns out you can still amass a small fortune by selling and rebuying 50 health potions.  It's a dumb mechanic, but it does remove any tedium from earning money.  And pretty much any meaningful value to the stealing skill.I have not yet dived in with my trusty mouse and keyboard, but so far so good.  Their latest patch, while fraught with complaints about the size, does seem to address issues I've seen reviews complaining about, like keyboard and mouse remapping.  What's not to love about a developer supporting their game?  Bottom line: maybe not enough improvements to make this worth all the hype (and price tag).  People can complain about how they loved some of the mechanics of 2 and 3, but if you absolutely have to play a female, go play the game that allows it.  Fable was a great game, and this seems to be at least as good, if only ever so slightly improved in graphics.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												What's amazing to me is the amount of people complaining about the game so far for reasons I don't see as legitimate. A legitimate complaint would be why they're charging 34.99 for this, when Fable TLC is only 9.99. An illegitimate complaint would be all the ones I see about the controls.PC Master Race people, this is a console game that was ported to PC. And there is absolutely no reason they should have to go the extra mile to appease you. The mouse and keyboard were not designed for gaming, a 360 controller was. And as such the keyboard and mouse will ALWAYS be inferior for controls. Unless the game was designed for PC first, which Fable Anniversary was not. Accept that the PC has flaws when it comes to gaming and lower your impossible standards and you'll all enjoy games a lot more. And if you can't handle the fact that your chosen method of playing games is flawed then it is no one's fault but your own. Sorry to burst your little bubbles but PC gaming isn't as perfect as you all like to pretend it is. Especially when the game in question is a port from console.And I know what you're gonna say. "The game should have been designed for PC first" Well it wasn't. And no amount of whining (And that is what you're doing, whining, because you're not getting everything 100% your way) is going to change that. And you have no right to criticize the developers for putting their game wherever they like. Because it's their game.Sure, the menu system sucks with a mouse and keyboard, but it wasn't designed to be used by those. And I imagine the developers have better things to do then tool around with this game for the 3rd time just to make a couple of idiots happy.If you can look past the assinine control scheme (Like me, because Fable is really damn good) or have a controller to play with (If the game supports it), I think you'll have a good time with this, it's just Fable TLC with an new coat of paint, and that's all it was ever meant to be.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												My first Fable experience was Fable III, on an x-box loaned to me by my son when I blew my PC up early this year. I had all his games to chose from, but only played that :)I pre-ordered this for my son and I, knowing he was a major Fable fan and I kinda liked it :) I read the reviews of others waiting for the download, and was a touch concerned. Nonetheless, I fired it up and got stuck in. My son was watching, telling me how much better everything looked. I experienced no lag apart from during dialogues, the "A" button doesn't always register. I've only played for 3 hours so far but it looks delightful. Maybe it doesn't have the famous cast of voice actors that it's sequels had, and the mix of accents were a bit dubious to say the least, but that can be forgiven.The most welcome feature for me is the x-box controller support. I have MS (multiple sclerosis) so KB/Mouse is impossible - my left hand only has a working thumb and forefinger. Even with the controller I have to limit my session times - a 3 hour session was way too long but I was in da zone :)I'm loving Fable Anniversary so far.

Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game holds your hand so hard, it threatens to break your fingers.Want the achievement for seeing the whole world without any actual work? Eat pies 'til you get fat! Several achievements make the game almost not even require another playthrough (I've beaten my old physical copy of The Lost Chapters more times than I care to admit, and it was a blast each time), which really tells you something about ol' Lionhead Studios (RIP and also LOL). The HD textures make everyone just as ♥♥♥♥-ugly as the original game, but now in HD, so you can look into their cold, staring, dead eyes as their mouths move in the same ventriloquist-dummy fashion as they do the exact same ten or so animations as they did about twelve years ago. The menus are a god-awful chore to navigate, and only for the sake of looking nice and being charming and rustic and cute and *vomits*.The combat is controller-snappingly frustrating (USE. A. CONTROLLER.), as enemies have finally discovered how to block, and also, how to abuse blocking completely until combat isn't even fun anymore.The fixed the Silver Key glitch in Darkwood. The ONLY thing they fixed, and it's the ONE thing I wanted to STAY broken.Also, the kid Hero looks like he is WAY too high to go get a birthday present for his sister.5/101 point for the music still being good.1 point for it still kinda being The Lost Chapters deep down.3 points because it isn't Fable III.tl;dr♥♥♥♥ this game, buy the cheaper/better/original version; and ♥♥♥♥ you, Peter Molynyucknyucknyucks, if you had just learned how to make a good game, you'd still have a ♥♥♥♥ing studio.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Those of us that were old enough to play Fable: The Lost Chapter when it first came out on PC should be feeling a sense of serious deja vu, and not just because this is a remaster. Just like the original Fable, Lionhead hyped this game as much as they possibly could. At least this time, they didn't make tons of outlandish promises they couldn't keep. Instead they promised a remastering of on of their best games, and instead it's just sort of...updated a bit. Now, I can't play this game on anything but its lowest settings because I am poor, but the immediate reaction I had when starting the game was, "What's wrong with the controls?" And then I was immediately repulsed upon seeing the face of the hero as a child. In fact, the entire population of that beginning section has some serious facial issues that made me worry about the game. With the ugly models and the wonky controls, the first half hour isn't very enjoyable. Luckily, as you adapt to the new controls (or get a computer controller) and grow up, the character models settle into their skeletons and by the time you graduate from the guild, the game begins to show its true colors. While probably not deserving of the hype it got, neither does it deserve the immediate bashing. Are there problems? Yes, but the original Fable: The Lost Chapters on PC had plenty of problems itself and unlike the original, this one is going to have some modding support and possibly patching. Even on its lowest setting, post Guild Graduation, this game is a beautiful reconstruction of one of the greatest examples of RPGs ever released. Just calm down, keep an open mind, and enjoy it for what it is, Fable's Anniversary.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												As an RPG lover who has never played a Fable game before (because I only had Playstation), hates playing PC games without a controller so I spent $40 on an Xbox 360 controller and waited 3 weeks for Fable Anniversary's PC release, I am pretty satisfied so far. I recognize that the gameplay could be smoother but it's not as terrible as I expected after reading some reviews by long-time Fable players and gaming experts.  The game is definitely playable, just not super smooth when the hero is running, etc. It took me a while to figure out the D-pad items/expressions feature, so that lack of instruction gets a thumbs down (I still don't know why my assigned expressions only appear on the D-pad screen icon when I hold Right Trigger and why certain expressions/items get auto-assigned to the regular D-pad screen icon and why I can't change *those*).I also think there should have been an explanation of the save system at the beginning of the game (or anytime!). I think I'm about to graduate from the Heroes Guild & hopefully I can save anytime after that. Despite the couple annoyances, so far this game has lived up to my expectations. I was hoping for a game like this that would give me future nostalgia, like I have for the old days of playing the Zelda and Final Fantasy series. I'm sure they'll release some patches to improve the framerate but I'm going to continue playing in the meantime; I think it's a cool game and so far, I'm hooked!

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Fable Anniversary is a great game!  That said, it is not perfect.  Overall Score: 9/10  My simple review breakdown follows:Pros: - Just like you remember the original Fable, except with better graphics.- One of the greatest RPGs of all time.- Steam achivements!  - Modding!- Classic gameplay.Cons:- Could have had spent more time redoing character motions and reworked their physics engine to make the game more fluid.- I hate to be cliche, but classic gameplay.  While it is a pro, it is also a con, because RPGs as well as all other games, have evolved.  I feel like this should have not just had new graphics slapped on.- No add in of previous Fable advances implemented into the Anniversary Edition?!  This is definitely my biggest pet peeve.  Lionhead introduced us to a whole new realm of customization of our character in Fable 2 and 3, and here we are, back at square one again without the ability to simply have different color hair.  It is my hopes the modding community comes up with a way to fix this.Overall, great game!  Still worth every penny!  Pick it up!!!

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												As an RPG lover who has never played a Fable game before (because I only had Playstation), hates playing PC games without a controller so I spent $40 on an Xbox 360 controller and waited 3 weeks for Fable Anniversary's PC release, I am pretty satisfied so far. I recognize that the gameplay could be smoother but it's not as terrible as I expected after reading some reviews by long-time Fable players and gaming experts.  The game is definitely playable, just not super smooth when the hero is running, etc. It took me a while to figure out the D-pad items/expressions feature, so that lack of instruction gets a thumbs down (I still don't know why my assigned expressions only appear on the D-pad screen icon when I hold Right Trigger and why certain expressions/items get auto-assigned to the regular D-pad screen icon and why I can't change *those*).I also think there should have been an explanation of the save system at the beginning of the game (or anytime!). I think I'm about to graduate from the Heroes Guild & hopefully I can save anytime after that. Despite the couple annoyances, so far this game has lived up to my expectations. I was hoping for a game like this that would give me future nostalgia, like I have for the old days of playing the Zelda and Final Fantasy series. I'm sure they'll release some patches to improve the framerate but I'm going to continue playing in the meantime; I think it's a cool game and so far, I'm hooked!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Alright, For those of you who are looking to buy Fable Anniversary because you LOVE Fable 1 and 2 or you are just looking for a new game to play, Dont look at the negative comments for this game because all of them are overlooking what is bad with that game instead of giving it a fair analysis, So here is my take for you guys!Lets start with the bads: YES! The game has some graphical issues, Initially the games motion blur on camera movement is horrble, But you can turn it off, And the colour of the game is too 'dark'. But again you can turn this off, I'll leave a "How To" at the bottom for you if you are interested The game lags or freezes alot and it drive people insane, But hey guys, Guess what, You can fix that too! jusy Verify the Integrity of the Game Cashe before you play it, It takes a few minutes, But its way worth it! No mouse to operate menus, Yeah thats a bad thing I guess for a PC Port, But its really not ♥♥♥♥ing hard to use Insert, Home, Del and End to scroll through a menu, Is it?Id say thats all for the bad besides just a few little things like hit boxes on the terrain being a little too large or something silly like that. So onto the good things! In all this  game is FANTASTIC and I love the Fable franchise, I even like the shocking abomination that is Fable 3, But this game is great Once you tweak a few things here and there the game runs smooth and you can play to your hearts content Hit up the graphic fix by following the section below and the game is beautiful, Its bright and every works as it should!There I'll leave it on a 3 to 3 basis, Because it really isnt a big deal that the game is a little unpolished, It has the same issues as the original from 10 years ago, It just looks a bit prettier, Thats all, Personally, I think they shouldnt have dont Anniverasy and just let Fable: The Lost Chapters on here and Fable 2 and 3, But hey, This is great and once you get used to the quirks of it, Its great, Ive played for 20+ hours now or something and I am loving it! Hope this helps And that it isnt too muhch text for my fair opinion and non pompus accusation! Graphic Fix  Go to: Documents\My Games\UnrealEngine3\WellingtonGame\Config Then open WellingtonSystemSettings with Notepad Then change AllowRadialBlur to false and change DepthOfField to false too Then TADA, Game looks fine, Happy Adventuring!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Ignore those tipping their fedoras in disgust. As you'd expect, the game (almost completely) replicates the TLC version of the game with slightly better graphics. Those complaining about lag/frame-rate problems must have some sort of hardware issue (most likely down to their gfx). There are plenty of reviews on websites such as IGN and YouTube and I'm sure that most people should have an idea what they're actually paying for. The game has only just been released and modding has yet to achieve one of the main reasons why you have probably purchased this on Steam, rather than a console (that is if you own one). Whether there will be any new (official) DLC that was not in TLC, is completely a mystery, although one thing is almost certain.  Modders will most likely do so.If there is one thing I would have to criticise about the game, it would be how easy it is to exploit stores to make money. If I had realised, I would've chosen to play at the Heroic difficulty from the start, rather than do a run-through on the original difficulty.All-in-all, I've most definitely enjoyed the game so far. It is what it is. I highly recommend using a controller (preferrably a Microsoft Xbox pad) due to some apparant issues there may currently be with using a mouse/keyboard. The port isn't as 'horrendous' as people make it out to be, although saying that, it could have most definitely have been better.To round-off this review, I'd like to say that if you are curious about buying the game, please do check out reviews/videos online rather than just insta-buying the game and then complaining because 'you thought they'd have improved it more'. 7/10

												I can't say I won't recommend this game since overall the game is enjoyable if you don't encounter any freeze or bug.There is a lot of complaining so far and I support almost all of them still the game is the same as Fable:TLC and other than the crappy menu and lack of keyborad/mouse option, the control inside the game are the same they were and if you use a controller you won't notice it. Graphically the game got a decent update but still could have been better. The visual might be good on the xbox 360 but on pc it suffer for a 2014 remake. The texture need better resolution and too much bluriness not sharp enough. During the playthrough I have encounter invisible wall over a little rock in the middle of the road when normally you could pass over it. The character model are a bit strange espacially the face.The game could have been way better if it wasnt only visual remake of the original. They should have corrected the bugs and even mix a bit of fable 2/3 in it to give it more a feel of a new game. Even if I will pass lot of time in this game like I once did in fable:tlc, it will need some fix and some update texture to give it a better feel. Maybe the modding community will make it honor.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												If you like chasing chickens and enjoy murdering villagers while chasing chickens, you'll love this game.Short review:Game has flaws. Keyboard and mouse controls work as well as Dark Souls. Graphic options are limited. Sound works. May crash, may not. May also stutter with certain hardware. Unreal game so you can tweak anything.There are certain flaws that a lot of people pointed out already but it's not that bad, A few people like myself can play this game no problem. I play with a controller so the mouse and keyboard controls don't bother me as much. I bought this game knowing it would be a console port so keep that in mind if you're interested. The game runs smoothly and I've only had it crash every few hours. Hopefully they'll fix that soon but the game saves frequently so it's not enough to cause me much anger.If you're not a fan of the Anniversary remake you probably won't like this either. The PC port is the 360 version with tacked on mouse and keyboard controls. It feels a lot like Dark Souls. It's rough around the edges but a good game if you play under optimal conditions(using a controller for ex.). Don't expact anything but a console port though and you'll find some enjoyment with this version. Keep in mind there is the original Fable on Steam too if that's what you want but it lacks controller support and that's actually one of the reasons I bought the Anniversary version.I'd recommend this to anyone who's ok with console ports, if you're not don't buy this game. Also it helps if you're a fan of the Anniversary remake because you know.. if you're not then why are you here?

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												As a huge Fable and Fable TLC fan, this is a great additition to the collection.  I had not yet played the PS3 or 360 version so I can't comment on the increase of quality (if any) over those versions.  What I can say is that I am thoroughly enjoying a re-textured HD Albion from the best title in the series.  I have yet to try the hardcore mode, but if you are looking for a Darksouls experience then move on.  Fable's charm lies in the characters, environments and quarky comedy that the game does so well.  Yes it is easy, but it is relaxing, fun, and thoroughly enjoyable.  If only they woud make a Fable 4 as a prequel to this game (during the age of dragons maybe?) with the same style and feel that made this game great.HUGE NOTE* Play it with a gamepad.  As a PC purist, I still have my wired 360 controller for occasions like this and the game really shines when it is used (can't wait for the steam gamepad!).  I could see how the menu system would be clunky with M&K.

												Just like the old Fable we know and love Fable Anniversary is a better looking one, though some faces do look a bit off when you zoom in.  The menu gets some time to get used to but i would say its much easier to transverse with a controller (as it is a port from the xbone it is more bias to the controller).The dlc was a bit cheeky but as a fable fan boy i got it, and i had to read around to find out that the weapons and armor were added to shops al around Albion. the weapons aren't game breaking which i like as it doesn't give that pay to win feel, the many sets of armor ( some of which have set weapons ) do look good some are on the better end but not by too much. number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												TL;DR: Get it on sale if you haven't played Fable, or if you want graphical pretties. Keyboard+mouse be dun goofed apparently. ------------------------------------I was an avid fan of the original Fable and Fable TLC, and the remastered edition doesn't fail to disappoint either.PROS: - WIDESCREEN SUPPORT AW YISS. Getting the original to work in widescreen wasn't terribly hard, but it was still hackish and bugged at some critical moments. - Very nice graphics, they've predominately kept to the core of the graphical characteristics of the Fable series, but it's amazing what a fresh coat of paint (proverbially speaking) can do with a game. Fable has definitely aged well. - Modding support? I'll be curious to see where this goes, and from what I've read, we may end up having Fable Anniversary coming to the Steam Workshop. Can't imagine it'd be like a Skyrim, though.CONS: - No Borderless Window nor scaleable UI. Just a bit of a bummer that I can't have the window maximised since it then causes letterboxing and the like, and considering this is a UE3 game, I'm surprised that we don't even have a borderless window option, since I often alt-tab between windows and would rather have the game appear full screen. I've tried tools to force the borderless window but it doesn't work. - Some graphical glitches exist where objects won't receive light from nearby light sources, kinda kills immersion a bit but it's not a deal breaker by any means.ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT: - Mainly to do with the overall environmental lighting, particularly outdoors, but we could benefit from variations in luminosity, and actually be able to use the lantern at night, right now it just seems pointless to have the lantern since everything is so well lit. - Some head models can do with some improving too, the child Hero looks like he hasn't slept for a week, and Maze does not look like Maze at all, his characteristic stern look got ruined by an elongated, pudgy, wrinkly baby face with tattoos. |:I can't speak for the copious amounts of people that have whinged relentlessly about the whole keyboard + mouse thing, I do remember playing Fable TLC with a keyboard and mouse and it was working quite fine, though since then I've been playing games with a 360 controller, and naturally given Fable Anniversary was originally made for the 360, it still feels pretty good to play with. I did try playing with the keyboard+mouse combo, but quickly switched back to the controller. :PHaven't played through Heroic yet, but that'll be the next step.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												The best source of chicken chasing in videogame history. Fable Anniversary brings you back into the world of Albion that we visited so long ago. A genre defining title that created a perfect balance of fantasy rpg elements and simplicity. While the game might seem simplistic in respect to a traditional rpg or the story cliched you will find yourself coming back for more again and again. The anniversary edition adds many great features besides its remaster, including easter eggs and small content additions mainly aimed at the original players, as well as mod support. While the game launched with some major issues, those were fixed relatively quickly and I would highly recommend this over "The Lost Chapters", unless of course you're a big fan and played both that version and continued to replay it with the anniversary edition. 8/10.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Judging by what it was, and not what people wanted it to be, the original Fable the Lost Chapters was excellent, and is one of the most defining games of that generation.Fable Anniversary retians everything you loved about the original; the humor, the combat and spells, the alignment system, and all those goofy little quests and tasks. But the video quality is updated massively; the models are much better, and the textures really pop as opposed to the original. The draw distance is greatly improved, allowing you to see your enemies much farther away now too, which can be helpful. Also the audio is improved too, but its hardly noticable honestly, given that so much of your attention is usally focused on the game itself.Achievments now come with it too, giving incentive to finish all those things you never did in the original, or just giving you a reason to finish them all over again. Inluded in those is one for finishing the game on its newly implemented "Heroic Mode," which among other things, removes exploits, makes enemies harder and removes resurrection phials, allowing for a much more difficult experience.The DLC for this game is nothing more than custume packs, which are fun to use, but a little pricy. Still, even these costume packs can add a little more to your experience without feeling out of place from the original, and can also result in hilarious screenshots.All in all, it's a fantastic way for fans of the original to experience it all over again, and for people who may have skipped it to reconsider and give it a go. It's by no means one of the best RPGs ever made, but its certainly unforgettable.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Fable Anniversary is a great remake of an amazing classic.I also feel the huge ammount of complaints some people have been having with this game to be very negligable.Negligable Complaints: Art style, A lot of people were expecting a more realistic art style for the game instead of a slight cartoony/fantasy look. I feel the art style the devs used works VERY well with the game, and increases the ammount of charm the Fable games give, so far everything I have seen looks asthetically pleasing.Not RPG enough, If you have never played a Fable game, you MUST realize before playing that this game is NOTHING like an Elder scrolls, Dark souls, or Witcher game. Fable is VERY casual in comparison, and doesn't take itself nearly as seriously. Despite there also being a harder difficulty to choose from than normal, the game is still very much casual.Real Complaints:The AI, The AI of a lot of the NPC's in this game is very clunky, and a bit buggy especially when trying to get people to follow you. Bad cut scenes, During a lot of minor dialogue cut scenes, everything in the background seems to stop moving except for you, and the NPC you;re talikng to. This can lead to some very distracting, or awkward backgrounds with NPC's just frozen in the middle of an activity. Also the audio during chapter progression cutscenes is very low quality, and even crackles at times like the original game.The $35 asking price, $35 dollars is just way to much for ecentially upgraded visuals, and audio especially when the original, and its Lost Chapters DLC are available on Steam as well.Over all though this game is extremely fun and very replayableThe Achievments are also a nice bonus, especially since most of them leave you with two different methods to unlock it, so the path / play style you choose won't impact if you can earn the achievment or not.

												*IMPORTANT NOTICE MUST READ!*Please, do not listen to the lists of negative reviews!The heavy hitting issues have been resolved and the minor ones are being worked on, and for the product it's self...Fable is a very unique game and remains fun to this day (The original was released in 2004) This game is truly a landmark in the RPG genre, the mechanics and gameplay remains untouched by it's sequels despite being outdated per se I would reccomend this game to anyone.On to the new stuff, the improvments to the Graphics and Lighting are indeed incredible! (Dont worry, not at all complicated like Dead Rising etc.)10/10 - One of the greatest games of all time.
