content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												It all depends really. If you nitpick every little thing, then what game is "recommended?" Not, I'm not going to go to the extreme and say it's amazing or it's terrible. To me, it's neutral. Is it a good port? No. Is it "terrible?" Again, no. After the dissapointment of Microsoft allowing Dead Rising 3 to be ported to Steam and that being horrible, why was everyones expectations for this so high? With that said, I will point out some flaws about this. Key bindings are there, but not for every key, which people are overreacting about because the keys themselves are fine, except for the blocking, which is the mouse wheel, and that's a bit weird but when they're physique shield and flourishes, who needs to block or dodge? Are people complaining about it because they WANT it changed or because they CAN'T change it? The FXAA does make the game a bit blurry but from what I can tell, it wasn't THAT big of a deal but I can understand some annoyance out of it. The HD graphics are improved a lot since TLC (obviously) and I saw a Total Biscuit review saying something about a door's resolution being lower than everything else... Really? A door? If it was something majoy like the NPCs, or weapons that's fine. But a door? C'mon... No mouse control in menus, frustration is somewhat understandable, but to me it seems more or less people not wanting something changed a bit, pushing a key instead of a couple of mouse clicks, again, seems something stupid to argue about. Performance issues, only problem I've had is in the very beginning as a kid in Oakvale, everything else I get 45-60 FPS with dual Radeon 6770's. All that being said, the game is still as fun as TLC and you get better graphics and higher quality sound. If you're going to nitpick every little minor thing about this game it seems more like you're trying to criticize everything rather than play an old nostalgic game with bumped up graphics and sound. If you're really complaining about it because "it's not worth the $35" then wait till it goes on sale this winter, it's gonna happen.

I haven't had any problems with the menu's in game or movement and visually this game casts a shadow over the lost chapters and the xbox original. If your a bargin shopper christmas is coming and we all have wallets that will hurt afterward this should go on sale by then.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												Splitting this into 2 parts, Review of the game itself and then the enhancements.The actual Opinion is right at the bottom if you want to look and if you don't feel like reading through detail.The game sets you out as a little boy, who has his home town raided by bandits and then saved by a mage known as 'Maze', He then makes you join the Heroes guild, a small guild dedicated to raising people into heroes so they can help Albion, from there it's a very big adventure. Now first off, it's not Elder Scrolls big, there are certain things you can't do but can do, It's between massively open and limited, You can marry, have sex, Buy houses, kill townsfolk (Good luck fist fighting in Bowerstone), Open secret doorways to treasure, buy houses in the towns of people you kill, become incredibly evil or incredibly good (This affects your appearance massively, Evil causes you to lose hair, grow horns, create an evil aura about you and causes your hands and feet to become demonic, while being good causes you to emit a good aura about you, grow white hair and have a Halo above you), but you cannot customise appearance at the start (You can get a haircut, get a beard, tattoo's, become fat by eating too much, becoming good/evil, old, Muscly and scarred), you cannot create your own adventure, your name is always 'Hero' and titles you can buy, Not immersive that highly and do all that creating weapons (There is more but I didn't want to keep this going forever).Now is this like Skyrim? Certainly not, the only reason I compared them with openess because everyone recognises Skyrim as the big RPG. It's a medium sized fantasy RPG action game, most people would think that because it's a fantasy RPG action game, it's similar to Skyrim, however it has it's own unique style, instead of being an entire fantasy world populated with elves, orcs and all that, It's basically medieval britian with magic and monsters, Does this ruin the game? No, not at all, for the time it was a incredibly refreshing change from Orcs and Elf fantasies (Still is).The combat for this game is quite basic, You have heavy weapons, light weapons, Bows/Crossbows and magic, Basic combat stuff like Swing, Block and a heavy attack, Heavy Weapons are incredibly sluggish to use (Don't expect to use them right away until your Physique is high enough) while light weapons are quick (No Dual wielding), Bows can be used to engage fights from a distance at first so they come to you, however headshotting an enemy will do high damage and can instantly kill them if strong enough and magic is something you can use to get around enemies, slow time, do deadly AoE attacks or summon/turn enemies against them. Leveling in this game is hugely different, in fact, leveling doesn't exist, you get EXP drops from enemies you kill or quests you complete, and you spend them at the guild to upgrade your magic, your skills (Speed, accuracy and guile) or upgrade your power (Health, Physique and Strength), killing enemies without getting hit will give huge boosts to EXP drops so make sure to be quick on your feet. Now for Actual opinion, The game is quite a great game, despite the series never living up to it's expectations, it's still a great game and the beginning of a great adventure, the story does better than most RPGs and keeps you invested to the end at least, the world is quite a lovely place, the gameplay is basic but good enough to get through the game, the music is absolutely gorgeus and the setting is amazing. Easy 9/10 for me Now is the graphical enhancement worth it? It looks very beautiful compared to the old game, no edges seen, but it isn't exactly todays standards but still nice and it's definitely as I remember it, the only issue I had with this was the menus, some of the layouts weren't that great but the UI is definitely improved, The only issue I have with this compared to the old game was nagivating through the menus, it was a bit of a chore to do, but they seem like they will be fixing that eventually and they are planing to allow more mod making soon (Currently it's just small things).So I do think this game is worth it if you are an RPG fan, it does it's job of entertaining you from start to finish and does contain british humour every once and a while

												I must be honest, I bought this mostly for the nostalgia factor after having played through Fable many times on the original xbox. Don't let the negative reviews fool you, if you were a fan of Fable in the original playing through this will be bliss.I can't speak of the keyboard and mouse controls as I used an Xbox 360 Controller to play and would recommend you do the same. Why anyone would want to play a third person game with a mouse and keyboard is beyond me.The graphics have been mostly improved. The only downside I would say is some of the bright aesthetic seems to have been lost which is a shameThe sounds haven't been changed but don't feel poor quality. You'll love hearing "Hero your will energy is low, watch that!" The first time you hear it again and then hate it every time afterI love the achievements they have too. Both interesting to achieve and full of funny references. "There's always a lighthouse" is a memorable example. A lot of achievements have two ways of getting them too which is nice.Overall, if you played this back in the day and you want an updated version, definitely get this. The combat isn't the best in the world at times but if they updated too much it would've been a different game. If you've new to the series, this is by far the best and is miles better than 3 (2 is pretty good, but is also Xbox 360 exclusive, which is a shame) so don't hesitate in getting it. I was put off by all the negative reviews but took the leap and love it all over again

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												I don't know what major issues are being experienced but apparently from reading the reviews on this page there is a slue of them. I haven't had any problems with the menu's in game or movement and visually this game casts a shadow over the lost chapters and the xbox original. There was added content but nothing that really matters because this is a HD remake not a reimagining or a retelling, personally I think that it is unfair to demand even MORE of a dev after they've already ported it once and now again. The game includes mods support with the engine editor so any problems to be had are going to be fixed whether we like it or not which is far and beyond what a lot of other games on steam can boast about. I've only just started it up and can't seem to replicate the issues so take this review for what its worth. This game probably won't have a good mouse and keyboard support because it was never intended to be played on a pc without a controller, they aren't even that expensive. The issue in the end isn't the game its the coddling of the players that is absent that seems to upset people and that doesn't lend to fair judgement of the game. tl:dr - if you like fable / lost chapters, get it. it looks amazing it has all of the replayability and it has the editor. If your a bargin shopper christmas is coming and we all have wallets that will hurt afterward this should go on sale by then.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												This is my first in depth review of a Game here on Steam.I'll divide my review into the typical; Good, Bad, And Ugly.I hope you find my review helpful in more way that one.Good: Graphics overhaul;The graphics were improved drastically since the release of TLC. Lighting was improved, as well as minor details such as foliage, bumpmapping on armour and weapons. The character models recieved smoother animations, along with better voice recognition so the character mouths don't look so rigid or twitchy.  The lighting and shadows were also improved to give the overall look of the game a much greater atomosphere.Sound;If you notice one thing like I have, it's that most, if not all of the original sounds, from combat, ambient sounds, to the sound track, sound exactly the same as they did in the original and TLC. I'm glad they decided to go this route as to keep a sense of nostalgia. No use redoing what you already had done, right? Now don't get me wrong, a lot of the voice acting in the Original Fable along with TLC was attrocious by any means. They could have gone out and tried to rerecord all of the voice acting, but it's been several years since the original voice actors recorded. Also, it wouldn't be much of an "Anniversary" Edition with different vocals. I'm glad they decided to keep all of the original voices, because it brings back memories from when we played the original and keeps continuity.Mod Support;Lionhead has gone out of their way and addedgiven us a completely modable version of the game, even though it is quite limited as of right now. Just think of wht people could do. They could add entire new quests, create new weapons, new spells, new environments, and a plethera of other content. I'm waiting to see what the entire community has to offer .Now for the Bad.Keyboard And Mouse Support;When TLC launched for PC back in the day, it had a UI designed for PC users in mind. The in game menus had mull mouse support and you could rebind keys to fit your unique play style. This time around, they developed the game with Console controls solely in mind. Annoying and trivial key presses to navigate the menus, keys rebinding themselves or failing to bind after changing them(in my experience.) It's almost as if they want PC players to go out and buy 360 controllers for their PC's just to play this game. I hope they're able to fully reimplement Mouse Support in the coming updates.Paid Addon DLC;I can't really understand why they are doing this. It seems as if they're taking a page straight from EA's play book when it comes to addon Content. $15 just for some extra weapons/outfits that aren't even better than what you can find already in the base game? I can maybe understaing having maybe a season pass if they were to release some extra story missions, or even to have you play as another person in a paralell story. But that wasn't the case. Last but not least, The Ugly.Reworked facial models;I can understand revamping the textures and models to utilize the newest technology, but they blew it when they completely recreated facial modles for most if not all of the main characters, including The Hero. All of the faces we grew to love and hate were completely scrapped and the one's we were given weren't all that good either.Character Progression;Yes, The same hack and slash/Grinding for Experience mechanic is still there, but there was no deeper involvement than that. The same body types, from Slim through Obese, are still the only options. In some of the preview videos for the skill trees, The Hero can be seen as a person with near body builder proportions. But we don't really see that in the game(at least I haven't, if there's something I'm doing wrong in game, please let me know.)This concludes my in depth review of Fable Anniversary. I would recomend this game to anyone enjoyed the first one who is looking for a visual upgrade, just don't expect anything spectacular. *This review is based soley on my personal perception and experience in playing the game. This review is not based on numers or facts, just opinion.

Posted: November 20, 2014
												This is exactly what the players have asked for for so long. A  "HD" remake of the fantastic game that was Fable. If you've enjoyed the fable games in the past and want to relive the old adventures of the first fable game (Looking slightly better) Then there's no reason for you not to play this. Yes it has some DLC's but nothing that is needed, if you don't enjoy DLC then don't get it. By all means this is a great game and worthy of sinking lots of hours into, exploring and getting to know the characters, but bear in mind the original game is now getting quite old and therefore might lack in content compared to modern AAA titles.  It has a captivating story and entertaining characters with lots of classic british humor thrown in here and there.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												I love the Fable games.  I bought The Lost Chapters (TLC) when it was released on steam out of nastalgia, but never got aroun to playing it.  Since this was an update on that version of the game, I came into this game blind to the changes that TLC made. I was disappointed at how many poor review this game was being given right out of the gate.  I preordered it, and was thuroughly enjoying it on release day.  I believe they did a wonderful job with this game, and were still patching any errors and exploits that were reported a week in.Personally I dissagree with the primary comlaint that was being given in the first week.  That complaint being about poor keyboard an mouse controls.  The original game was designed around a controller, and required significant changes to work intuitively with a keyboard.  They attempted this with a modicum of success, but as with any game that is designed with one control sceme in mind, they do not translate well.  I would never dream of playing this game without a controller, so in my opinion it is a moot point.The addition of a harcore mode was interesting.  It did not add much challenge though.  I almost never use potions, so the lack of resurection phails became the greatest dificulty.Overall I enjoyed this game even more than I remembered from my playthrough of the original.  I would recommend this game, but would also caution those with a tight wallet that there is little difference between this and TLC.

												This game is one step up from the original Fable TLC. Many will hate this game if they prefer using Mouse & Keyboard, but if your like me, were you like both and keep both at hand then this game is an excellent buy. I was going to play this game with a controller just like I did with the Xbox Original and I really loved revisiting everything with an amazing upgrade on graphical power. The great glitches that I abused along time ago; some are there and some are gone. I have found no bugs that have really caught my attention. The game has also been updated non-stop by Lionhead, probably trying to prove that they do want to create the game that all users were hoping for. The game recieved bad reviews because of the lack of mouse support, but I'm sure that with an update with mouse support will turn all those reviews around to a positive. Obviously this game lists it self as Full Controller Support just like other games that have limited keyboard+mouse functionality, but most purchasers that complain about mouse support are ignorant not to realize that. If you are up for a trip back into the past revitalized then this game is perfect for you. Lionhead has put sufficent enough effort into recreating this game, but realize that this is just a remake. Which means no extra content other than small dlcs they released it is only updated graphical wise, so before you buy know that you are buying a copy of a game that is only graphically updated not content wise.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Fable Anniversary is exactly what it says on the tin: it's Fable: The Lost Chapters with a new coat of paint. The game looks good, performs great and, most importantly for me, has great controller support.A lot of the negative feedback for the game is based on the sorry state of its initial release. Most of these issues have been resolved in later builds, including adding mouse support, more logical keyboard inputs, better keymapping and better performance. I personally play the game with a controller and think the implemented support is superb however I can see how M+KB players would have been put off by the game's initial state. There are a few notable changes; Hero Saves are gone and replaced by a Checkpoint system. This has advantages in that it's much easier to pick up a mission where you left off, rather than having to plant yourself once a quest begins and hope nothing pulls you away. Unfortunately, some of the old exploits are now gone as a result of the change -- you can't decrease your age, you can't farm for experience by Hero Saving mid-mission, you can't get both of the "either-or" items in the game (Bright/Dark Will User's Hat, Sword of Aeons/Avo's Tear.) Overall, these were exploits so while I miss their inclusion, I don't think it's a straight negative for the game. In addition, the game now has a Fable 2/3 style control scheme. This works rather well, though it's largely not a significant advantage and comes with its own issues. You can't use your Fists since using X or Y (on a controller) automatically unsheathes your Sword or Bow, respectively. More importantly, Will users are significantly less flexible as they can now only use one spell at a time, having to cycle through each individual spell rather than cycling through groups of three and using a button to cast the appropriate spell. It's problematic and for most users, the Traditional is probably the best option. For users who focus almost entirely on Melee/Archery, however, it can be a boon. Overall, the game is faithful to the original and that's what you're buying -- the original game with enhanced graphics and Xinput support. I got the game on sale and think I got my money's worth, given that I'm a massive fan of the Fable franchise and the original is still arguably the best. A chance to replay the game with rose-colored glasses firmly in place is definitely worthwhile for me. P.S. Lipsyncing helps the dialog look a LOT less wooden. Very good move on Lionhead's part.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Since I wrote my original review, there have been patches implimented into Fable Anniversary Edition! The game comes off as more stable, but still has rendering issues in the Arena when it comes to the cut-scenes with the hero, audience, Jack of Blades, and Lady Grey scenes. I also am confused by the system used to assign keys for the D-Pad. I assign them, but cannot seem to use them. Those are my only urks at this moment.Aside from the urks of rendering issues with certain points of the game, Fable feels like the original. The game-play is very smooth with the XBox 360 controller and the Fable 2-3 controls (unless you are assigning to your D pad, as mentioned before). The game matains the feeling I had with the Original Fable and Lost Chapters versions of the games and gives you a nostolgic feel when you play it.If you are a big Fable fan, and can get past the issues of rendering delays, and the D-Pad issues, then I would reccomend the game! Despite the flaws, it is still a lot of fun and a great trip down memory lane for those who once played it on the Xbox. There is much the world of Albion has to offer you, once more!If you cannot stand those problems I listed, I suggest waiting for more patches or look into getting Fable: Lost Chapters instead (You cannot play that version of Fable with a gamepad unless you get a seperate program that allows it. It is a strictly a Keyboard and mouse version of the game). If you are still on the fence, the best I can tell you is to wait for the game to go on sale and take a chance on it.As for the DLC, you do not need it. The DLC only gives you the ability to BUY the items in game, and they items are insanely expensive or hard to find. I was hoping we got the items off the bat once you became an adult, but nope. Unless it goes down to super cheap, I suggest you save your money and play the game as is.

Posted: November 18, 2014
												The majority of these bad reviews are when the game first launched; the the devs put in a ton of patches to fix those complaints and those reviews are no longer accurate. That said, did you like Fable TLC? Yeah who didn't. You'll probably like this too since its the exact same game, but with updated graphics, sound, and price. If thats worth the $20+ extra this costs over the original then absolutely pick this up. I have both and this is the superior version, but why wouldn't it be though? You have to pay extra if you want to fly first class.There's a reason this game was remade, and thats because it's an awesome rpg. You have your standard classes, archer, mele, mage; you can mix and match abilities and weapons to cuztomize your battle abilities as well as a bighuge amount of sweet looking gear which is mainly aesthetic. So if you want to run around in a robe and carry a giant axe you wont be gimping yourself too bad. This game isn't exactly difficult anyways so just have fun doing your thing. All in all, I absolutely reccomend this game. If you can't afford it pick up the original. It's only a few bucks on sale and will provide a couple dozen hours of chicken chasing fun.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Long Version (Short at the bottom)It's a great remake of the original game with updated graphics and the optional use of an Xbox 360 controller. I'd recommend this to any fan of the Fable series. It's a fun world with interesting lore and decent gameplay, but the nostalgia is what is going to sell this. If you already own Fable TLC it's still worth the purchase because you can use the Xbox controller on PC, not to mention the modding support that has arrived along with the Steam Workshop.I have two complaints about the game and one is the zones being seperated by loading screens. When this game was released it was impressive to have a world this large and it was neccesary to have each zone seperated like this, I was hoping that they would remove some of these. My second complaint about this game is the DLC, especially considering what it is. I enjoy the armor and weapons they've created in these DLC packs and they look great in the revamped graphics, but the amount of money you're asked to pay is ridiculous. 15 dollars for the Heroes and Villains pack seems extreme as well as the ten dollar Scythe content pack - both of these content packs should be reduced by at least 5 USD considering these are all only cosmetic items.Short VersionGood gameplay, graphical update, and remake alltogether. Brought down by the pricey DLC and the constant loading screens.Overall - 7/10

number of helpful: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												Generic story, generic world, generic characters and very simple, basic gameplay. Press the attack button to win. I was mashing x on my 360 controller the whole time and had no problem with any enemy. And then getting the solus greatsword halfway through the game which is the best weapon in the game and maxing out my slow time ability, my god. They updated the game adding a higher difficulty in response to how easy the game was. The problem is they couldn’t balance it. They added tougher enemies, for example instead of normally fighting wasps in the starting areas you are now fighting against bandits that kill you in three hits instead of eight or so. This would have been fine but the combat mechanics are not built for higher difficulty because of how basic it is. There is only one attack button and there is no way to predict enemy attacks like in dark souls for example so the enemies attack animation hits you in less than a second and takes of half your health bar and blocking and dodging is so clunky it’s not even worth it. So you have to choose either one of the easiest games of all time or really unfair difficulty for the sake of it being difficult. I mainly focused on the main story because I wasn’t into the game much to do much of the side quests. The main story isn’t very long took me 10 hours to beat. I could not get into this game at all I thought everything about it was so bland, basic and dull. 4/10 (Mediocre)

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
Fable Anniversary ReviewOverviewFable Anniversary is the remake of Fable: The Lost Chapters. With Fable Anniversary, many promising changes are made, and many disappointing issues surface from its predecessor. I recommend this game for these reasons:GraphicsIn comparison to Fable: The Lost Chapters, Fable Anniversary's texture work is massively improved. All the textures from the game, from doors to wall textures have all been reworked. An issue that I've noticed is the AA used in the game; FXAA. FXAA is most likely the worst type of AA avaliable from the numerous other offered AAs, such as SMAA, or MSAA. With FXAA you have a smaller performance hit in comparison to MSAA. FXAA is a fast solution to AA but massively degrades the visuals of the game as it blurs, and washes out the textures of the game. Unfortunatley, you are not given the option to change the type of AA within the options menu. There is, however, mods out there to disable the AA used in  game. Character models is a hit or miss really. Character meshes have been completley reworked to showcase HD textures. However, some of the models are completley off putting, especially the children's. I really did not have an issue with the character models, but it may be for others. Controls I recommend not using a mouse and keyboard for this title. It seems that little effort was put into the binding of the controls in Fable Anniversary, in comparison to Fable: The Last Chapters. Lionhead has consistently updated the game with changes to the control schemes for the game. The menus are now fully controllable with the mouse, and more keybinding options have been unlocked for customization. Even with these changes, it's very awkward to play with KB & M. I highly recommend playing this title with a controller, it is much more predicatable, and fluid.  GameplayThe gameplay is the same from Fable: The Lost Chapters. In Fable Anniversary, a new mode is available called Heroic. It is a bit of a increase of difficulty from the standard difficulty of the game presented in Fable: The Lost Chapters.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I am pretty surprised at all these negative reviews. I really don't see what the big fuss is. Self-entitled kiddos is my guess... Anyone outside of that should be ashamed of themselves for acting like one.To be honest, I wasn't wanting additional content. I wanted a Fable experience exactly how I recall back in 2004. On those grounds, Anniversary delivered tremendously.Fable was a staple of my young adulthood. I beat the thing 20 times before Anniversary released, and after recently purchasing the original TLC for the PC; I really suffered through not having controller support. I ended up using Xpadder, which really sucked due to limited movement.The added controller support, along with a redesigned UI really addresses the weakpoints of the original game.The game plays on a completely new engine - Unreal 3, which makes it look incredible. That, coupled with the massive effort to retexture the game really gives the graphics a kick to make it competitive with current releases.Fable Anniversary also features an audio overhaul, where some parts have been completely redone. No more out of sync voice overs with the character animations!The majority of people downing this game are ignorant. I've watched people of the community refuse to buy this game for petty reasons like no more silver key glitching with hero saves, or no ability to play as a female. Those are features that were purposely left out because they weren't intended in the original game. These idiots are seriously bashing the game because they fixed bugs from the original...Overall, if you enjoyed the original game, then you are bound to enjoy Anniversary. As a Fable series enthusiast, and longtime fan of the game; I can definitely say that Anniversary's graphical rebuild does the original game justice. The added controller support and UI overhaul really make the game a much smoother experience on the PC!It was just like experiencing the original game for the first time again - and in my opinion, you really can't put a price on such a great feeling of nostalgia.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												This game is horribly British.But that's ok! In some universe. It's also a console port so get ready to deal with awful menu controls. They patched up most of the issues (oakvale lag, no enter button on menu) and fixed the blury issue. It actually looks pretty good, and the art style will begin to grow on you. By the end of the game, I actually loved it and started taking screenshots.Character growth is nice and the ability to still hit achievements from both evil and good sides of the ball is great. The combat is fun and engaging. Even if you're into only one style of combat (ranged, melee, magic), you'll eventually earn enough XP to flesh each system out enough to make them all useful in different situations.The game is well written. It has some pretty comedic moments, some "hard choice" moments, and no matter what you're not stressing about right or wrong you just play it and do. The concept of your player changing by way of decision making is fantastic as there isn't a right or wrong; it's just exactly what it is.The map is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible. The menu controls are ♥♥♥♥ing terrible. The auto target is ♥♥♥♥ing terrible. Vendors are awful. Some quests are bugged. But what do you expect from a 10 year old game? They did a great job rebuilding the world and modernizing its appearance but it still suffers from old world bugs.It was worth playing through the bugs and any action-RPG fan needs to give this a good play through. Waiting for Fable 2 (on PC).Edit: turn off vsync in game, use a forced vsync from your graphics card. You're welcome.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Fable: TLC has been my favorite game for years. After beating Anniversary it makes it right around the 20th time I've played it beginning to end. For people new the series or if you skipped the first one, there's no reason not to get this instead of the original. For those that played TLC and want to know if it's worth upgrading, I'd say only if you're at least some what as obsessed with it as I am.There are a handful of problems with the new game, but it's been made clear Lionhead is doing their best to patch it up as there have already been a few patches since release day for the PC version. So, in terms of general bugs, I'd call it a wash. That said, by the time I finished the game (Sept. 18, 2014), these were the bugs/glitches/annoyances I didn't see mentioned in any patch notes:- chicken kicking competition has really, really fuzzy scoring. Your chicken could be a pixel off the white score label of a square but it still counts as the next point zone. Still doable, but annoyingly when you know you scored 5 50 point kicks to get the top prize but you only get 2nd.- the pub games controls are way, way more sensitive than I remember.- This is really just a complaint from the original game, too, but having to hit the Knothole Glade mayor 50 times to finish the fist fighter's club quest, but he only has to hit you twice, is still my least favorite part of the game.A note about some bad reviews and complaints I've seen: Although the minimum specs are low, to turn things up you'll still need a decent rig. I think a lot of PC players forget that these days the minimum requirements means "you can run it if you turn it all the way down." Recommended also doesn't mean you can jack it all the way up, it means "the best experience STARTS here." Granted, my system is relatively beastly compared to the average Steam user's system (according to the Software and Hardware Survey), but with my i5-3570k, 16GB RAM, SSD and GTX 770 it ran at a buttery smooth 60+ FPS the entire time I was playing with everything turned all the way up.So, if you're able to ignore all of that general moaning about bugs that are being fixed and people that don't understand that their computer is kind of junk, the only real problems with the game are two fold:1. This is a console port. It's, honestly, one of the best console ports for this kind of game I've played in a while, but there are draw backs to it. You always (at least kind of) feel like you should be playing with a controller, which doesn't bother me but will bother some people. If you bemoan console ports because you feel like you need to feel surperior to console games, you'll be all bristly the entire time you're playing. If you're a reasonable adult that enjoys playing games on PC, you might be mildly annoyed at worst through certain parts. Note: I'm somewhere in the middle. I hate the typical fascist PC gamer, but that doesn't mean I can't be all "come on kid PC master race gtfo" sometimes.2. There are needless, dumb achievements. I'd like to believe Lionhead was forced to implement them to begin with because it came out on Xbox 360 first (related to my first problem with the game), where games are essentially, if not outright, required to have them, so they just kept them in for the PC version because the work the was done. It still feels like it dirtied up the game though.I enjoyed it, and I played the original, non-TLC version on the original Xbox 2-3 times, the TLC version on original Xbox about 5 times, and TLC at least 10 times on PC between my retail copy and the Steam copy. I'm perfectly happy having paid for this game a fifth time, apparently.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												(Updating due to fix by player Diggler)Apparently the Bright Will, Dark Will and Assassin outfits cause the game to lag horribly. Something to do with the capes. Ever since wearing different armor the freezing and stuttering have stopped entirely. Also recommending the game instead of not recommending as it's not entirely game breaking.(Updated at escorting trader to orchard farms)It's become almost unplayable at this point. Every other bandit I attack the game freezes and audio loops. Must keep going..This is disappointing. I first read from a friend who gave a bad review saying the cutscenes were buggy. I was hoping this was an isolated issue or an issue with her computer. Sadly, it's not isolated. For the first 10 cutscenes or so it will freeze or stop for no reason what so ever. This isn't an issue with my hardware and I'm not the only person to experience this. Whenever I use the Lightning magic on more than 3 enemies the game will freeze and the sound will loop for a good 10-15 seconds then cut back to normal. I'm doing my best to avoid being a parkinsons Senator Palpatine with stuttering issues.Apart from the terrible performance of the game and the sub-par graphics improvements (lol improvements), the game is fun. I'm enjoying it as I've already paid for it. I'm not about to whine over trivial issues and not enjoy the game I've paid for in advance. Lots of nostalgia! :D That being said.. I don't recommend this "hd remaster". At least not until they fix the cutscenes and horrible performance of the game. P.S. After getting past the guild introduction quests and venturing into the world all by your lonesome, the cutscene stuttering/freezing isn't as bad.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Fable: The Lost Chapters has always been a favourite of mine and has a very special place in my heart. Fable Anniversary is, basically, exactly the same, but with several key differences.Let's start with the obvious: Textures have been massively reworked, giving wonderful eyecandy while preserving a Fable feel. That's the main selling point with Fable Anniversary. It really does look great, although I was a bit iffy about Chicken Chaser's new textures at first, but then I realized that, when he got old, he didn't exactly look old. And that was what I modded out with the original Fable, so that was an issue that I felt had been very well hurdled over (and I'm not the only one who wants their character to appear young for the game). And the not-so-obvious: The developers chose to keep the mouse out of the menu interface. And hey, that's not a bad thing, so long as it's done well. Unfortunately, it's not. With the layout of my computer, it took a fair amount of time to figure out how to properly traverse, and even then I was unable to move left in the prime categories due to the menu deciding I wanted to select instead of move left. Usually, these issues don't annoy me, but when I accidentally make a mistake by moving too quickly in the interface and go one more right than I had intended, so then I have to exit the menu to begin trade all over again, it begins to wear on the patience a little bit. In this case, the original's menu was much better with the layout, and it had the use of a mouse.The characters and environments, however, do look excellent. And while sometimes there can be minor issues in conversations (like mouths moving but no words coming out) and camera focusing for cutscenes, I personally can overlook it because of my love of the original game. I also enjoy hearing the original voices and am glad the developers chose to simply carry them over instead of get new voice actors. Then again, it's hard to replace someone like Maze or Jack of Blades.So, if you've ever played the original, I do suggest this game. The menu can be trying but I find it's worth it. And if you haven't jumped on the Fable bandwagon yet, this is a great game to start, so you can properly appreciate the lore in the sequel. But if you have the original game already and are iffy about purchasing, I'd suggest waiting for a sale. Believe me, you're only missing the pretty colours.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Is this the "real" Fable? Yes, yes it sure is. It is the same good old game in a fancy new suit, and that doesn't have to ba a bad thing. I have always liked the fable series and I view the first game as the best in the series. As such, I have been waiting for this tirelessly since I heard that it was coming to pc.Is it a good port then? It is now. It had its fair share of problems at launch and during beta - loss of audio at random places mostly. The mechanics are unchanged since it's the same game in a new engine (if I have understood it correctly) and thats a great thing! You have the option of playing it with the old xbox-controller layout or with a new, And i really recommend playing with a gamepad.Is it a good reskin? I say that it is. It looks great! you can recognize the effects from the original, which I think is important, but still see that it really is made in a modern engine.Something I don't really like is the addition of new items that mainly seem to be for "fun" and are essentially microtransactions to buy new costumes. There is a sword that is supposed to react to silver keys, but any guide on the internet make it unnecessary and saves you a few bucks.Over all, would I recommend it? Yes. Absolutely it is still one of the best examples of a good rpg with wonderful voice acting and a great sense of humor. Not to mention that it is very satisfying to pop guards heads of with a bit of chain lightning.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Never played Fable? You're in for a classic treat with a wonderfully applied, new coat of paint. Played the original, years ago? You're in for a nostalgic treat with a wonderfully applied, new coat of paint.Welcome to or welcome back to Albion. In either case, Fable Anniversary welcomes you with a wonderous world, filled with quests that are, at times, as crass and humerous as they are fun. New players will feel at home with a solid control scheme, while long-time Fable fans will recall Anniversary's scheme from Fable 2 (which can be switched back to the original Fable's scheme). As you're questing, farting, and chickin kickin', you are bathed in one of gaming's best soundtracks, which will leave you whistling it's tune long after you've turned the game off. And, finally, PC purist, fear not. Fable Anniversary plays as good as it looks (which is pretty damn good). I'll post my specs below, but I haven't discovered any errors since launch and the devs have been quick and reliable with patches and feedback.Whether this is your first time, second time, or whatever time entering or re-entering Albion, you are bound to be pleased. I have been a fan of Fable since it was called "Project Ego" (yeah, I'm getting old...), but this long-time fan is very much pleased. It was exciting replaying a long cherished part of my childhood through a new lens. Graphically speaking, I'd say that the acorn that was the original Fable has become the lovely tree that is Fable Anniversary. ;)Specs:AMD 8350 4.0ghzGTX 680 2 gigs of vRam16 gigs RAMWin 7, 64*Played with Xbox One controller*

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												This game is awesome.It can only be defined by that word.It's true, people complained at the launch for the existence of quite a big amount of bugs, and they kept whining about the "crappy console port" thing. But thats besides the point.Lionhead did an EXCELENT job. They fixed all these bugs and glitches (most of them), in the first month of launch, wich is insane. Now, you might be thinking, why'd they launch it before then? They did it for you guys. Let's face it, everyone would be mad if the game got delayed. And even though it came out like this, what counts is the finish, and at the end, the game was amazingly well made.As a previous player of the lost chapters, I can say this game has an astonoshing storyline, filled with many goodies and endgame side quests you can play after the game ended. It has a great deal of minigames and stuff to do, so you'll never get bored. It makes you feel awesome.You can also make your own path, wich makes it even greater, you can decide to be evil, and let the story envelop through your evil acts, or be good, and have the story become the path you want to be. This remains even until after the end of the game :)I have to give this game a big 8.5/10, yes it's true, some content could have been added. But it was a remaster, not a remake, and some things could've been better, but I bet alot of companies couldn't have done better themselves, since this is a huge game, and a legendary title.I was also a proud beta tester, and I can say, yet again, Lionhead is a great company, and has great employees, they read almost every forum post, and every bug report you can say about it, and they will most likely not deceive you.I reccomend this game to anyone who likes these types of games.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Absolutely nostalgic and fantastic. Not the best rpg you'll ever play, but a damn good one. If you had the pleasure of playing the first Fable game or the extended edition Fable: The Lost Chapters, you love this game just as much as you did the first time you played it. While it uses almost the exact same game mechanics as its older form, it doesn't feel that ancient, nor as sluggish and static as the older game feels in this age. The graphics and UI have been updated beautifully, though the UI could have incorporated more/better sorting mechanics. Players of the original Fable will definitely be able to tell that this is pretty much a gorgeous paint job on an old car, but you won't care, it's the same ride that took you wherever you needed to go and you'll love it no matter what. For those new to the franchise, you'll still enjoy this fresh look on an older rpg that still resonates with today's games. Fable Anniversary is far from perfect, but all in all marvelous and just as wonderous as Fable was in its prime.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												I had never played Fable before this Anniversary Edition. I'm torn, I think it's a really good RPG in many ways; A good amount of abilities and almost no filler fetch quests. It also has a kind of comical charm about it and is quite funny at times. Other times this same quality can get on your nerves, the voice acting gets irritating and all of the expressions you can use are obnoxiously juvenile or corny. I appreciate that this is an older game and the first in its series, but there are issues here that are grating. If you are using a controller the button options are quite irritating (why can't I have toggle stealth and a range of spell hotkeys/buttons at the same time?), however if you prefer keyboard, the customisation is much better. The menus are just miserable, and in RPGs menus are important, this is bad.However I have fun with this game, despite its flaws, and that's the main thing. Would like to see the sequels on Steam to see if the series has improved.

												IMO:Not much of a change from the origingal, besides the obvious hi definition models and textures.A bit of a let down in that sense, but I'm rating it up because I love it and I'm an avid supporter of the first Fable over the others.Just don't get your hopes up that theres immense amounts of new in game content, that'll only come once the epic DLC and mods are released.Still quite buggy, I experience a few crashes, occuring when you load a previous save.Looking forward to some new content, until then, I'll be kickin' chickens.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												EDIT: I thought after almost 50 hours I'd add some more detail to my review, for those complaining about keyboard and mouse issues, I can't imagine how this game could be enjoyed without a controller. I do have to say I probably enjoyed it more as I haven't played this Fable before now, only the sequel I can imagine anyone who has played through this a few times like I have now would see improved graphics as not much of a change but you are paying for the rest of thegame too..All I can say is the bad reviews are way too biased.. I don't imagine remastering is some small feat and this has been done rather well with Fable Anniversary. I'm a huge Fable 2 fan, I've wasted many an hour gaining my halo, horns and cool glowing blue lines so I went into this expecting that to have ruined this experience for me, boy was I wrong, for 2004 this game is outstanding, the story is rich and full of twists, the characters have, well, character and the alignement options and side quests allow for hours of extra fun. Yes they are still working out some bugs but what do you expect? Even then you still have no room to complain, it's completely playable. I'd say if you're a fan of the other Fable games and not played this yet then go right ahead, it's worth every penny in my opinion. I know my review is slightly biased but my game experience has been an enjoyable one and I want anyone considering buying this to see what they are missing out on. Your's sincerely, Arseface.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I've not plaied any of the Fable series before this one, and I must say this game was well made with quite alot effort and precission. It's a classic ARPG game put in a 3d world, where you need to complete certain quests to get along with the storyline. I've got used to gameplay quite fast, either with keyboard or gamepad. At most i've liked beautifull landscape, where you walk arround trees on an adventure, and feel like you are in some kind of a wonderland - just beautifull. Also there's a narrator that often commentates when you need to acquire some items or when you've finnished the quest.There's also several outpost camps with different merchants(traders), where you can buy goods for an exchange of your gold you've collected through the game.Fable Anniversary is definatelly worth buying if you like to play this genre of games. Buy this game as it's definatelly worth it's money.

number of helpful: 11 of 26 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Being one of the few have actually played this game for more than an hour before judging it, I have to say that I'd definitely suggest it for any fan of the Fable series. Fable: Anniversary is Fable: TLC brought to life again with new colors, animations, and items that still represent the quirky, bright style you've come to expect from the Fable series. In addition, there is a new Hero Mode exclusive to PC, art and animation is fully moddable, and there is a very dedicated developement team that has been working for months to get the game up and running, with the help of beta testers who's feadback has definitely been an influence on the product now present. I have never once had any issues with Anniversary since I downloaded it, and it has definitely brought me many hours of joy.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I would not recommend this game over Fable: The Lost Chapters, all it is is a graphical upgrade, no new mechanics, no bug fixes, nothing new that makes it worth the extra $24 you would be wasting on this over TLC. While it does look nice at a glance (and admittedly the glamour shots on the store page), in game it doesn't seem very good. While all the models and areas are remade, it all seems the same as TLC, they didn't even to redo the intro cutscenes, so they are very low-res and compressed while the rest of the game is HD. The animations each character does seem to be mapped to what seems like the TLC models and not the new Anniversary models, making the other cutscenes even worse to look at than Sonic Adventure's terrors. Now it might seem I'm making a big deal on graphics and animations, and you may be like "What about the gameplay? Why are you just comparing to TLC constantly, can't you judge this as its own game?". Well to answer your questions, the gameplay is exactly the same as TLC, the graphics and animations are the only thing they "changed" in this. Now if I were to judge as its own game, I would maybe say it's pretty ok, except for the weird animations and it will definitely not have aged well in a couple years (heck it doesn't even look that good now). But since this is a remake that is THE EXACT SAME GAME as the original game with a graphical upgrade, A comparison is all you can really review it on. And in comparison, TLC is better, though the graphics don't hold up as well to this, they have aged considerable better than this has in only 2 years, gameplay is the same, bugs are the same, story is the same. These were the reasons I found myself asking for a refund after such a sort playtime, I had seen all I needed to see and it wasn't worth it even if it was on sale. Just take your money and get Fable: The Lost Chapters, you'll be much better off.

												This is rediculous... the combat is awful, the camera worse. Sometimes Enemies can be focused on, sometimes not. If you're moving whilst casting a spell your whole movement gets srewed up, making it impossible to dodge enemies or even move slightly past them without getting stuck in the super tight paths.This whole Situation gets only worse by thinking of how restricted one is in the matters of movement itself. "Oh, wanna dodge an attack splitseconds before it hits, but you're casting a spell? Well f*** you!"Moving through a fight in this game is like trying to fly a solid rock. In matters of controls, this is even worse than playing dark souls with mouse and keyboard.I can live with the crappy graphics, the restricted magic, and even with the bad timing in fights... but to load into a map and watch your character get killed by some freaking bandit because he suddenly just stands there by f***ing chance tops it all, I'm done with this sh*t.For f***s sake, I'm furious.sh*t game.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Did you love the original Fable? Are you satisfied with a visual and audio upgrade with the improved comat from its successors? This is absolutely the game for you.Where Fable 2 and Fable 3 largely failed is they lost the awe, wonder, and atmosphere that was so vibrant in Fable. Decisions were truly reactive with everybody judging you and your choices truly impacted your image and how you were perceived. Mixed in with an iconic soundtrack, classic British Dark Humor, and plenty of unforgettable moments, this is truly a jewel amongst RPGs.Even if you did not play the original Fable, I strongly urge you to buy Fable Anniversary, especially while it's on sale. It's better than its successors and is an experience everybody should try if they are an RPG fan.I didn't (and still don't) see eye to eye with Peter Molyneux on many things, but this game truly was a masterpiece. Enjoy your journey through Albion. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Before being disuaded from buying Fable Anniversary by the countless bad reviews, try comapring the time spent by playing by the people who didn't recommend to the people who did. It's important to remember that this is a remake of a console port. That said, if you buy Fable Anniversary without having played the original and you are expecting a AAA RPG adeventure prepare to be disappointed. Very few things are changed from the original game, aside from the visuals, and aside from the addition of extra weapons and armor from the pre-order bonus, there doesn't seem to be much in the way of rebalancing, save for the addition of the "Heroic" difficulty. Most people's gripes with the game seem to be from the controls and lack of mouse support in the menus, my recommendation is to have a gamepad. Believe me it will make life a lot easier on you.Storywise, the game is unchanged from TLC, become a Hero, take on quests, discover the secrets to your bloodline and the power that awaits you. Same old, same old.Visually the game does indeed look better than TLC, except for the face gen they used. Half of the NPCs look like their eyes are trying to escape from their head (lots of derp faces to be seen). The game does look more dark and grim than it did before, where it was more cartoony.Your biggest foe in this game isn't going to be the bosses or the small hordes of enemies, instead you will find youself fighting with control over the camera. If I can say anything bad about this game, it is that the camera controls have not aged well AT ALL! The bad camera controls are especially noticable in locked-on combat and questionable angles while you're gambling.Performance wise, the only real issue I have with the game so far is the occasional audio stuttering, my friend didn't seem to have this issue so it might be isolated to my rig, but it's still something that bugs me.Also if you're an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥, 18 hours of play was all I needed to get 100% of the achievements, so there's that too :P.

Not all of us want a locked up peice of slow hardware thats only useful for one thing! Thank you!

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												After 41 hours, I can safely say that I absolutely recommend this to any and all classic Fable fans. The developers have been on the ball with patching some of the launch teething issues and now we're left with a wonderful love letter to the original title, that has hugely improved graphical quality whilst not sacrificing any of the classic gameplay or style. The initial issues (such as hard freezing due to physics calculations) have now been fixed and a lot of the keyboard & mouses issues have been remedied too, there's still no mouse-controlled menus - which is really inexcusable given the engine this is running off and the original game it was remade from - but if you're not averse to using a joypad, then you can have a great deal of fun with this.Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Fable Anniversary PC - Acquiring Avo's Tear 

			Views: 212		

			It's quite simple, really. The only hard part is you must finish the original part of the game first, throw away the Sword of Aeons, and begin The Lost Chapters before you can claim this sword.		

This game has been awesome! I got it for $14 with a coupon, and it was worth every penny. No, it's not optimized so well that it feels like a brand new game, but if you were a fan of the original, you should love this! Apparently, there were some game-breaking bugs when the game was first released on PC, but with my main system, I haven't detected any problems. The game looks much better than the original version, and I ran on max settings at a constant 60 FPS. When trying to play on my Surface Pro 2, the FPS did studder a lot, making it an unenjoyable gaming experience, but the SP2 only has integrated graphics. If you have a dedicated gaming PC, you shouldn't have any problems running this game.I just finished my first playthough of the Anniversary edition, and it was thoroughly enjoyable. The only annoying thing was the load screens, but they were quick, and only interrupted gameplay momentarily. I didn't encounter any game-breaking bugs or glitches. The graphics look great, compared to the original game. Compared to modern games... they aren't that great, but they are certainly better than tolerable. The video I posted above was to show how the graphics look.If you're a fan of the original game, this version is a must have! If you're a fan of the series, but never played the original, this is the version you should play it on.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Honestly, I have played the CRAP out of TLC. I've played this game for quite a bit of today and have come to the conclusion that most if not all of what these horrible reviews are saying is not the case. I have a mediocre computer, nothing special... this game has not frozen for me once, it has not demonstrated slow load times or high FPS or ANYTHING of the sort. This remake is more than worth it if you're a big fan of the original.To be completely honest the ONE problem I have with it is the clunkiness of your characters head movement. (Which was always clunky to begin with, but now with the updated graphics it just looks ridiculous at times). I quite frankly love the game already and yes, the menu navigation is a bit ridiculous but at the same time THOSE THINGS ARE NOT "GAME BREAKING" like others have tried to tell you.All in all it's still a great game and I would highly reccomend it if you want an updated version of the original, oh... and yes... Maze IS white.Pros:-Beautifully updated environment that actually took me breath away when first walking into Albion.-All the core elements have not been altered to the slightest degree. (Disregarding the menu interface)-Great game with hilarious puns and decent action that has the potential to keep a fan of the genre hooked from start to finish.-No frame rate problems as of yet, -Modding support? Yes please.Cons:-Clunky player character head movement.-Menu controls do frankly -SUCK-.-The main character's face is now ugly as all hell.There you have it, no misplaced hate... or misplaced love... just my honest opinion on what I think of this remake. Still a great game and I look forward to finishing it.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												Let take a look at what Fable Anniversary did right and what did it do wrong. I will be reveiwing the game in a pro/ con style where i will try to give as much detail as i can with the game.Pro:   The game has a really nice atmosphere. When playing i felt as if was playing a game like The Legend of Zelda Orcarina of Time. That really was cool to tap in to that sense of how similar in hero stories both are.   If playing on chicken mode, the player can easily take on any challenges without much worry since that mode has many features that are gone on heroic. Such as the ability to get money really easy, revive potions, more hp, and the ability to take more hits.   The achievements can be earned in diffferent ways, not all achievements but a good number can be earnd one way or another way depending on what the player chooses. One example was either winning the archery competition or pulling the sword from the stone nets the player the same achievement. This is awsome since it doesnt necessarily limit the player to do any thing specific that they wouldent necessarily do. Some people are either mainly archery or strength builds.   Lots of content for both a good playthrough and bad playthrough. Note that there isnt much of a major difference but it does have some minor changes between being good and bad or whatever choices you chose in specific moments. They give dialog difference for the most part but can not really do anything majorily different. For an example i could kill wisper in the collesum or just leave her to live and after that nothing different besides dialog is different.Con:   Enemies can easily block attacks and swing really fast. Thats ok if they do that only if i dont get major stun lock.   Major stun lock. Like the point above the game has some major stun lock on the player himself far more than the enemies they fight. The collesum is the worst part especially when fighting the 2 trolls or gollems at the same times since if you get hit once better have your fingers crossed that you dont get stun locked to hell. I got stun locked so bad that i went from max hp to near death 2 times with no ability to change the outcome.   The game at points does not explain things well. This goes for things like how to upgrade the archery skills and magic skills since the game doesnt tell you that 1 you can upgrade those skills in the same upgrade station and 2 the buttons to press to change the skill sets. I know it is simple but it is worth noting since the rest of the game explains things in good detail as to what this does and how to use it...ect   Heroic mode makes getting money hard and causes an entire skill to be useless. I played heroic mode and thought it was ok for a hard mode, especially since it is hard to get money but heres the issue; there is a skill that helps with getting money that even if you upgrade provides no help what so ever. If it does nothing then why not delete the skill for that difficulty, sure it has a stealth ability for that one stealth section but really it doesnt help much at all in that aspect either.   This game isnt metal gear solid so why do i need to stealth? I dont mind the option to stealth given if i want to be that player but it is a mechanic used once and done. It isnt even a good mechanic so why is it here? I know Orcarina of Time had stealth mechanics but that works since it wasnt a one and done thing. Also since i am talking about Zelda and stealth it worked in that game because it was for the most part simple and was not a huge deal since one can do it very easy since we can knock out the guards and pass through will ease. It isnt a big deal for this game but it is just an awkard mechanic to have when it is only used just once.    The inability to abbandon a side quest. Sometimes when your not carful which side quest you choose you might choose a villain side quest which again doesnt mess with your moral very much at all but can really be annoying if you realize that you are going to kill guards or civilians making an area pretty empty later. This causes you to avoid the area like the plague but the problem is sometimes you need to go to the area to go to another area to do a main quest item. Which means the player will need to kill the guards and civilians to be able to travers in and out of the area without having to load a previous save. If the player could return a quest to the guild to abandon the duty then awsome. I wont have to worry about killing innocent people when i am trying to play a strictly good guy.     Players can get villain quests at the guild...a guild full of heros. That is just akward and can cause people to acidently choose the wrong moral quests.      Rpg elements mean pretty much nothing. As a maxed out hero i can be easily killable reguardless of how much damage resistance i have or how much strength i have. Some enemies take alot of hits not counting the big enemies but the normal minions. What is the main way to survive is to focus on weapons and armor. Kinda makes the whole idea of leveling up pointless in some way not counting the accuracy, speed, and all the magic skills pretty pointless.     Wonky hit detection. Sometimes when you play the game you will take damage even though you dodge the arrow or sword swing. It is akward and can lead to some unfair deaths given the situation.     The flopping hero (lol). At times when you take a hit, your character will be locked in place while the enemies move freely. This may be a bug or glitch but it is an annoying issue i ran into many times while playing heroic mode. Since the enemies have free movement they can constantly hit you while you can obviously do nothing. After the game releases your character from being immoblized, he will flop multiple times which looks funny but wastes time and can lead to more damage being taken or being stuck in a stun lock.     Some bosses are just broken. Being broken doesnt mean unbeatable but just a real pain to fight because they have the ability to use magic. I dont mind that if it didnt do so much damage and they were always attacking which makes getting a hit in a real chore. The main one i feel is broken is the final boss since he has this magic ability to suck all the hp from the player. I dont know if this is just strictly heroic only moment or not but it is broken since the hp drops very fast and you die. It is unfair in the sense that you can not dodge it and if you dont have any healing items then your dead. The boss isnt too much of a trouble but that one move can make or break ones experience since it doesnt allow equality in other circumstances where people are low or have no health potions. All the other bosses you have a chance except maybe maze since he has the lightning spell that auto locks on which is again broken since you can not dodge unless your behind and object.   Archors can pre-aim. So if you turn the corner in a hallway and get hit by an archor immediantly passing the corner. That is unfair since the player has no chance of avoiding it unless they dodge roll pass the corner but still there is a chance they will shoot it after the roll animation which will cause a hit. Not just that but enemies can fire arrows at you without looking at you. It looks funny but again can be really broken since if the player doesnt know that this can happen then they will get hit thinking they can rush the enemies to attack with the sword.Conclusions:    Fable is not great of a game. It has really nice set peices but nothing really in terms of entertainment. There are weird bugs and glitches that can lead to some unfair and frustrating deaths depending on the difficulty. There was 2 pretty unfair bosses and other cons i put in the list. I am just too lazy to remention them again. I unfortunantly can not reccommend the game since i didnt really have fun playing the game and had issues with bugs and glitches.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13
												★★☆☆☆This HD remaster needs an HD remaster.  Fable Anniversary is an HD re-release of an old hack'n'slash RPG with simple morality systems, but its not especially HD.  People seem to love Fable 1, and hate Fable 3, but I would recommend the opposite.  + Nice music+ Hire bodyguards+ Good Performance+ Title screen is a book+ Skill line specific exps+ Interesting spell variety+ Decent fast travel system+ Buy property to live in or rent out+- Worldmap makes a decent loading screen+- No coop, but this game is old, so that's excuseable+- The boast system is a somewhat interesting idea, betting bonus objectives on quests, but handled clunkily and not very dynamic- Scars- Can't jump- Stealing isn't marked- Clunky spell selection- Escort quests hijack the game- Camera snaps when you end input- Have to go back home to levelup- Manually advance voiced dialogue- Weapon sockets/gems are permenant- Bodygaurds and escort NPCs can die- Clunky menus with tabs inside of tabs- Lockon to friendly targets on accident- Morality and NPC interactions are... lets just call them simple- The 2ish hour intro/tutorial to this game could be removed entirely- Bad save system, that only saves generic checkpoints, and doesn't even do that accurately- Picking up Exp orbs is a tedious mess, even with the pull, and they often get stuck behind objects- Graphics are pretty awful, for a remake made purely to improve the graphics, they may actually be worse than the original- Official mod support?  There are only a handful of mods, and all of them look terrible.  Supposedly the modding tools don't actually work.  * Controller recommended

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Okay. So I played 30 mins of Fable Anniversary and surprisingly, considering from the steam reviews I didn't get a single crash or froze. But I did get frame drops from 60fps to 25fps once, until I turned off the game's Vsync. Now I have 60fps to 85fps ingame. I understand that Vsync will produce the smoothest gameplay without any tears, but for this I didn't see that much tears. My graphics card is an EVGA NVIDIA GTX 650 TI SSC 1GB, and my CPU is an AMD FX 6300. My card is (correct if you want) a simply mid-to-high end graphics card that handles older games such as Skyrim, Far Cry 3, and TOMB RAIDER game.So what's the point?... Well, my PC isn't really a high-end computer especially with a cheaper AMD processor and Nvidia Card inside. I don't know why it works for mine but doesn't work for anyone else. Some reviews I read said that they can't even play the game at all.I bought and owned the Fable Lost Chapters PC version when it was on sale, also played the original version on the first Xbox console. My friend bought me Fable Anniversary as a gift so that way I didn't need to waste my money incase of horrible reviews. The game's good for what it is, but you gotta think Microsoft isn't too keen on testing out the game themselves before publishing it on Steam and assuming that the graphics are updated (which they aren't). So basically it's exactly the same Fable Anniversary from the xbox 360 version but ported on PC, same crappy face models, bloomy blur, sharpen textures, and same old audio recordings. Except you have a harder difficulty mode that you can choose and that you're force to use a controller since there's no mouse controls.I would only recommend this game if you don't own a Xbox 360 anymore (mine got the red ring of death) and that you own a 360 wired controller for your PC. Otherwise you're more likely to buy it on the console instead of PC. And also I wouldn't buy this game now, if I was you I would rather buy this when it's on a big sale. Like $15 or less, hopefully. So far I'm liking this remake even though it's crap, and I wonder when or where in the game I can use the DLC items if you already pre-purchase this game.Thanks for reading my review :)

Overall, the game plays better than i remember, i would have liked maybe some extra missions, but every remake i've bought this year including windwaker hd really didn't have anything new. I say it's worth it if you're new or a fan of the series.-editWith the updates, the problems that people were experiencing like the dark and light will outfits causing choppiness and the key mapping problems are gone. so the game seems even better than before, even though i think the people complaining about the mouse in the menu problem are still just being babies.

												This game... is amazing. ON CONSOLE ONLY. Yes the pc is more often then not the best for games, but this game is the WORST possible port.Ive only played around 40 minutes of it and all it is is a texture pack over the main game, and that would be FINE if they FIXED THE DAMN BUGS AND MADE THIS GAME WITH MEDIOCRE GRAPHICS AND GAMEPLAY RUN RESONABLY WELL.My pc is... mid range, in short it wont be running witcher 3 on Ultra/Uber, but it can run Witcher 2 on high without ubersampling (Low with ubersampling) and stay at a resonable fps, but Fable Anniversary.. NOPE. not even on the lowest settings can it acheve over 7 fps, and i more than meet the recomended system requrements. I even went as far as overclocking and only obtained 12~ fps.I could forgive that... hmmmm if glitches and crashing where fixed. THE GLITCHES ARE CONSTANT... but sometimes funny so ill let that go. But crashing is unforgiveable, i mean THE INTRO OF TAWLKING TO YOUR DAD PERSON CRASHED SO MANY TIMES THAT THE FIRST 20 MINUTES OF MY SUPPOSID PLAY TIME WAS THAT DAMN CUTSCENE, STARTING QUESTS REQURES ME TO SAVE , TALK TO THE QUEST GIVER, LET THE GAME CRASH, LOAD MY SAVE, AND DO IT ONCE MORE AND HOPE I ACTUALLY GET THE DAMN QUEST. EVEN RIDE TO HELL AND ITS DRYHUMPING GAMEPLAY IS BETTER THAN THIS AT LEAST ITS RELIABLE THAT I GET TO DRYHUMP.... IF you run 4 titans in 4 way SLI have fun, if not Get used to crashes and low fps, oh make sure you have a duel cpu mother board, 4GHz ,12 cores, xeon cpu, and use 64 gigs of ECC ram to take advantage of the xeon cpu.But no, if you can get it to run its awesome... AMAZINGLY GOOD for such an old game. But with all my problems with it im afraid i have to say get it on console it will be much more enjoyable there.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Fable 1 has been, and will always be, one of my favorite RPG ever released (along with Kotor and other amazing games) and this game does it justice. It looks great, plays great, and sounds great. It's exactly the game I wanted it to be....ALMOST. The only reason I'm recommending this game is because of how great the storyline and characters are, and how they managed to keep it exactly the same, while improving the graphics. But one major flaw, could've kept me from buying it...THE USER INTERFACE (UI) IS TERRIBLE! You can easily tell this is a game (much like ones we've seen in the past) that had almost no effort put into the PC version. This feels like it was stripped from console, added the ability to use a keyboard and mouse (barely) then released on PC for $35. Only buy this game if you have a controller to play it with, which completely defeats the purpose of buying it on PC. So I recommend this game to die hard fans of Fable (like me) but to NO ONE else until the terrible PC UI is fixed.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												This remake runs identical to the original but with substantially better visuals. It's a joy to return to albion in HD. Keyboard and Mouse support is acceptable but could use some work. Similar to Fable: TLC, you start off your destiny as a young lad in the town of oakvale. It's from this beginning that you mold your hero in your liking, good or evil. You face many challenges that you must use your judgement to decide what is best, again, affecting your hero for good or evil. The story is great, and isn't lacking in combat. You could be a strong hero weilding greatswords, a swift archery killing with precision from a distance, or a master of the will, controlling the arcane arts. Fable isn't the perfect RPG, while you are for the most part free, the story is to some extent on rails and a little open ended. Also, don't expect a massive, expansive world like those in The Elder Scrolls because there is none. Fable is solely "area" based, where you travel from one end of a location to another between loading screens. All-in-All if you are a beloved long time fan of Fable, this is truly a welcomed site. The editor is an oustanding addition, and I can't wait to see the additions the fans of Fable will come to create. 84/100
